title: Brooklyn Beckham pictured just hours wedding actress Nicola Peltz
story: Share this articleExude elegance like Victoria in a dress from her own collectionClick to buyWho better to showcase Victoria Beckham&#39s latest designs than the frontwoman herself?The singer-turned-designer&#39s beautiful dress has topped our wish list. Cut from an organic cotton-blend, it incorporates a square neckline, contrast straps and A-line skirt to create an elegant aesthetic.Love the look as much as we do? Click the product image to add Victoria&#39s dress to your basket. It retails for ¬£590, so might be pricier than your usual dress spend, but you&#39re bound to hold on to a piece like this forever.Alternatively, head to the carousel, where you&#39ll find gorgeous lookalikes by H&ampM, Reformation, &amp Other Stories and Staud. Prices start at just ¬£19.99. If you&#39re feeling spendy, why not treat yourself to her Bottega Veneta bag too?MailOnline may earn commission on sales from these product linksBottega Veneta chain bag at SelfridgesReformation &#39Vinny&#39 dress at NET-A-PORTERStaud &#39Wells&#39 dress at MyTheresa&amp Other Stories cut-out dress (now reduced to ¬£52.50)   BILLIONAIRE BRIDEBrooklyn and Nicola started dating in October 2019, after being introduced by Sofia Richie, the model daughter of singer Lionel.They went public in January 2020 and the engagement was announced in July the same year and sealed with a ¬£160,000 emerald-cut diamond ring.The pair are said to have signed a pre-nuptial agreement, meaning that they will exit the marriage with whatever they took into it should romance fade.¬†Nicola is the youngest of eight siblings, and one of three children by Claudia Heffner Peltz, Nelson Peltz‚Äôs third wife.She was a tomboy who dreamed of playing hockey for a living until she took a drama class when she was 12.Her screen debut was in a Miley Cyrus pop video when she was 13.Aged 15, she was cast as Katara in the 2010 fantasy adventure, The Last Airbender.She is best known for her role as Mark Wahlberg‚Äôs daughter in Transformers: Age Of Extinction. She has since appeared in the TV series Inhumans.Her exes include pop star Justin Bieber, whom she dated briefly in 2016, and Anwar Hadid, the brother of supermodels Gigi and Bella.They split ‚Äòamicably‚Äô after a year, but she unfollowed him and his entire family on Instagram after he was pictured kissing model Kendall Jenner.It has been widely speculated that she is the ‚ÄòHollywood mean girl‚Äô described by actress Bella Thorne in a 2015 interview.In it she said: ‚ÄòI have a mean girl. She‚Äôs in the business, and she‚Äôs very, very mean. I stay away from her at all costs.I never say hello to her. ‚ÄòHer siblings are not mean like she is. It‚Äôs just her. One of the reasons I don‚Äôt like her is because she‚Äôs been a billionaire since she was very little, and she‚Äôs never had to work for anything in her life.‚ÄôThorne knows Peltz because her boyfriend Gregg Sulkin also co-starred in the film Affluenza with Nicola Peltz in 2014.Nicola has never commented on the speculation.

But there were certainly also fans of Putin, as well as people who don't necessarily like Putin but don't want to see their country discredited, despite the war,' he said.Though it was billed as apolitical, the Berlin demo provoked a wave of indignation in Germany, with the Bild daily calling it a 'parade of shame'.¬†UKR Embassy in Ireland on Twitter: &quotIt‚Äôs absolutely disgusting that these russians living inüáÆüá™demonstrate their complete disrespect for country of residence&ampthe Irish people who stand against russia‚Äô ...

title: Games children traditional childhood pastimes dying out
story: Share this articleOther games that have fallen by the wayside include Grandmother's Footsteps (also known as statutes), 91 per cent, Leapfrog (where you jump over others), 81 per cent, and British Bulldogs, (a game where people try to stop you from getting to the other side), 79 per cent.¬†Games of conkers are not played by 79 per cent, and Piggy in the Middle (where the¬†third person in the middle tries to catch a ball) is not played by 56 per cent.¬†And 37 per cent say their kids find gaming far more exciting than the outdoors.¬†In fact, 57 per cent of the parents polled confess their kids have no real connection to nature or the great outdoors.And a fifth of parents, 22 per cent, admit they worry that their child's lack of connection to nature means they will struggle to understand how important it is to protect the environment.The poll of 1,000 UK based parents with children aged five to 12 was commissioned by Persil as part of it's Dirt Is Good campaign.Tati Lindenberg, Marketing Vice-President at Unilever, Dirt Is Good said: 'Getting dirty outdoors is so important for the development of children and their relationship with nature.¬†'We believe that a child has to build a connection with the natural world in order to care for it.'We were shocked to find some of these beloved games, that were such a staple of past generations, are practically on the verge of disappearing.¬†'We wanted to engage with the gaming community and rally support behind encouraging children to head back outside and play.¬†'Nobody should be able to resist a game of muddy tag.'The study also found that nine in ten adults, 93 per cent, say they got more fresh air when they were the same age as their kids and a further four in ten, 42 per cent, that they were more in tune with nature than their children are.

story: Ruth Gregory of Capital Economics says the economic recovery following December‚Äôs Omicron-induced fall in GDP stalled in February: Thomas Pugh, economist at RSM UK, predicts growth will slow sharply through 2022: But February may be the last month with a positive sign in front of its economic growth figure for a while, Pugh warns: ING‚Äôs James Smith forecast a small contraction in the April-June quarter: Danni Hewson, AJ Bell financial analyst, writes that the economy was limping along in February: James Smith of Resolution Foundation warns that there are more headwinds ahead: Here‚Äôs their take on today‚Äôs UK GDP report: French stocks had come under pressure last week, as polls showed Le Pen had narrowed the gap with Macron. The ONS reports that Storms Dudley, Eunice and Franklin caused delays at construction sites, and led some projects to be suspended.  Health spending is likely to be the number one driver of these GDP figures over the next couple of months, Smith adds: Economist Samuel Tombs of Pantheon Macroeconomics says health output could keep dropping for some months: But the easing of travel restrictions lifted the travel sector, Morgan explains. UK economic growth slowed by more than expected in February, with Britain‚Äôs industrial output dropping as manufacturers struggled to obtain parts. Ths was driven by tourism-related industries, after the scrapping of coronavirus testing for double-vaccinated travellers arriving in the UK from mid-February, in time for the half-term holidays. Also this morning, Elon Musk has decided not to join Twitter‚Äôs board of directors, in a U-turn just days after becoming its biggest shareholder. Twitter‚Äôs chief executive, Parag Agrawal, says he believes the moves is for the best.  He‚Äôs been outlining various ways in which Twitter could (in his view) improve the services, including adding an edit button to tweets and criticising its moderation policies. title: french election macron to face off against far right leader le pen in presidential run off
story: France's incumbent leader Emmanuel Macron has urged citizens to block his far-right challenger Marine Le Pen from power when the two go head-to-head on April 24th in a presidential run-off vote. Video: Reuters  Marine Le Pen and Emmanuel Macron will go into the April 24th presidential election runoff, according to projections following Sunday‚Äôs vote.  Photographs: Joel Saget and Eric FeferbergAFP via Getty ImagesPresident Emmanuel Macron will confront the extreme right-wing leader Marine Le Pen in the runoff of the French presidential election on April 24th, after ten other candidates were eliminated in the first round of voting on Sunday.Mr Macron defeated Ms Le Pen five years ago. The Ifop-Fiducial polling institute on Sunday night predicted he will defeat her again, by a much narrower margin of 51 to 49 per cent. That prediction is within the margin of error, meaning Le Pen has a chance of winning. Mr Macron defeated Ms Le Pen by 66 to 34 per cent in 2017.Mr Macron won an estimated 28.3 per cent of the first-round vote, five points higher than Ms Le Pen at 23.3 per cent.There was palpable relief among Mr Macron‚Äôs supporters, because the last opinion polls on Friday had placed Ms Le Pen only one or two percentage points behind him.Four other candidates immediately called on their supporters to vote for Mr Macron in the runoff and the extreme left-wing candidate Jean-Luc M√©lenchon, who came in third with an estimated 21.2 per cent of the vote exhorted his supporters: ‚ÄúDo not give a single vote to Madame Le Pen!‚Äù. Mr M√©lenchon could make a big difference by asking his supporters to vote for Macron.‚ÄúI solemnly invite our compatriots, whatever their choice in the first round, to join us,‚Äù Mr Macron continued. ‚ÄúSome will do so to bar the way for the extreme right. I am fully aware that does not mean they support my programme, and I respect that. I know that is the choice of Jean-Luc M√©lenchon. I salute their clarity towards the extreme right... I want to hold out a hand to all those who want to work for France. ‚ÄùMs Le Pen made a similar appeal, inviting all those who did not vote for Mr Macron to join her. The leader of the Rassemblement National said the runoff presents France with ‚Äúa fundamental choice between opposing visions‚Äù with on one side ‚Äúision, injustice and disorder‚Äù which she said were embodied by Mr Macron, and ‚Äúsocial justice‚Äù if she is elected.Eric Zemmour, also from the extreme right, came in fourth, at around 7 per cent. He was alone in calling on his supporters to give their second-round vote to Le Pen. He said that the party he recently founded, Reconqu√™te! (Reconquest!) ‚Äúwill not give up until France is reconquered‚Äù.Ms Le Pen‚Äôs niece, Marion Mar√©chal, who abandoned her aunt to join Mr Zemmour‚Äôs campaign, said it was up to Ms Le Pen to ‚Äúhold out her hand‚Äù to Mr Zemmour ‚Äúso that Emmanuel Macron will not be re-elected‚Äù.Sunday‚Äôs results showed how successful Mr Macron has been at destroying the traditional left and right-wing parties, the Socialists and Les R√©publicains, but how badly he has failed to blunt the appeal of the extremes. Of the top four candidates, only Mr Macron is not considered an extremist. Three extreme right-wing candidates and Mr M√©lenchon from the far left won a combined score of about 53 per cent.None of the other candidates was certain to reach the 5 per cent threshold required to have their campaign expenses reimbursed.By winning more than 20 per cent of the vote, Mr M√©lenchon, a former Socialist, is positioned to lead the remnants of the French left in the legislative elections which follow in June.Stay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: perilous moment conservative party
story: And we have the ongoing police investigation into whether Boris Johnson himself broke lockdown rules by attending events in his flat and the offices within Number Ten. Here there is already a concerted attempt by loyalists to downplay the significance of the moment should the Prime Minister be fined by the police. Their job has been made easier by the strength Johnson has shown in arming Ukraine and standing up to Russia. They are aided too by the sense that Sunak‚Äôs recent difficulties mean he is less likely, for now at least, to win the race to succeed Johnson. And they will use Sunak‚Äôs example as a warning against taking a chance on other less experienced candidates.Regardless of their good fortune, however, the loyalists‚Äô arguments will not wash. It is not sustainable, for example, for Downing Street to keep the names of senior staffers or officials secret after they have been fined. Nor is it sustainable for fines issued in relation to events in the Downing Street flat to be kept secret. Nor can the Prime Minister or his spokesmen get away with refusing to accept that it will be established, if he is issued with a fine he accepts and pays, that he has broken the law.However much the loyalists may wish to convince themselves otherwise, the idea that a prime minister should survive a process that finds him guilty not only of breaking the law, but breaking extraordinary laws he imposed and implored the public to respect, is simply absurd. So too is the idea that he should survive after denying breaking those laws and issuing emphatic denials in Parliament.The Conservative Party might be capable of deluding itself thus, but if it does the public will draw very different conclusions. They will see a Government ‚Äì already struggling with inflation and finding it difficult to get things done ‚Äì closing ranks and showing appalling double standards.This is dangerous enough for the Tories, but if part of the strategy to prop up the Prime Minister is to limit and discredit potential successors, there follow two more problems. Keeping tall poppies away from high office will mean the quality of day-to-day government will continue to suffer. And it will risk a crisis of leadership following the Johnson premiership, whenever it ends, as the choices are narrowed unnecessarily. It is ridiculous that the likes of Tom Tugendhat and Jeremy Hunt remain on the backbenches, and ridiculous that some in Downing Street see only advantage in Sunak‚Äôs recent difficulties.With notable exceptions ‚Äì such as Nadhim Zahawi‚Äôs vaccine rollout, Ben Wallace‚Äôs work arming the Ukrainians, and Priti Patel‚Äôs forthcoming plans to establish offshore processing for asylum claims ‚Äì much of what the Government is doing is piecemeal, technocratic and often contradictory. The Tories want to intervene in the economy, but have junked their industrial strategy. They say they want lower taxes, but keep putting them up. They promise to level-up the country, but while Michael Gove has the ideas, he lacks the spending power for them to make a difference quickly enough.As with the questions of ethical standards in government, this lack of coherence can be explained in part by the Prime Minister‚Äôs style of leadership. Johnson has deliberately formed a third eleven cabinet, to avoid creating powerful rivals. He has set lofty targets, but neither formed detailed plans to achieve them, nor empowered ministers to do so. He has appointed a chancellor with whom he was always going to clash thanks to their contrasting methods of working and starkly different views of fiscal policy.Tired governments, made complacent by years in office, come to believe that their position of power will last forever. They lose sight of the bigger picture, drift into technocratic decision-making, and their fights with one another grow more important than those with opposing parties and vested interests.Unfortunately, this government now suffers all these ills.So now seems a good time for Conservatives to remind themselves of the binary nature of power in our parliamentary democracy. You either hold power, or you do not. You can change the country, or you can watch the other side change it in ways you dislike.More from NewsChechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov warns Russia will &#39take Kyiv&#39 in new offensiveRussia-Ukraine latest news: Russia could use phosphorus munitions to seize Mariupol, warns MoDPolitics latest news: Rishi Sunak has been &#39very candid&#39 about tax, insistsWhy this French presidential election heralds the demise of traditional politicsLocal Elections 2022: What is up for election, where, and how to votePink Moon 2022: when it peaks in the UK and other full moon datesMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: easter holidaymakers urged travel night country braced busiest
story: Easter holidaymakers have been urged to travel at night to avoid road chaos as travel woes are set to worsen.An estimated 21.5 million leisure trips will be made between Good Friday and Easter Monday, making it the busiest weekend on Britain‚Äôs roads in at least eight years, according to the RAC.As families seek to avoid chaos on the railway network, with 2,500 train routes due to be delayed or cancelled, and in airports, where Covid staff shortages continue to cause disruption, more are expected to travel by car for the first bank holiday in two years with no legal restrictions.Long delays are also expected to continue on roads in Kent because of a shortage of cross-Channel sailings caused by the suspension of operations by P&ampO Ferries after it sacked nearly 800 workers.The RAC, which began tracking motorists' Easter plans in 2014, has urged drivers wishing to avoid congestion this weekend to set off before 9am or delay their journeys until after 7:30pm.Around 2,000 roadworks will be in place over the Easter weekend, and the busiest single day on the roads is expected to be Good Friday.In addition to increased congestion, motorists also face the most expensive Easter on record when it comes to fuel prices.Latest government figures show the average cost of a litre of petrol at UK forecourts on April 4 was 161.9p, with diesel at 176.0p.Likely congestion spots will include the M25 clockwise from Junction 8 (Reigate Hill Interchange, Surrey) to Junction 16 (Denham Interchange, Buckinghamshire), the M6 north between Greater Manchester and the Lake District, and near Stonehenge, Wiltshire.Meanwhile, several airlines and airports are struggling to cope with staff sickness and shortages, prompting thousands of flights to be cancelled by easyJet and British Airways in recent weeks.Manchester Airport is warning departing passengers to expect delays of up to 90 minutes, whilst rail passengers are being warned of delays as Network Rail carries out 530 engineering projects costing a total of ¬£83 million.The West Coast Main Line will be closed between London Euston and Milton Keynes between Good Friday and Easter Monday because of upgrades of the existing line and HS2 work.This will affect football supporters as Liverpool and Manchester City meet in an FA Cup semi-final match at Wembley on Saturday.Rod Dennis, an RAC traffic spokesman, said: After two years of relatively quiet Easter bank holidays on the roads, our research suggests a return to traffic levels that are much more typical of this time of year.It's very possible this weekend could turn out to be one of the busiest for leisure journeys for many years.Add in the impact of disruption on the rail network and one of the biggest fixtures of the sporting calendar taking place this weekend, and you have all the ingredients needed for problems on the roads.Traffic volumes will likely be even higher if some warm spring sunshine makes an appearance.Mr Dennis urged drivers to make sure vehicles are prepared for getaway trips.This is even more important for anyone travelling longer distances than they have for several months, he said.A breakdown is much less likely if a car's oil and coolant levels, as well as tyre pressure and tread depth, have all been checked before setting out.A Network Rail spokesperson said: 2,500 train services over the four-day Easter weekend will be affected by works. Some will be running on alternative or shorter routes with buses.Over 95 per cent of our network is open for business but works will affect some routes. Please check before you travel.More from NewsRussia-Ukraine latest news: Russia could use phosphorus munitions to seize Mariupol, warns MoDPolitics latest news: Rishi Sunak has been &#39very candid&#39 about tax, insistsWhy this French presidential election heralds the demise of traditional politicsLocal Elections 2022: What is up for election, where, and how to votePink Moon 2022: when it peaks in the UK and other full moon datesChechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov warns Russia will &#39take Kyiv&#39 in new offensiveMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: france should take leaf brexit britains book
story: Meanwhile, the centre-right candidates, debating the ‚Äúgreat replacement‚Äù theory that the growth of the Muslim population is an attempt to diplace whites, distanced themselves from the term, but not the premise. Val√©rie P√©cresse did not like it because ‚Äúit implies we‚Äôre already screwed.‚ÄùI‚Äôve been fascinated by the fate of the Safe To Be Me conference, which the Government was promoting as Britain‚Äôs first state-backed LGBT summit (Britain being evil, yet again) ‚Äì till the Tories decided not to ban trans conversion therapy and various groups pulled out. This failed venture cost taxpayers ¬£650,000. The projected budget was ¬£8.1 million.While Westminster is pretending to be desperately upset that this conference has been cancelled, some readers might be more surprised that it was ever taking place. We can infer from the decision of supporters to withdraw that you and I were paying big bucks to bankroll an event to promote policies that the elected Government is opposed to. According to a statement made in December, Safe To Be Me was being worked on by 8.25 members of staff ‚Äúwithin the international LGBT+ team in the Cabinet Office‚Äù, which raises the questions, what on earth is an ‚Äúinternational LGBT+ team‚Äù and why do we need one? Given that we cannot house our people adequately (16,000 families are being evicted each month), this doesn‚Äôt sound like a priority.More from NewsRussia-Ukraine latest news: Russia could use phosphorus munitions to seize Mariupol, warns MoDWhy this French presidential election heralds the demise of traditional politicsPolitics latest news: Rishi Sunak has been &#39very candid&#39 about tax, insistsLocal Elections 2022: What is up for election, where, and how to votePink Moon 2022: when it peaks in the UK and other full moon datesChechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov warns Russia will &#39take Kyiv&#39 in new offensiveMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: chancellor rishi sunak asks prime
story: Chancellor Rishi Sunak asks Prime Minister for probe into his OWN financial affairsChancellor Rishi Sunak has referred himself to Boris Johnsons independent adviser on ministerial interests, Lord Geidt, over his own financial affairsRishi Sunak Image: Getty ImagesByRachel WearmouthSenior Political CorrespondentRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsRishi Sunak has asked the Prime Minister for a probe into his own financial affairs. The under-fire Chancellor tonight took the dramatic step of referring himself to Boris Johnsonaposs independent adviser on ministerial interests, Lord Geidt, following a growing row over his familyaposs financial arrangements. It comes hours after he had ordered a Whitehall inquiry into how his weaposs tax arrangements were leaked to the media. Mr Sunakaposs political future hangs by a thread as he faces fresh calls to come clean over his tax affairs and US immigration status. The Tory minister tried to claim his we Akshata Murty was the victim of a smear campaign, after it emerged she held non-domiciled tax status, which allows people to avoid paying UK tax on overseas income.  The Chancellor, whose Spring Statement last month failed to help struggling families cope with the UKaposs biggest fall in living standards since the time of rationing, was reportedly weighing up whether to quit after a string of damaging stories. His team has previously argued all declarations to the register of ministerial interests were above board. In a statement posted on Twitter on Sunday evening, Mr Sunak said: ‚ÄúI have always followed the rules and I hope such a review will provide further clarity.‚Äù In a letter to Mr Johnson, Mr Sunak said his ‚Äúoverriding concern‚Äù was to maintain public confidence.  ‚ÄúMy overriding concern is that the public retain confidence in the answers that are given and I believe the best way of achieving this is to ensure those answers are entirely independent, without bias or favour,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúTo that end I would recommend that Lord Geidt makes all his conclusions public. ‚ÄúI am confident that such a review of my declarations will find all relevant information was appropriately declared. ‚ÄúI have throughout my ministerial career followed the advice of officials regarding matters or propriety and disclosure and will continue to do so.‚Äù  The White House has been urged to investigate after Mr Sunak admitted holding a US green card until October  - while he was the Chancellor.Mr Sunak has been hit with reports that he is listed as a beneficiary of tax haven trusts in the Cayman Islands and British Virgin Islands, despite pledging to close tax loopholes. Meanwhile, Infosys, an Indian firm founded by his weaposs billionaire father, where Ms Murty holds ¬£m of shares in, is urgently reviewing its base in Moscow. Shadow Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said it was a matter of ‚Äúbasic fairness‚Äù that the Chancellor‚Äôs family should pay tax in the same way as everyone . ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think the Chancellor gets that. That raises real questions about his judgment,‚Äù she told BBC‚Äôs Sunday Morning programme.  Policing Minister Kit Malthouse admitted Ms Murtyaposs status as a non-dom - something she gave up last week amid public fury - was ‚Äúnot ideal‚Äù, but nonetheless rushed to defend Mr Sunak from colleagues who declared the Chancelloraposs career to be toast. He said the Chancellor was a ‚Äúsmart, clever, committed politician‚Äù who had helped steer the economy through the worst of the pandemic. Ms Murty, who is an Indian citizen, dramatically announced on Friday that she would now pay UK taxes on all her worldwide income as she did not want her tax status to be a distraction. It has been estimated that her non-dom status could have saved her ¬£ million in taxes on idends on her shares. Mr Malthouse admitted it was ‚Äúnot a brilliant time‚Äù for the details to come out when the country was struggling with a cost of living crisis. ‚ÄúRishi Sunak has been a remarkable force for good in this country over the last two years, he said.‚ÄúHe put in place some incredible support schemes during the pandemic at enormous speed. ‚ÄúIt is not ideal, but we all when we sign up for this job know that there is going to be rough times and smooth times,‚Äù he added. Meanwhile sources close to Mr Sunak have played down reports that he was moving his we and two daughters out of Downing Street to escape the glare of the media. The Sunday Mirror published pictures of removal vans arriving in the street on Saturday to take their belongings away. One source said however they had always intended to spend more time in their west London home as their elder daughter, Krishna, entered her final term of primary school before moving on to secondary school. Mr Sunak is still expected to stay in Downing Street during the week while joining them at weekends. Labouraposs Angela Rayner said: ‚ÄúThe chaos caused by the Conservatives over the last week must be brought to an end. ‚ÄúA fish rots from the head. It is the Prime Minister‚Äôs responsibility to bring this debacle to a close by ensuring that standards are upheld across his Cabinet. When it comes to the Tories hiking up taxes on working people, it seems it is one rule for them and another for the rest of us.‚Äù Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Breaking NewsRishi Sunak" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: fishy rishi beached chancellor struggling
story: Fishy Rishi is a beached Chancellor struggling to survive and considering quittingChancellor Rishi Sunak seems unlikely to ever succeed the morally corrupt incumbent Prime Minister Boris Johnson - all down to the ongoing non-dom scandal related to his we, Kevin Maguire says" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _The-Prince-Of-Wales-And-Duchess-Of-Cornwall-Celebrate-The-British-Asian-Trust.jpg" width"" "" The Tory minister and his billionaire heiress we Akshata Murthy were the victims of a smear campaign this week Image: UK Press via Getty ImagesopinionByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  Apr |commentsFish rot from the head down and the stench of contempt in Downing Street is seeing scales falling from voters‚Äô eyes. Fishy Rishi is a beached Chancellor without credibility, struggling to survive and contemplating resignation over the Rishi Notax scandal. The nets trawling the sordid financial affairs of his incredibly wealthy family may yet produce another jaw-dropper that will force the Tory moneybags to resign in disgrace. And the morally corrupt Prime Minister he‚Äôs now unlikely ever to succeed ‚Äì charlatan Boris Johnson, who presided over widespread law-breaking during Covid, his head on the chopping block until Putin spared him ‚Äì remains a rotten man. Downing Street‚Äôs decaying neighbours represent a Conservative government decomposing rapidly, with ministers mocked for regurgitating on the airwaves pathetic excuses for indefensible behaviour.  Draw a Venn diagram and the fools spouting drivel to shield slippery Sunak and an heiress we, Akshata Murty, who‚Äôd pay ¬£, to avoid millions of pounds in British tax, overlap with idiots who ly claimed Johnson didn‚Äôt hold parties and is innocent of all charges. Whether what non-dom Murty and Green Card Sunak did was legal misses the point that it is unacceptable for a Chancellor to put up taxes for the little people while his family lawfully dodge them. Sleaze taking the Tories back to the John Major era is a glorious opportunity for Labour ‚Äì and a challenge. Leader Keir Starmer is receiving conflicting advice. Either he sticks with Ed Miliband and Jeremy Corbyn‚Äôs proposals to end the non-dom scam, or he listens to those who say it would be seen as anti-business. Championing fairness could draw a thick red line between Labour and the Tories at the election. The Conservative fish is rotting... Labour needs to use its head. title: nearly half teachers england plan
story: Nearly half of teachers in England plan to QUIT within five years amid workload stressA bombshell survey by the National Education Union found % intend to leave by  - with half of thoseplanning to quit within two yearsTeachers have warned they are struggling to cope with unmanageable workloads Image: Rex FeaturesByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Apr  planning to quit within two years" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s PROD-VARIOUS.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top" planning to quit within two years" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s PROD-VARIOUS.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top" planning to quit within two years" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s PROD-VARIOUS.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"|commentsNearly half of state school teachers in England plan to quit over the next five years amid soaring workload pressures. A survey of , teachers for the National Education Unionfound % intend to leave by  - with half of thoseplanning to quit within two years. Stretched schools are already struggling to fill vacant posts, with % of teachers saying this has worsened since the start of the pandemic. Over halfof teachers said their workload was either ‚Äòunmanageable‚Äô or ‚Äòunmanageable most of the time‚Äô - up from % in . Two-thirds of teachers feel stressed at least % of the time, according to the poll released ahead of the start of the unionaposs annual conference in Bournemouth today.  NEU Joint General Secretary Dr Mary Bousted said teachers had among the highest number of unpaid working hours, saying: This is simply unsustainable and can only lead to burn-out. ‚ÄúThe government would do well to not just accept that high workload is a problem, but that they have played a starring role in many of the contributing factors. Dr Bousted went on: The Department for Education must take steps to right the ship, which is currently shedding too many staff and not finding enough to replace them. This is to a very large extent because the job is made unattractive and unsustainable. Labour warned that Tory cuts and the chaotic handling of childrenaposs education during the pandemic had made le a misery for schools. Shadow Schools Minister Stephen Morgan said: A decade of Conservative government and their botched handling of the pandemic is driving teachers out of our schools. Unsustainable workloads, doubling up on roles to plug staffing gaps, soaring stress levels, these are not conditions that will deliver the world class education our children deserve. A Department for Education spokesperson said: We recognise the pressure that staff in schools and colleges have been under and are enormously grateful to them for their efforts, resilience, and service now and throughout the COVID- pandemic. Teaching remains an attractive and fulfilling profession. The number of teachers in our schools remains high, with more than , teachers working in schools across the country ‚Äì , more than in . We have taken and will continue to take action to improve teacher and leader workload and wellbeing, working proactively with the sector to understand the drivers behind such issues and improve our policies and interventions. title: pm needs firm hand priti
story: PM needs a firm hand with Priti Patelhe wants to help Ukrainian refugeesBoris Johnson has shown that Britain is committed to Ukrainian independence and that it stands by refugees in their hour of need. However, Priti Patel is not issuing them with visas quickly enoughBoris Johnson has shown that Britain supports Ukrainian independence Image: POOL AFP via Getty ImagesopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Apr |comments Although Boris Johnson had one eye on a great photo op on his surprise visit to Kyiv today, there is no doubting the genuine friendship between our PM and Volodymyr Zelensky.The Ukrainian president was certainly also grateful for Mr Johnson‚Äôs offer of extra British weaponry while there. On the international stage, Mr Johnson has shown Britain to be Ukraine‚Äôs staunchest ally, committed to Ukrainian independence and standing by the Ukrainian people in their hour of need. But that story is disturbingly dferent closer to home. What Ukrainian people fleeing war need most is sanctuary, and , big-hearted British families are ready to open their homes to provide it. Yet only , Ukrainian refugees have arrived here so far under the Homes for Ukraine scheme.  That is because Priti Patel is not issuing them with visas quickly enough. The Home Secretary promised Ukrainian MP Lesia Vasylenko she would ensure visas were processed in three days. That was three weeks ago. Ms Vasylenko is an impressive MP. And she is not impressed by Ms Patel‚Äôs dilly-dallying. In Kyiv today, Mr Johnson showed President Zelensky the firm hand of friendship. Now the PM needs to take a firm hand with Ms Patel ‚Äì and tell her thatshe cannot sort out this mess, he will find someone who can.  Grant us a plan There was something depressingly inevitable about Brits who‚Äôd been looking forward to their first proper holiday for years spending much of it stuck in traffic jams and airport lounges. Today, chaos reigned on the ground and in the air as people tried to get away for a much-needed Easter break. The port of Dover blamed its delays on the suspension of PO Ferries. Airports said they were plagued by Covid staff absences. And Transport Secretary Grant Shapps wrung his hands and expressed concern, which was about as much use as a flat tyre on the M. PO bosses are to blame for some of this by their summary sacking of  seafarers. We must spare a thought for them and their families. But Mr Shapps knew PO would present a problem this weekend. And Covid should have come as no surprise to him. Labour says better planning could have alleviated some of these delays. And when it comes to travel, Mr Shapps is planner-in-chief. Tea infusiasts You have to be British to appreciate Sue and Keith Blayze‚Äôs passion for collecting teapots because where in the world, they would be dubbed crackpots. The couple have spent ¬£, on their collection, which now attracts thousands of visitors a year and even earned royal approval when Prince Charles and Camilla popped in. Which just goes to show that when it comes to hobbies, Sue and Keith have theirs down to a tea. title: pm photo op zelensky now
story: PM got his photo op with Zelensky, but now he must look at the bigger picturePrime Minister Boris Johnson raced to get his grip and grin moment with President Zelensky - but lives depend on him delivering on all his promises to UkraineBoris Johnson met Volodymyr Zelensky in Ukraine Image: @UkrEmbLondon TwitteropinionByVoice of the People:,  Apr |comments It was a race against time for Boris Johnson.Determined to beat EU leaders to Kyiv, he headed out today for a photo op with Zelensky. And he got the snap he wanted. A handshake and grin before getting back on the plane. Job done. Kind of. After all, that‚Äôs the optics sorted, PM, now it‚Äôs time for action. During his brief stay Mr Johnson pledged, as is his wont, everything that Ukraine needs to survive as a sovereign nation. And he‚Äôs promised missiles, rockets, armoured vehicles and new anti-ship weapons systems. That‚Äôs a start ‚Äì these weapons are much needed. They are up against one of the world‚Äôs largest and most ruthless armies.  But the battlefield is not the only place where the PM needs to deliver. He also promised visas. He promised that the UK would make the process as easy as possible for desperate refugees. That‚Äôs a promise he‚Äôs failed to deliver. More accurately, his Home Secretary has failed. Lesia Vasylenko, a Ukrainian MP who took up arms against the Russians, said she was promised visas in three days by Priti Patel ‚Äì three weeks ago. We‚Äôre used to this Government breaking promises. But to renege on a deal made to such desperate people is unforgivable. The joke in the Ukraine is that the visas will land when the war is over. Dark humour but frighteningly close to the bone. Mr Johnson needs to act with the same urgency on this as he did when he sped off to Kyiv. This is not a photo op, not a headline grabber, not an opportunity to spin. It‚Äôs about people‚Äôs lives. People we promised to help. Time to deliver.  Prove your honour Speaking of promises - it‚Äôs time for Prince Andrew to step up. He‚Äôs had plenty of chances to prove he remains capable of doing the right thing. He pledged to help victims of sex trafficking as he paid out to his accuser Virginia Giuffre, saying he would atone for his association with Jeffrey Epstein by supporting the fight. Now, victims want him to act. This is the time, surely, to prove he still has some honour left  Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Boris JohnsonVolodymyr ZelenskyUkraineRussia Ukraine warSunday People" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: priti patel told uk visa
story: Priti Patel told UK visa process for Ukrainian refugees is a national disgraceShadow Home Secretary Yvette Cooper branded the speed of the visa process for Ukrainian refugees as scandalous and shameful, leaving thousands of people stuck in limboUkrainian evacuees queue as they wait for further transport at the Medyka border crossing, after they crossed the Ukrainian-Polish border Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Apr |commentsPriti Patel has been accused of presiding over a national disgrace as Ukrainian refugees face long delays getting to the UK because of the visa system. Shadow Home Secretary Yvette Cooper described the latest figures as ‚Äúscandalous and shameful‚Äù, claiming thousands of people are ‚Äústuck in limbo‚Äù as she accused the Tory minister of letting everyone down. As of Thursday, about , applications had been submitted to the schemes and , visas had been granted. Of these, , applications were for the sponsorship scheme, with , visas issued. Out of , requests made for family visas, , had been approved. Ms Cooper said: ‚ÄúThis is scandalous and shameful.  Over thirty thousand people with British sponsors waiting are still stuck in limbo - around half of whom have been waiting more than ten days already to hear anything.A shocking % of Homes for Ukraine applications are still waiting for a visa.Behind these numbers are many desperate mothers and children in temporary accommodation or still sheltering in Ukraine. Where is the Home Secretary  She needs to stop hiding and account for this national disgrace. British families have offered Ukrainians sanctuary in their hour of need, but the Home Secretary is letting everyone down.  Policing Minister Kit Malthouse admitted that there was frustration with the visa process when he was challenged on Sky News over how few refugees have arrived in the UK so far. He said: I know that people are disappointed with the progress of the visa regime. ‚ÄúThe Home Secretary has been out this week expressing her frustration and regret that it hasn‚Äôt been quicker but we are motoring now.‚ÄùIn a pre-recorded interview aired on the BBC on Friday, Ms Patel apologised ‚Äúwith frustration‚Äù but denied that visa requirements and checks are slowing the process and causing delays, insisting the UK will ‚Äúabsolutely see changes in numbers‚Äù as work continues.She said: ‚ÄúI apologise with frustration myself‚Ä¶ it takes time to start up a new route.‚Äù Meanwhile, crossbench peer Baroness Finlay, who is offering space in her Cardf home to a family, said the scheme was unwelcoming and only adding to refugeesapos trauma. She said her husband, Professor Andrew Finlay, spent eight hours filling out forms for their visa applications on March , the day the scheme launched.just so confusing and complicated, she said. title: rishi sunak moves out downing
story: Exclusive: Rishi Sunak moves belongings out of Downing Street as he clings on to job as ChancellorThe Sunday Mirror understands Rishi Sunaks family is moving to their West London pad because his eldest daughter is about to go to boarding school Image: Rex ShutterstockByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsUnder-fire Rishi Sunak moved belongings out of Downing Street today, as he desperately clung on to his job as Chancellor. Removals vans were seen lining up to take furniture and personal items from the flat shared by Mr Sunak and we Akshata Murthy and move them to their newly-refurbished, luxury West London pad. A red velvet armchair, a shelving unit and several bags and boxes were loaded onto two trucks, which arrived at Downing Street‚Äôs back gate early on Saturday morning. But the Sunday Mirror understands the move was planned before Mr Sunak‚Äôs popularity noseed this week. The family are making the move because their eldest daughter is about to go into her final term of primary school, the Mirror understands. They want to be nearer to her school for the last few months before she goes to boarding school.  Mr Sunak is expected to split his evenings between the Downing Street flat and their Kensington home, but continue to work from Number .Previously a shoe-in to replace Boris Johnson as the next Prime Minister, Mr Sunak‚Äôs fortunes have been on the wane since last month‚Äôs disastrous Spring Statement failed to provide help for families facing a cost of living crisis. This week it was revealed Mrs Murthy enjoyed non-dom tax status - and Mr Sunak had held on to his Green Card as a ‚Äòresident‚Äô of the United Sates for more than a year after becoming Chancellor. It comes amid calls for partners and spouses of ministers to be banned from being non-doms - and avoiding paying tax on money made outside the UK. Labour said Mr Sunak and his family potentially saved tens of millions of pounds in taxes through his weaposs non-dom status. And Shadow Transport Secretary Louise Haigh blasted the chancellor for not being transparent about his family‚Äôs tax status. ‚ÄúHe has come out on a number of occasions to try and muddy the waters around this and to obfuscate, she said. Mrs Murty announced on Friday that she would voluntarily pay UK taxes on all her worldwide income as she did not want her financial arrangements to be a distraction for her husband. But she will keep her non-dom status, which allows her to take advantage of India‚Äôs zero rate of inheritance tax on her family‚Äôs multi-million pound business empire. And the SNP called on Mr Sunak to publish his tax s.Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said the scandal showed the Chancellor and his we lived in a completely dferent universe in financial terms from ordinary people left struggling by the cost-of-living crisis. The Lib Dems have called on the PM to ban the wives and partners of ministers from using the non-dom ‚Äúloophole‚Äù. Lib Dem Treasury Spokesperson Christine Jardine said: ‚ÄúGovernment ministers have a duty to do what‚Äôs morally right. When they change peoples‚Äô taxes, they and their immediate families should play by the same rules as everybody .‚Äù Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Rishi SunakBoris JohnsonConservative Party" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: rishi sunaks political future brink
story: Rishi Sunaks political future on brink of collapse amid wes tax scandalThe Chancellor Rishi Sunak has been fighting fires since delivering his Spring statement last month after which he was blasted for being out of touch amid a worsening cost of living crisisThe Chancellor of the Exchequer Rishi Sunak leaving Downing Street this week Image: Nigel HowardByRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Apr |comments Embattled Rishi Sunak ‚Äôs political future hangs by a thread as he faces fresh calls to come clean over his tax affairs and US immigration status.The Chancellor tried to hide behind claims he and billionaire we Akshata Murty were victims of a ‚Äúsmear‚Äù cam-paign, after it emerged she had been avoiding paying UK tax as a non-dom. And he was reportedly weighing up quitting after admitting holding a US green card while Chancellor ‚Äì which foreign ministers are supposedly not permitted to do. The White House was urged to probe the claim. Mr Sunak also faces reports that he is listed as a beneficiary of offshore tax haven trusts, despite pledging to close tax loopholes.  Meanwhile, Infosys, an Indian firm his we holds ¬£million of shares in, is ‚Äúurgently‚Äù reviewing its Moscow base amid claims the Sunaks were benefiting from Putin‚Äôs regime. But Mr Sunak was again accused of being out of touch after aides briefed yesterday that he had ordered an ‚Äúaggressive‚Äù Whitehall inquiry into how his we‚Äôs tax details were leaked. Shadow Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said it was a matter of ‚Äúbasic fairness‚Äù that the Chancellor‚Äôs family should pay tax like everyone .She said: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think the Chancellor gets that. That raises real questions about his judgement.‚Äù Policing Minister Kit Malthouse said Ms Murty‚Äôs status as a non-dom, which she has given up, was ‚Äúnot ideal‚Äù, but defended Mr Sunak from colleagues who called his career ‚Äútoast‚Äù. He called Mr Sunak a ‚Äúsmart, clever, committed politician‚Äù who steered the economy through Covid.Heiress Ms Murty, who remains an Indian citizen, said on Friday that she would now pay UK tax on all global income so as not to be ‚Äúa distraction‚Äù. It was estimated her non-dom status could have saved her ¬£mil-lion in taxes on share idends.Mr Sunak yesterday said he has written to Boris Johnson asking him to refer his ministerial declarations to the Independent Adviser on Ministers‚Äô Interests.He said: ‚ÄúI have always followed the rules. I hope such a review will provide further clarity.‚Äù Sources close to Mr Sunak played down reports that he is moving his family out of Downing Street to escape the media‚Äôs glare, saying they want to spend more time in their West London home as elder daughter Krishna completes primary school. title: sajid javid held non dom
story: Sajid Javid held non-dom status and had money in offshore trust before becoming MPAmid an ongoing row over Rishi Sunaks wes non-dom status, Sajid Javid came clean about his own use of the scheme before entering ParliamentHealth Secretary Sajid Javid Image: REUTERSByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsSajid Javid has admitted he previously held non-domicile tax status and kept money in an offshore trust. Amid an ongoing row over Rishi Sunakaposs weaposs non-dom status, the Health Secretary came clean about his own use of the scheme before entering Parliament in . Mr Javid also admitted to benefitting from an offshore trust when he worked for Deutsche Bank but said he voluntarily collapsed the trust when he became a minister in . Labour blasted him for hypocrisy over the revelations, which came after the Tories hiked national insurance contributions for millions of Brits last week.Non-dom status is a legal scheme that allows people domiciled abroad to avoid paying UK tax on their overseas income.  The arrangement has come under scrutiny after it emerged that Mr Sunakaposs we Akshata Murty held non-dom status, which could have spared her paying millions of pounds in UK tax.Ms Murty bowed to intense political pressure on Friday and said she will now pay UK tax on her overseas income, which includes an estimated ¬£. million a year in idends from her billionaire fatheraposs IT firm Infosys.In a statement first reported by the Sunday Times, Mr Javid said: I have been domiciled in the UK for tax purposes throughout my entire public le. Given heightened public interest in these issues, I want to be open about my past tax statuses. After a posting in New York between  and , where he paid US taxes, Mr Javid ed to the UK where he was a tax resident.He said: ‚ÄúFor some of those years I was non-domiciled for tax purposes, but I paid all UK taxes due on my income and have always done so. It is unclear where he was domiciled during this period but it is understood not to have been Pakistan, where his father was born. Mr Javid went on: ‚ÄúIn  I moved to Singapore with my family and was therefore no longer a UK tax resident. In , upon myto the UK, I became tax-resident in the UK again and also proactively chose to give up my non-domiciled status by making the UK my ‚Äòdomicile of choice‚Äô. He became an MP in  and went on to hold a number of Cabinet jobs, including Chancellor from  to . Mr Javid also admitted to having some financial investments based in an offshore trust before he ed to the UK and entered Parliament.  He said: While this was an entirely legitimate arrangement, on becoming a minister in  I decided to voluntarily collapse that trust, repatriate all assets to the UK and pay  per cent income tax on those assets. ‚ÄúThis approach deliberately incurred the heaviest possible tax burden, and offset any accrued benefits from the previous trust arrangement, but I believed it was the right thing to do.‚ÄùShadow Health Secretary Wes Streeting said: Last week Sajid Javid was lecturing struggling taxpayers about their duty to pay higher taxes, but this is the guy who spent six years as a non-dom and had an offshore trust to avoid paying his fair share of tax in Britain.Even now, he refuses to sayhe was using a tax haven. The hypocrisy stinks. The luxury of being able to choose how much tax you pay, where you pay it, and when you pay it, is not one that is enjoyed by most people in this country. title: what undeniable queens platinum jubilee
story: What is undeniable is the Queens Platinum Jubilee will see a new phase to her reignThe Queen has struggled with wider poor health issues forcing her to miss public engagements - making it clear that the time is fast approaching for Prince Charles and Prince William to ease her burdenThe Queen contracting the virus at the age of  was downplayed by Buckingham Palace Image: POOL AFP via Getty ImagesopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Apr |commentsDiscussing the debilitating exhaustion inflicted on some Covid victims, the Queen both connected with those facing long-term ill effects and may have given us an insight into her own condition. Her contracting the virus at the age of  was downplayed by Buckingham Palace. Understandably, the monarch was unable to fulfil a number of engagements and wider poor health caused her to miss ceremonies at which her attendance was once a given. Like many vulnerable and older citizens, even a head of state must look after herself and be cared for carefully because age doesn‚Äôt travel alone, as Labour MP Dennis Skinner once observed. Other royals, particularly Charles and William, can take the strain to ease the burden. What is increasingly undeniable is an unparalleled Platinum Jubilee is also the start of a new, dferent phase in her reign.  The info war The misery, fear and death suffered by Ukrainians at the hands of Putin‚Äôs war criminals is harrowing and heartbreaking.Graphic accounts and details from traumatised survivors, men and women who a couple of months ago were living peaceful, even mundane lives, are the first draft of historyand charge sheets for investigations and,hopefully, prosecutions.What we‚Äôre reading, hearing, seeing and feeling isn‚Äôt unique to this war. But rapid, ubiquitous communications allow us to be informed sooner and in greater depth. Ukraine is a tragedy inflicted by a guilty man.  Rishi‚Äôs rattled Demanding the head of whoever ulged details of his rich family‚Äôs unforgivable tax arrangements, rattled Rishi Sunak again demonstrates he‚Äôs an out of touch Conservative Chancellor. He and puppets parroting the deceit that Sunak‚Äôs been totally open should stop and ask themselveshe was, why is he so eager to unmask the person who told the truth. title: couple who shed 15st after
story: Couple who shed st after embarrassing funfair incident reveal their new daily dietAllison and Alasdair Mcluskie, from Dreghorn, near Irvine, Scotland, were fed up with being overweight so decided to change their lestyle in favour of a healthier lives, and their transformations are staggeringAllison and Alasdair Mcluskie with their son Jacob Image: PA Real LeByZoe ForseyFeatures Editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsA devoted couple have lost nearly st between them after she became fed up with being the fat mum, fat we and fat friend and he was marched off a funfair ride with his son for being too heavy. Diagnosed with multiple sclerosiswhich affects the brain and nerves  years ago, at st lb and wearing a dress size  , Allison Mcluskie, , knew that losing weight would improve her mobility, but found it dficult as she could not perform strenuous exercise. With cooked breakfasts, toasties and takeaways forming the basic diet for her and her ft in chef husband, Alasdair Mcluskie, , who weighed st lb, they were not setting a healthy example for their son, Jacob, nine, but every time Alison tried to slim she was tempted back to eating caloric food by her other half. But ft in Alison, of Dreghorn, near Irvine, Scotland, made a dramatic breakthrough in January  when she joined WW and lost st lb, saying: ‚ÄúI was determined to lose weight and keep it off this time. I was fed up being the fat mum, fat we and fat friend and wanted to make myself feel better. ‚ÄúDue to my MS, I was struggling with a lot of basic everyday tasks, so losing weight was one way I knew I could help myself.But, because of my health and being unable to do strenuous exercise, most of my weight loss had to be down to what I ate.‚ÄùAllison, whose illness means she cannot work, had a body mass index , used to gauge a healthy weight, of ., compared to the NHS healthy range of . to . when she signed up to the slimming club, making her obese.Now a healthy st lb, with a BMI of . and a slim size  , she was delighted when in August , Alasdair decided to join her and lost st in just six months. Recalling how she had issues with her weight even as a little girl, Allison said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve always been big. Always the tallest and fattest right through school. ‚ÄúMy mum would take me to slimming classes even when I was a teenager. I was so embarrassed and never really stuck to the plan.  ‚ÄúOver the years I‚Äôve probably been to every slimming club there is. I‚Äôve always lost a bit of weight then went straight back again to my normal eating habits and put it all back on.‚Äù When she finally joined WW, she had hit rock bottom with her weight, saying it was really influencing her moods and damaging her self-confidence. Also, while there were days when she felt fit and healthy, on others her MS meant she could not get out of bed and being big only increased her battered self esteem and poor body image, which made feeling fat even harder to bear. She explained: ‚ÄúI realised thatI carried on going the way I was that I‚Äôd have a heart attack and never see our wee boy grow up. I just wanted to be healthier.‚Äù Allison threw herself into the plan, buying books with new healthy recipes and cooking herself meals from scratch full of vegetables. While her weight loss was slow, because she could not combine diet with rigorous exercise because of her MS, she never once gained weight in more than three years on the plan. With Alasdair constantly trying to tempt her back to bad eating habits, she says this was a miracle. She laughed: I was cooking two or three dferent dinners every night. I‚Äôd make mine and Alasdair would say, ‚ÄòIs that all you‚Äôre having  I don‚Äôt want that.‚Äô Or he‚Äôd try to twist my arm for a takeaway!‚Äù  She was delighted when he decided to join her on the diet in August  ‚Äì not least because it meant cooking just one meal a night. She said: ‚ÄúThe stuff we were eating, the junk food, made us feel so run down. We‚Äôre a lot happier and fitter now and it‚Äôs fantastic for Jacob as well. ‚ÄúHe keeps saying, ‚ÄòLook how skinny you are!‚Äô ‚ÄúI‚Äôd just like to say to anybody thatwe can do it, they can. Evenyou‚Äôre disabled, please don‚Äôt think you can‚Äôt.‚Äù Inspired by his we‚Äôs success and following an embarrassing incident at a funfair, Alasdair joined WW last summer. He said: ‚ÄúLast summer I was at the fair with Jacob and got marched off a ride for being too big. It was so embarrassing. ‚ÄúExactly a week later, I joined Allison at my first WW meeting. I decided something had to change.‚Äù Despite being stick thin as a young man, by the time he joined WW, years of unhealthy eating, washed down with calorie-laden booze, had taken its toll on Alasdair, who wore a in waist size and whose BMI was ., making him obese. He said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôd seen how well Allison had done, but I was still a bit apprehensive about going on a diet at first, as I thought I would struggle cutting my portion sizes down, stopping drinking and all that.‚Äù But, losing a whopping .lb in his first week spurred Alasdair on to keep it up. And soon he was even sitting through meetings on topics such as eating more throughout your period. Sticking with the plan, he cut out alcohol, fizzy drinks, takeaways and started the couch to k app. With husband and we both using the WW app to track and scan their foods, they now enjoy a breakfast of porridge or muesli, lunches of homemade soups and salads and dinners of pasta or risotto cooked from scratch. Alasdair, now a in waist, runs k three times a week and has taken up cycling. In just  weeks, he reached his goal weight of st lb, making his BMI a healthy .. Between them the couple have lost an astonishing st lb and are both maintaining their weight, while still attending weekly WW meetings. Alasdair thanks his we for his success, saying: ‚ÄúWithout Allison, I absolutely could not have done it. I‚Äôd have given up. She was the one who showed me the ins and outs and reassured me. She was always there to remind me how much I had to lose when I wanted to give in.‚Äù Their diet before Breakfast ‚Äì Cooked breakfast, cereal or filled rolls Lunch ‚Äì Toastie Dinner ‚Äì Takeaway or homemade meal such as donner pizza and cheesy chips with curry Snacks ‚Äì Crisps Diet now Breakfast ‚Äì Porridge or muesli or brown toast Lunch ‚Äì Homemade soups or salads, fruit and a yoghurt Dinner ‚Äì Sausage bake, port tagliatelle or risotto. All homemade. title: grandma takes toyboy lovers virginity
story: Grandma takes toyboy lovers virginity despite -year age gap - our sex le is greatQuran McCain, , claims he lost his virginity to we Cheryl, , after they met in  - and despite the -year age gap between them, he says he has no regrets about their relationshipQuran and Cheryl have been together since ByBeth UreJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Apr |commentsA man who claims heaposs in love with a grandmother  years older than him says they are very happy and have a great sex le. Quran McCain, , is married to Cheryl, , after the pair first met and began dating in  - and according to Quran, he even lost his virginity to her. The loved-up toyboy said: When it comes to only being with one person, I donapost see that as a problem. Personally, I donapost think sex is something you should share with just anybody, no disrespect to people who do but thataposs not for me. I think thataposs itaposs a sacred ritual, and it should be shared with someone special. He added grandmother-of- Cheryl is freaky and has taught him a lot about sex and being open to new things. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here I feel like Iaposve had a lot of experience, evenit is just with one person, he said. Quran says Cheryl is his second romantic partner after a brief relationship when he was a teenager, but added his first girlfriend refused to take his virginity. After that I didnapost really see anybody or talk to anybody until Cheryl, honestly no one was really interested in me until she was, he said. He added he has no issues with Cheryl being the only person heaposs ever had sex with. He said: Le is short, so I donapost think you should waste time trying to have experiences when youaposve met the person you love. I feel like I have enough experience to know what I want, and I think thataposs a really big misconception that people have. People think you have to experience the world and have all these learning experiences. I donapost have any regrets about the decisions that I have made - I put my all into this relationship! As their relationship blossoms, the pair are keen to have children and have been looking into options like surrogacy and adoption. Quran said: We were initially hoping to conceive naturally, but due to age that isnapost likely. We know it might be a bit unconventional, because Cheryl might not be around for as long as I am, but she trusts that Iaposll be a great father. news uk-news archies-surname-caused-huge-rt-"Meghan Markle says Archie ‚Äòloves being a big brother‚Äô in ByZoe ForseyFeatures Editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsBeing a senior member of the royal family means you get all sorts of fancy titles, including HRH, dukedoms and honorary ranks. But the Queenaposs relatives who are further down the line of succession donapost have this privilege, which means they have to use a normal surname like the rest of us. So while Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis use their parentsapos aposCambridgeapos title as their surname at school, their cousins Archie and Lilibet use the royal familyaposs aposofficialapos last name - Mountbatten-Windsor. The moniker combines the royal name, Windsor, with Prince Philipaposs surname, Mountbatten. However the name caused a massive row in the royal family and was even raised in the Houses of Parliament, resulting in a rt between the Queen and her husband.  It didnapost appear on an official document until , but the complicated story behind the name dates all the way back to .Before marrying The Queen and becoming the Duke of Edinburgh, Philipaposs official title was Prince Philip of Greece and Denmark of the House of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Gl√ºcksburg.However, his name wasnapost considered to be neutral enough so he adopted the name Mountbatten after his grandparents. When the then Princess Elizabeth had the coupleaposs first child, Prince Charles, in , he assumed, due to tradition, that their little one would take his name.  However, when Elizabeth went on to become Queen in , she had to confirm the official surname of the Royal Family and many wanted her to continue using Windsor, instead of changing it to Mountbatten. Winston Churchill is said to have been an advocate for the Royals using the name Windsor and The Queenaposs grandmother, Queen Mary, agreed.Do you enjoy reading about the royal family for all the best royal news from the Mirror here. It is said to have caused such an issue that the matter was even discussed in Parliament. In the end, the Queen decided to support her familyaposs views and the name Windsor was used.At the time, Philip reportedly said: I am nothing but a bloody amoeba. I am the only man in the country not allowed to give his name to his own children.The topic continued to bother him for years to come, but it wasnapost until  that Elizabeth decided to do something more about it. When the couple fell pregnant with their third child, Elizabeth was Queen and Philip was still keen for his children to have his surname. So in , Her Majesty is said to have gone to see Harold Macmillan, who had then taken over as PM. She said she absolutely needed to revisit the issue and admitted it had been irritating her husband since . Finally, a comprise was met, and on February ,  -  days before Prince Andrew was born - the Queen declared that she had adopted the name Mountbatten-Windsor. She announced that it would be used by all her descendants who do not enjoy the title of His or Her Royal Highness. And as we have seen, itaposs still used today. A statement on the Royal website explains: The Royal Family name of Windsor was confirmed by The Queen after her accession in . However, in , The Queen and The Duke of Edinburgh decided that they would like their own direct descendants to be distinguished from the rest of the Royal Family , as Windsor is the surname used by all the male and unmarried female descendants of George V. It was therefore declared in the Privy Council that The Queenaposs descendants, other than those with the style of Royal Highness and the title of Prince Princess, or female descendants who marry, would carry the name of Mountbatten-Windsor. title: couple pick one bed flat
story: Couple pick one-bed flat on housing estate over large country home with swimming poolMiranda Quigley, , and her husband moved into a one-bed one-bathroom flat in the Barbican in September, leaving behind their Hertfordshire family home - which boasts stunning features including a swimming pool and massive gardenMiranda Quigley said moving from the countryside to the Barbican is a dream come true Image: Facundo ArrizabalagaByHannah NearyRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Apr |comments A couple traded in their countryside house complete with swimming pool and garden for a one-bed flat on a London estate. The Barbican Estate was hailed a city within a city when it first opened its doors to residents in . The site was branded as a utopia for hard-working, middle-class Londoners, with everything they could possibly need - a cinema, tennis courts, an arts centre, bars and schools, MyLondon reports.The Grade II-listed development, which sits across -acres of ground in the City of London, was designed by architects Chamberlin, Powell, and Bon. It was built by the City of London Corporation to get people to live in the financial district after it was obliterated during the Blitz. Today, around , people call the estate their home in over , apartments. The site is still run by the City of London but the vast majority of the flats are privately owned.Average property prices at the Barbican recently reached an eye-watering ¬£million in  - a massive  per cent higher than . Miranda Quigley, , moved to the Barbican with her husband in September. They left their family home in Hertfordshire with a swimming pool and garden in search of a new way of le after their children moved out. The couple now live in a one-bed, one-bathroom flat with views of the London Eye. She said: We had an opportunity to change our lives and we did what most people don‚Äôt do - we moved into Central London. It‚Äôs an iconic part of London. I can remember coming here as a child. It had just opened and I remember thinking. ‚ÄòI‚Äôd like to live there one day‚Äô. I feel really excited that this dream has come true. While the flats are often small and expensive, Miranda said residents are well-looked after and there is a strong strong sense of community, which can be hard to find in London. She added: We didn‚Äôt even look at the Barbican at first because we thought it was expensive. But our estate agent suggested we come and look here. Prices had dropped quite a bit because of the pandemic.  Within  seconds we thought, ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs perfect‚Äô. It isn‚Äôt what we were looking for - we wanted two beds and two bathrooms but it‚Äôs light, it‚Äôs bright, it‚Äôs a bit quirky. The service charges are really high everywhere in the City - like ¬£, to ¬£,. Here we pay ¬£, a year but it feels like you‚Äôre getting something that‚Äôs worth paying for as all the maintenance is done really well. The listed status of the estate also makes it hard for residents to alter their flats. For example, wooden floors are banned because they make too much noise. Miranda said: There are some weird, quirky things. With it being such a huge entity, making change happen is quite dficult. If we wanted to put another toilet in here it would be virtually impossible. Resident Adam Hogg, , bought a flat at the Barbican five years ago. He added: We are right in the middle of London - you couldn‚Äôt be more central with public transport. I walk about the place at night just thinking how nice it is to be here. It‚Äôs absolutely lovely. I have come here to die. I have no intention of going anywhere . The former brewer and factory manager is a huge fan of the brutalist design of the estate and his uncle, also architect, was close friends with Chamberlin, Powell and Bon. He said: The flats are terric. There‚Äôs the architecture which is Marmite - you either love it or you don‚Äôt. I have always been brought up in modern houses.There are lots of architects, lawyers, professional people living here and people who make films. It‚Äôs a middle-class ghetto. It‚Äôs a lovely place to live and we have benevolent landlords in many ways. There are people who came here when it was built. Both Miranda and Adam said the City looks after them well but it could be more environmentally-friendly. The whole estate still has old, underfloor heating that is controlled by one provider and cannot be turned off. Miranda said: Sometimes we open the door because it‚Äôs so hot and we are trying to improve our carbon footprint and it‚Äôs a bit insane. Sometimes it feels criminal to let the heat out especially with what‚Äôs going on. Resident Fred Rodgers, , also said the design of the buildings can be a pain. He added: The underfloor heating charges are constantly rising because of electricity costs rising but there‚Äôs very little that can be done about it. But like the others, he said he loves the way of le at the Barbican, where he has lived with his we since . He added: We lived in a small basement flat in Marylebone and decided we wanted to move where there was light and the Barbican with its massive windows offers a massive amount of light. It has so many attractions. We can walk down to the cinema in slippers and our dressing gowns basically. We have got everything we could want. We are very well looked after and we are very privileged. Adam, also chair of the Barbican Association, which represent the thousands of people living on the estate, said living at the world-renowned site means lots of people are drawn to it, like noisy skateboarders who sometimes shout at them to get out the way. But he is less bothered by the endless stream of influencers having photoshoots outside their homes because it adds to the charm. Adam is also worried about the future of the arts centre, which is poised for a ¬£ million revamp and the Museum of London, designed by his uncle, which is being moved to a new home. Like many residents, Adam hopes the City will preserve both the buildings at least on the outside. A City of London Corporation spokesperson said: ‚ÄúThe Barbican Estate is home to thousands of residents who enjoy living in this iconic area of the Square Mile, and within walking distance of one of the largest multi-arts and learning institutions of its kind, the Barbican Centre. Residents who have any concerns about their living standards and accommodation are always encouraged to contact the Barbican Estate Office, which can offer them information and guidance on a wide range of issues. ‚ÄúAny changes to the Barbican Centre made as part of the upcoming Renewal Project will respect the building‚Äôs Grade II-listed and be developed in line with listed building planning regulations. ‚ÄúThe views and ideas of the local community and other groups are - and will continue to be - important to us, because they help ensure that the Barbican Renewal Project meet the needs and demands of modern audiences. As the development proposals evolve, residents and other interested groups will be engaged and consulted with.‚Äù Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON HousingCity of London CouncilCity Estate" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: covid measures should come back
story: NHS bosses call for new Covid restrictions as UK faces "brutal" Easter with virusThe NHS Confederation called for mitigating actions to stop the spread of Covid such as not meeting people indoors and wearing masks in crowded spacesPublic transport users in London are no longer be required to wear face masks Image: Victoria Jones PA WireByTom DavidsonAssistant news editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsCovid measures should be reintroduced in the UK to slow down the spread of the virus, health chiefs have warned.The NHS Confederation has accused the Government of aposabandoning any interest in Covid whatsoeverapos and says hospitals are set to deal with a aposbrutal Easter as bad as any winterapos.Last week Covid cases hit the highest since February  at , infections. That is despite official tallies having plunged because of Noaposs decision to axe the ¬£billion-a-month mass-swabbing regime.The so-called coronavirus dashboard shows casesdecreasing however hospitalisations and deaths are still rising though both statistics usually lag behind infections.It is estimated a record one in  people have coronavirus in England. The NHS Confederation, which acts as a representative for hospitals and ambulance trusts, called for aposmitigating actionsapos such as not meeting people indoors and wearing masks in crowded spaces.This would help prevent the spread of the virus, the health and wellbeing organisation told The Times.It also said the Government needs to introduce a apospublic information campaignapos in England to ask people to stay away from AE unless they have an emergency. Already overcrowded AE rooms are suffering from staff shortages as three per cent of staff in the NHS have coronavirus. Confederation boss Matthew Taylor said: NHS leaders report a clear disconnect between the Governmentaposs Living with Covid plan and the realities at the NHS front line. We have a Government that seems to want to wash its hands of responsibility for what is occurring in plain sight up and down the country. No  has seemingly abandoned any interest in Covid whatsoever.Last week Boris Johnson, speaking to GB News, admitted he aposcanapost rule outapos plunging the UK into a Covid lockdown again in the future, despite only just releasing the nation from two years of crippling on-off restrictions. The Prime Ministerpreviously promised the route back to normality was aposirreversibleapos, seemingly consigning draconian stay-at-home orders to history.But the PM has now said it would be aposirresponsibleapos for the Government not to keep a blanket shutdown in its virus-fighting playbook. He added: aposIaposm not going to take any options off the table.apos Mr Johnson added: I want to avoid any such thing ever happening again.
