title: devastated mum pays tribute baby
story: Devastated mum pays tribute to baby girl who defied medics by living for nine monthsNancy Jo Anne Rogers was born with Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome which is a condition which affects multiple body systems, including the internal organs, growth and intellectual developmentLisa said Nancy developed her own little character and was always laughing despite her rare condition Image: HandoutByPoppy Kennedy:,  Apr  A heartbroken mum is paying tribute to her ‚Äúperfect‚Äù baby daughter who defied medics by living for nine months after being diagnosed with a rare genetic condition.Nancy Jo Anne Rogers was born with Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome - a condition which affects multiple body systems, including the internal organs, growth and intellectual development, facial features, fingers and toes.Nancy defied medics‚Äô expectations time and time again, going on to live for months after her parents were told she wouldnapost be here in  hours,Teesside Live reports.Her mum Lisa Rogers, from Thornaby, is telling her daughteraposs story to raise awareness of the rare genetic condition. She had a perfect le. We were told she would never smile or get head support and that she would never sit on her own ‚Äì she managed all those things,‚Äù Lisa said.  ‚ÄúShe laughed constantly, she started waving and smiling. She developed her own little character. ‚ÄúAll the things we thought she would never do, she did. And more. For a baby that was so poorly, she accomplished more in her nine months of le than most of us do in a year.‚ÄùAfter a normal pregnancy, Lisa was concerned about her babyaposs movements and made her way to the University Hospital of North Tees in September  - when days later she was induced. On Friday, September , the health care assistant welcomed her daughter into the world via caesarean section.But it was only upon Nancy‚Äôs arrival that she and her midwery team recognised something was out of the ordinary. Nancy was taken straight to the special care baby unit which cares for premature or seriously ill newborns.  Lisa, , said: ‚ÄúWhen she was born, she didn‚Äôt cry. She had dficulty breathing ‚Äì she had a wheeze. The only thing I remember saying was that she only had four fingers ‚Äì she didn‚Äôt have her little finger on her left hand.‚Äù Medics found that Nancy had problems with her heart and kidneys, slanted eyes, webbed toes, a missing finger and she could not suck or swallow. The newborn was transferred from the University Hospital of North Tees to the paediatric intensive care unit at the Freeman Hospital. Lisa continued: ‚ÄúTwo days after giving birth by C-section, I was travelling to Newcastle. I needed time to heal but Nancy came first. I was allowed to change her and hold her but she was so poorly. A doctor there asked meI understood how poorly she was. ‚ÄúHe told me to take her home to meet her family because she won‚Äôt be here in  hours. They‚Äôd done all they could and we just had to wait and see now.‚Äù But three weeks later, on October , , Nancy came home. The following month, she was diagnosed with Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome . Symptoms of SLOS dfer from person to person. Some people may have more symptoms than others and symptoms can range from mild to severe. Those with the syndrome also have abnormally low levels of cholesterol in their blood. Lisa knows of only two other iniduals in the North East with this condition ‚Äì one of whom sadly died.Despite being given just  hours to live, Nancy defied doctors‚Äô expectations, continuing to grow and develop. Although she remained under the care of several hospitals and specialists across the North East, Nancy lived a full le, Lisa said.She enjoyed her first Christmas at home, went on three holidays and laughed as she spent time in the water. But on July , , Nancy was taken to the University Hospital of North Tees by ambulance where she received treatment after Lisa noticed she was struggling to breathe.She sadly died on the children‚Äôs ward two days later of heart failure and sepsis.Lisa continued: ‚ÄúI was sat with her the whole time and one minute she was quiet and not moving much, then a few hours later she was lively and kicking her legs, playing. I was holding her in my arms and when I thought she‚Äôd gone to sleep, I put her back to bed and put her oxygen mask back on her and she just flopped to one side and was gone. She‚Äôd died in my arms. Doctors and nurses worked on her for  minutes. But she was ready to go ‚Äì she was tired and she‚Äôd had enough. We say now that she didn‚Äôt want me to have to make that decision to give her open heart surgery which only has a % survival rate. ‚ÄúNancy made her own decision.‚Äù Since Nancy‚Äôs passing in July last year, Lisa and her family have dedicated themselves to raising awareness of SLOS and raising money for the organisations who helped Nancy. She has raised and donated money, along with blankets and clothing, to the special care baby unit at the University Hospital of North Tees. Lisa said: ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt describe how thankful I am to everyone in the special care baby unit at North Tees - to Zoe Kitching and Jayne Jobling especially.‚ÄúJayne came to Nancy‚Äôs funeral and continues to be a great support to me, as are a lot of other nurses. Nancy simply wouldn‚Äôt have had her nine and a half months without the NHS.‚ÄùRead MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Childrens HospitalBabies" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: ditching big brands supermarket brand
story: Blind tests of big brands v supermarket own-label products show one clear winnerShopper taste tests undertaken by researchers reveal that store brands are not only cheaper, but often are preferable when it comes to tasteDitching big brands for supermarket own-label products could save shoppers hundreds of pounds a year Image: Getty Images Image SourceByGraham HiscottHead of Business:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments Cost of living hit shoppers could save hundreds of pounds a year by ditching big brands such as Heinz and Kelloggs and switching to supermarket own-label products, consumer group Which  found.Researchers carrying blind taste tests concluded that supermarket own-brands are often not only cheaper when it comes to everyday essentials, but sometimes taste better. Examples include baked beans where, Which  says, shoppers could knock over ¬£ off their shopping bill. Budget chain Lidl‚Äôs Newgate baked beans - p for g, p per g - were ranked the best value option.They cost less than half the price of Heinz beans, that Which  found cost ¬£ for g tin. The savings are even greater for orange juice, at almost ¬£ a year. Aldi was rated the cheapest with its The Juice Company Smooth Orange Juice costing ¬£. per . litre carton - or p per ml.  In contrast, Innocent orange juice was the priciest option at ¬£. for . litres, or p per ml, and came last for taste. A third product tested was peanut butter, although the saving from switching from a bigger brand was a lot less, at ¬£. a year. Testers compared popular peanut butter brands WholeEarth, Sun-Pat, and KP against own-labels from supermarkets. Lidl‚Äôs Mister Choc Crunchy Peanut Butter was found to be the best value pick, costing p for g - p per g. At the other end of the scale was Sun-Pat, costing ¬£. per g jar - or p per g. Other supermarket own-brand products were ranked better on taste. Big brand spread Marmite cost ¬£. per g jar - ¬£ per g - said Which   Yet Aldi‚Äôs Grandessa Mighty Yeast Extract was not only ranked top for taste but also costs ¬£. per g jar - p per g. It comes as figures last week found shoppers are ditching big brand groceries for supermarket own-label ranges to save money amid the cost of living squeeze. A report from number crunchers NinIQ showed sales of branded grocery products fell by .% in the four weeks to March . Sales of own-label products were down less, at .%, while demand packaged ‚Äúprivate label‚Äù ranged increased by .%. It meant the own-label products shares of all sales rose from .% a year ago to .% now. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Natalie Hitchins, head of home products and services at Which , said: ‚ÄúNo one wants to overpay for basic groceries, especially when the cost of living crisis is putting huge pressure on household budgets. ‚ÄúShopping around and buying own-brand products is an easy way to save hundreds of pounds a year. ‚ÄúThose prepared to switch to a cheaper supermarket for their regular shop will likely find some great value alternatives to their favourite brands - with many even beating their well-known rivals for taste in Which ‚Äôs tests.‚Äù Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Cost of Living: Were Here to HelpSupermarketsSave money" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our money-saving tips and top offers direct to your inbox with the Mirror Money newsletterInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: exact date brits can expect
story: April heatwave: Exact date Brits can expect  days of sun in time for Easter weekendBrits are being encouraged to break out the sunscreen as another mini heatwave is set to boost temperatures over the coming days after a disappointing start to April so farMuch of the UK can look forward to rising temperatures in the run-up to the bank holiday weekend, forecasters have said Image: PAByNathan RaoJoe Smith:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments Spring is set to make awith temperatures due to touch C in the run up to the bank holiday, forecasters have said. Britains are being encouraged to break out the sunscreen as another mini heatwave is set to boost temperatures over the coming days, following the hot weather earlier in March.Over the next  days the weather is set to get warmer and more stable as high pressure builds pulling air in from the Atlantic.James Madden, forecaster for Exacta Weather, told the Express : ‚ÄúAfter the weekend we expect to see more in the way of high pressure building over the UK.‚ÄúThis could bring temperatures back up to something like we saw at the end of March.  ‚ÄúIt will also turn more settled, again as we see high pressure taking more of a dominant effect over the weather.‚Äù But a risk of spring showers remains, with the possibility of downpours on Monday and Friday for much of the UK, despite rising temperatures. The start of the week will mark the end of the colder weather seen over the past week in parts of the country. Parts of Scotland and Northern Britain will be slower to catch up with the rising temperatures, with the possibility of frosts and wintry downpours remaining during the start of this week. Rain is also predicted early in the week for northern and western regions as low pressure moves in from the Atlantic.  However for many, Monday will see temperatures raising as the sun breaks through for the run up to the bank holiday. Met Office meteorologist Aidan McGivern said warmer weather is on the way for the start of the week.‚ÄúWith a southerly air flow, it is certainly going to feel warmer,we get some brightness in the southeast, temperatures could top out at C, mid-teens where,‚Äù he predicted. ‚ÄúFor the next  days, the general trend is for it to turn warmer with higher pressure increasingly through next week and into the following next week.‚Äù  Britons could be in for a barbecue Easter weekend with highs of C possible next weekend, according to some forecasters. High pressure will build keeping chilly northerly winds out and allowing warm gusts in from the south. Jim Dale, meteorologist for British Weather Services, said: ‚ÄúIt is going to warm up from where we are at the moment. ‚ÄúNext week we could see temperatures in the high teens, and I would not be surprisedby Easter weekend we saw C. ‚ÄúIt is fair to say that the week to come is not going to be a bad one.‚Äù  Balmy forecasts have prompted books to slash the odds on an Easter scorcher with Ladbrokes offering - on an Easter sizzler. Spokesman Alex Apati said: At last it looks as though Brits will have something to smile about on the weather front, with a record-breaking Easter scorcher potentially on the cards. However, allergy sufferers should watch out for rising tree pollen levels as experts sound the hay-fever alarm. Airbourne allergens expert Max Wiseberg said: ‚ÄúHigh pollen counts are forecast across the south and east of England on Monday. ‚ÄúTree pollen could be released earlier than usual and in a shorter space of time leading to a more severe tree-pollen season. ‚ÄúPeople with allergies should prepare a hay-fever kit to suit their needs which may contain antihistamines and a nasal balm.‚Äù Met Office meteorologist Dan Stroud said: ‚ÄúThe mild theme is going to persist for a good part of next week. ‚ÄúThe wind direction goes into reverse after the weekend bringing milder temperatures. ‚ÄúThis is down to tropical maritime air from the southwest which could also bring some cloud and rain. ‚ÄúBut, through the start of the week it is going to feel very pleasant, and we expect mild conditions to hold out for a good chunk of the week.‚Äù Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON WeatherHolidaysHeatwave" data-immediate"data-immediate"Fancy an escape to the Chill newsletter for weekly inspiration and advice on UK holidays Sign Up!Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: familys anguish after dad seven
story: Familys anguish after dad-of-seven buried in the wrong grave away from family plotClive Stephensons loved ones say they were assured his plot would be next to his mother‚Äôs in Handsworth Cemetery, yet he has been buried on the very edge of the vast Birmingham burial groundClive Stephenson‚Äôs family have hit out after he was buried in the wrong grave Image: BPM MEDIAByMike Lockley:,  Apr |commentsThe bereaved family of a dad-of-seven who died aged  have demanded an apology after he was buried in the wrong grave. Clive Stephensonaposs loved ones say they were assured his plot would be next to his mother‚Äôs in Handsworth Cemetery, yet he has been buried on the very edge of the vast Birmingham burial ground.His sisters, Vivienne and Jean Honeyghan, say mourners were unaware of the change until Clive was placed in the ground on the day of his funeral. Then, it was too late to protest, Birmingham Live reports.Vivienne said: They could not have placed my brother farther from my motherthey tried. They‚Äôve made him look like the black sheep of the family. To add to their anguish, father-of-seven Clive was placed in a plot so sodden, it was filling with water as the coffin was lowered into it, they say Birmingham City Council has met the family on-site in a bid to resolve the issue. They have offered to exhume the body, at their own cost, and place it in the grave of another sister, Ionia Stephenson, who died only months after Clive, a painter and decorator from Northfield.  The local authority has told them it cannot put Clive, one of nine siblings, close to his mother Rita‚Äôs -year-old grave because that section of the cemetery is no longer used for burials. But support worker Vivienne - a cousin of former boxing world champ Lloyd Honeyghan - alleges graves have been placed in the area since her brother‚Äôs funeral. Things have moved on since Clive‚Äôs death, from a brain tumour, in February . The grandmother of his three youngest children died and was buried close to him. For those children‚Äôs sake, the family no longer want his body exhumed. They want the council to pay for a memorial stone on Clive‚Äôs grave - as an acknowledgement of mistakes made - and say sorry. They are being supported by Bishop Desmond Jaddoo who conducted the funeral service at Handsworth‚Äôs New Le Wesleyan Church in March . For the bishop, the campaign is particularly poignant. Clive died in his arms after the cleric delivered the last rites. The dying man told Desmond in those final hours he wanted to be buried near his mother.  The bishop has dubbed the council‚Äôs handling of the matter ‚Äúshoddy‚Äù and ‚Äúarrogant‚Äù. He says the authority is no longer communicating with him or the family. Vivienne says she was too numbed by grief on the day of the funeral to fully comprehend her brother was being buried in the wrong plot. She said: ‚ÄúClive‚Äôs last wish was to be buried near his mother and that was agreed. That was the plan. On the day of the funeral, it didn‚Äôt sink in, but I know now. I know one of my brothers asked, ‚Äòwhy are we stopping here ‚Äô On the day, grief does take over your mind, grief does blind you. ‚ÄúIf I‚Äôd known, then and there, it was the wrong place I would‚Äôve stopped it in a split second. A lot of the family were totally distraught, but, at the time, what can you do  ‚ÄúOn the same day, I contacted the undertaker and said, ‚Äòthis is not what was agreed‚Äô. I was given an assurance they would look into it and, to use their words, ‚Äòheads would roll‚Äô.‚Äù Vivienne has claimed she later learned a decision was made on the day of the funeral to change plots: the one where Clive was intended to be interred had become badly waterlogged. Yet he was placed in a pool of a grave. Even the bishop askedanything could be done to stop the water pouring in,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe paid so much money for that grave. We are a close family. He is miles from the rest of his family. His last wish has not been realised. The council messed up. We want them to take responsibility, we want an apology stating they have done this.‚Äù Those sentiments are echoed by sister Jean. The -year-old, from Handsworth, said: ‚ÄúI think this has been handled terribly. Now, the council don‚Äôt respond to our requests, they just blank us. ‚ÄúI was too distraught on the day to notice what was going on, I just assumed it was the right spot. I had to be led away because I was so distressed I was passing out. We are not asking for money, we just want it sorted. Our brother is not in the right place. I‚Äôm so emotional about it, it has broken me down.‚Äù Bishop Jaddoo is currently attempting to broker a solution. He told the Sunday Mercury: ‚ÄúI think the family have been treated shoddily, at no point were they told the grave was going to be moved. ‚ÄúThings have moved on. They no longer want their brother moved, they don‚Äôt want to go through the trauma again. His final wish was to be buried as close as possible to his mother. They buried him on the edge of Handsworth Cemetery, it could not be farther from his mother‚Äôs grave. ‚ÄúBirmingham City Council has failed to consult with the family, which shows arrogance by the council.‚Äù A spokesman for the local authority told the Sunday Mercury: ‚ÄúUnfortunately, the request for the late Mr Stephenson to be buried as close to his mother‚Äôs grave as possible was not passed onto Handsworth Cemetery prior to the funeral. However, any request to locate a grave in a specic area cannot be guaranteed due to the uncertainty of ground conditions, and the paperwork which the family of the late Mr Stephenson signed, makes this clear. news uk-news gran--makes-priceless-discovery-"Iris Jones and age-gap lover Mohamed speak on This Morning in BySaffron OtterRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments A loved-up pensioner says sheaposs made a priceless discovery about her Egyptian toyboy lover after the couple were forced to spend time apart. Iris Jones, , fell for Mohamed Ahmed Ibriham, , three years ago in  despite their massive -year age gap.The loved-struck couple married a year later in  but have had to spend time apart the past month after Mohamedaposs father fell ill and he rushed back to Cairo to visit him.But their month spent thousands of miles apart has lead Iris to a major revelation, and has helped her realise what a priceless gem her hubby is, Manchester Evening News reports.  Iris welcomed him home last weekend, then reflected on how lucky she is to have him on Facebook.The British grandma, from Somerset, was swept off her feet when she met Mohamed in  through a Facebook page for atheists. They tried to get married in Cairo just four days after they first met in person, but they didnapost have the right paperwork. They were eventually able to wed a year later, and he was able to move in with her shortly afterwards when he was granted a three-year visa. Iris wrote on Sunday: Love is knowing you look like s**t after a days housework and gardening, without a scrap of make up on dressed in my scruff! After a monthaposs absence, my wonderful husband will welcome me just the way I am, because thataposs what love is all about.Welcome home, Mohamed. Missing you this past month has made me realise what a priceless gem you are. This rough diamond of a we will be more appreciative of you in the future. In an earlier Facebook post, Iris uploaded a photo of a suitcase, and explained in the comments: My husband had to make an emergency dash to Egypt as his father was ill. The update comes after the pensioner made headlines in January  by sharing intimate details of their sex le.Speaking on ITVaposs This Morning, she had hosts Philip Schofield and Holly Willoughby blushing. Describing their first night of passion, Iris said: ‚ÄúPretty rough. Nobody had been near me for  years. I thought I was a virgin again.‚ÄúCan I say we used a whole tube of KY Jelly  I couldn‚Äôt walk the next day. I felt asI had been riding a horse. Saddle sore wasn‚Äôt in it. Anyway we got over that.‚Äù  The pairaposs romance caused a rt in Irisapos family, with her previously opening up about how her two sons, both in their mid-s, had struggled to come to terms with their mumaposs relationship with a man  years her junior.Speaking with the Sunday Mirror back in , she said: Darren [one of her sons] is worried Mohamed is just after my money and we had a big row which resulted in me asking him to leave the house.We have made up since, but I‚Äôve asked him not to talk about it ‚Äì I don‚Äôt want to argue. Her other son Steve, , was aposa bit wary,apos according to Iris, but said she thinks he will eventually accept Mohamed as his dad.‚ÄúIf he‚Äôs marrying me for my fortune he‚Äôll be sadly disappointed because I live on a pension, she said to those who questioned why Mohamed was with her. I don‚Äôt suffer fools gladly. I‚Äôm honest and I‚Äôm truthful and I told him straight away he couldn‚Äôt be a freeloader. ‚ÄúIn Egypt we were quite frivolous, going out to the best restaurants all the time and we split everything  . She said Mohamed had agreed to sign a pre-nup to prove his love for her. It‚Äôs me he wants ‚Äì not my house, she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve spent years making other people happy, now I just want to marry the man I love before I die. news uk-news kate-middletons-shock-history-grand-"The Grand National: The shock winnersByZoe ForseyFeatures Editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments When Sam Waley-Cohen crossed the finish line at this yearaposs Grand National on his horse Noble Yeates, he would have had a team of royal supporters celebrating his victory.The -year-old jockey is good pals with The Firm thanks to his surprising friendship with the Duchess of Cambridge, and heaposs even been credited with getting her back together with Prince William after they split early in their relationship. Heaposs been spotted out and about with Kate on several occasions, and photographed with her in fancy dress at a rollerskating party before she married into the royal family. Sam was a guest at Kate and Williamaposs royal wedding, and the Duchess and sister Pippa were in the congregation for his nuptials to Bella Ballin. After his victory at Aintree, the Cambridges took to social media to congratulate their pal on his win.  We take a look at Kate and Samaposs unexpected relationship over the years. Tragic loss Kate and Sam became pals under tragic circumstances, as the Duchess was originally friends with the jockeyaposs younger brother Thomas. Thomas died in , just days after his th birthday. He was diagnosed with the bone cancer Ewing‚Äôs sarcoma in . Sam focused racing while dealing with the loss of his brother and was quick to reference him following his Grand National success, revealing that his initials were on his saddle. After Thomasaposs death, Kate organised a charity roller disco in London to raise money for a paediatric surgery ward named after him.Sheaposs pictured at the event wearing yellow hot pants and a green sequin top, while Sam wore a bright pink blazer with an orange top. Royal matchmakingAfter meeting at university and falling in love, Kate and Wills split in . The couple discussed the brief breakup during their engagement interview.Kate admitted: At the time, I wasn‚Äôt very happy about it, but it made me a stronger person. You find out things about yourself that maybe you hadn‚Äôt realised.I think you can get quite consumed by a relationship when you‚Äôre younger. I really valued that time for me as well, although I didn‚Äôt think it at the time. William added: We were both very young‚Ä¶ we were both finding ourselves and being d¬≠ferent characters. It was very much trying to find our own way and we were growing up, so it was just a bit of space and it worked out for the better. However before long they were back together, and Sam reportedly played a big part in their reunion. Despite awkwardness surrounding the breakup, the jockey decided to invite both of them to his aposFreakin Naughty-themed partyapos at his familyaposs Oxfordshire manson. According to MailOnline, Wills wore hot pants and a policeman helmet and Kate was dressed as a naughty nurse in fishnets. They were reportedly seen in deep conversation during the evening, and within just a few weeks they were back together. However Sam always plays down his role, saying in : There‚Äôs an idea that I was like Cupid with a bow and arrow. People love the idea that somebody put them back together, but they put themselves together far more. Days out Kate and Sam have been pictured together several times over the years, normally enjoying a day out at the races.Back in  they were seen laughing together at Cheltenham Horse Racing Festival, chatting as they looked through their race programmes. They also attended each others weddings, and were seen arriving at the ceremonies in their finest outfits. Race message Kate and Wills were clearly watching Saturdayaposs race as they were among the first to congratulate their pal on social media.Taking to Twitter, they said: Huge congratulations to @swaleycohen for winning the Grand National. What a way to retire!Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Royal FamilyKate Middleton, Duchess of CambridgeGrand National" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: manchester airport passenger arrives 13
story: Manchester Airport passenger arrives  hours early for flight after queuing chaosTim Samunyai "panicked" at chaotic scenes of long queues for security and crowded check-in halls so decided to show up for his flight to Zimbabwe more than half a day earlyTim Samunyai, from Coventry, arrived at the airport at around :am for his :pm flight yesterday Image: MEN MediaByRamazani Mwamba:,  Apr |comments A father-of-two said he arrived more than  hours early for his flight at Manchester Airport in fear of getting caught up in queuing madness.Tim Samunyai, from Coventry, arrived at the airport at around .am for his .pm flight to Zimbabwe yesterday.The -year-old says he came so early because of the recent reports of chaos which caused him to panic.Despite having to wait a very long time to board, Tim said he was glad he came early and used it as an opportunity to aposde-stressapos and prepare himself for the journey he described as a ‚Äòspiritual timeoutapos.He told the Manchester Evening News : ‚ÄúI was thinkingI come here nice and early then I won‚Äôt have to deal with all that madness over there. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt knowI was panicking because of the news just highlighting the negativity or whatever. ‚ÄúBut there was no dferentiation in the reporting, you saw queues for check-ins at TUI, EasyJet or Jet and it was choc-a-bloc. ‚ÄúMy problem was not realising that, its a panicyou‚Äôre going to Corfu, Greece or Tenere because everybody wants to go there, and it‚Äôs half-term. ‚ÄúButyou‚Äôre going Africa, then there‚Äôs no issue. This week passengers have been arriving to Manchester Airport early in a bid to tackle to the chaotic scenes of long queues for security and crowded check-in halls. Airlines and travel firms have encouraged people to arrive with plenty of time to spare.Tim said that he brought a chuckle out of a member of staff who told him he broke the record for being the person who has arrived earliest for their flight. For the long wait bought himself four books to read, as well as a tablet to keep him entertained and even had some sandwiches and pastries to keep himself fed.  He found himself a small corner at the bottom floor of terminal two where he had a nap before checking in at around .pm. He said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got some sausages rolls and I had two steak bakes. I‚Äôve got my motivational books to read and a tablet too. ‚ÄúThirteen hours is a bit much, fair enough, but I‚Äôd rather be early. title: man unable live flat 12
story: Man unable to live in flat for  years after repair which could end up costing ¬£mCouncil worker Ian Gibbon, , left his basement flat in Glasgow, Scotland, in  to allow for insurers Axa to have a minor leak repaired but  years on his home is "lying in ruins"Ian Gibbon has been unable to live in his home for  years Image: DAILY RECORDByGordon BlackstockChief Reporter with the Sunday Mail:,  Apr |comments A homeowner has been unable to live in his flat for over a decade after a minor leak repair job was botched, he claims.Ian Gibbon was forced to flee his home in Glasgow, Scotland, in  when a blocked drain led to floor and wall damage in his basement abode - valued at around ¬£,. The -year-old council worker moved into hotels and then a rental property as work was started by insurers but it stalled and the damage quickly worsened.Ian believes the bill to fix his digs in Walton Street in the cityaposs West End could now be as much as ¬£million, reports the Daily Record. He said his le has been on hold this whole time with his home, which dates back  years, lying in ruins. He explained that pouring fat down the sink had originally blocked the drains and he was told by insurers Axa to move into a hotel for six weeks.Have you had a similar issue  Let us know at webnews@mirror The firm agreed to cover the cost of the flooring repair and move Ian into a hotel in . He says they took the keys off him, then kept them until last year. ‚ÄúI had spent seven years doing it up. It was my first home and one I thought I‚Äôd probably be in forever,‚Äù continued Ian. At first he was moved into posh hotels Malmaison and Blythswood Square while work was done to patch up the damage. But with the work dragging on, insurers moved him into a flat and gave him replacement furniture when all his possessions were put in storage. And the y delays meant the water damage had spread to the walls, with builders forced to strip them as well as the floors. The repair work halted and, when it wasn‚Äôt restarted by , Ian asked the Financial Ombudsman Serviceto intervene. He said: ‚ÄúIt was incredibly frustrating. I was getting nowhere. It wasn‚Äôt just the cost of the property. All my possessions were put into storage, where they remain. I‚Äôve had to replicate my le.‚Äù  An FOS ruling found Axa had ‚Äúmistreated‚Äù Ian as well accusing Axa of treating him ‚Äúwith contempt‚Äù. Despite the damning report, Axa didn‚Äôt restart the work again until  ‚Äì after two more rulings by the FOS. By this time, the concrete foundations of the basement home had been damaged and new quotes to fix the building stretched to an incredible ¬£,. Builders put in a support frame for the walls and heating to dry out the flat but then walked away and haven‚Äôt been back. In  Ian bought another home after being out of his first for so long. Axa stopped paying his expenses in September  ‚Äì including funding for the   radiators that blast hot air into the damp home, which cost ¬£ per month and which Ian now covers. He added: ‚ÄúThey gave me my keys back last year and I couldn‚Äôt believe what it has been left like. Since they stopped paying my expenses, I have invoiced them for my costs and it now runs to over ¬£,. I‚Äôm paying the utilities, mortgages and council tax in two properties. ‚ÄúAxa said they would repair the work. I don‚Äôt want to settle. I‚Äôve not heard from them since  and even my lawyer is now being snubbed.‚Äù Axa, whose most recent offer to settle was ¬£,, said: ‚ÄúWe sympathise with Mr Gibbon‚Äôs situation. However, the majority of damage to his property was not caused by the original water leak for which he is insured. We‚Äôve offered a cash settlement and continue to communicate via his legal representative.‚Äù Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON HousingAssociation of British Insurers" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: marcus rashford launches scheme help
story: Marcus Rashford launches scheme to help youngsters be confident with their cashFootball star Marcus Rashford has launched a programme aimed at developing the financial skillset in children to ensure they have the skills to thrive as they grow upMarcus Rashford has launched a financial scheme to help young people Image: PAByStephen WhiteNews Reporter:,  Apr |commentsFootball ace Marcus Rashford has ed to his old youth club to back a scheme to help youngsters to be confident with their cash.The -year-old Manchester United player sat down with NatWest chiefs to plan the programme being trialled at three community centres this Easter ahead of a nationwide roll-out.The striker, whose school meals campaign famously delivered a government U-turn worth ¬£ million in support for disadvantaged children told NatWest chief executive Alison Rose: ‚ÄúA lot of kids are scared to go to a bank, and that‚Äôs not surprising because they don‚Äôt teach you about money mindset at school. ‚ÄúFor those who grew up in the sort of area that I did, it‚Äôs about what you don‚Äôt have, rather than what you could achieve.The positive and empowering element doesn‚Äôt register in their heads. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not hard to reverse that.‚Äù  Studies have shown that two thirds of young people worry about money but get only eight per cent of their financial education from the classroom. The Thrive scheme sees youth workers equipped to host workshops to improve the confidence of young people in dealing with their finances. Visitng the Norborok Youth Club in Wythenshawe, south Manchester, Rashford said: ‚ÄúA lot of kids are scared to go to a bank and that‚Äôs not surprising because they don‚Äôt teach you about money mindset at school. ‚ÄúFor those who grew up in the sort of area that I did, it‚Äôs about what you don‚Äôt have, rather than what you could achieve.The positive and empowering element doesn‚Äôt register in their heads. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not hard to reverse that but not many people are trying to change that. ‚ÄúI know so many talented young people who could really benefit from a program like this, who could actually propel themselves into something much bigger and achieving their goals.‚ÄùAs well as at Norbrook, the programme devised with the National Youth Agency is being piloted at St. Mary‚Äôs Youth Centre in Primrose Hill, north London and Sunderland‚Äôs Lambton Street Youth Centre. A national roll-out is scheduled for the summer. NatWest CEO Alison Rose told Rashford: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre mum‚Äôs given you the framework, so that you know what to do, which is really powerful. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre in people‚Äôs lives from the very beginning. ‚ÄúIf we can give people the tools to be economically secure and know what to do and not to see something to be frightened of, it can be empowering of their le rather than something that holds them back.‚Äù The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Rashford was last year awarded a MBE by Prince William in recognition of his campaign to support vulnerable children during the pandemic. The Manchester United forward has become a prolic anti-poverty campaigner over the last two years. He has spoken about his own experiences of using food banks and free school meals and is also involved in boosting childhood literacy. His efforts to accelerate free school meal provision in England during holidays pressured the government into major policy changes in . title: mum shares how feeds family
story: Mum shares how she feeds her family-of-four a tasty pub roast dinner for just ¬£Lucy Leeson spent just ¬£. on the Too Good To Go app on two carvery magic bags from West Bulls Pub, part of the Stonehouse pizza and carvery companyLucy Leeson fed her family-of-four a massive roast dinner for just ¬£ Image: HullLive WSByLucy LeesonRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments The cost of living crisis is beginning to bite. Food and energy bills are rising and donapost even mention childcare costs.Everyone is feeling the pinch right now and looking for ways to save money.I have to admit, I had heard of the Too Good To Go app from a very good friend, who often shared how she had picked up some amazing bargains from the likes of Starbucks, Costa and Morrisons, Hull Live reports.For those who donapost know, the app lets people buy food at a great price every day to stop delicious fresh produce from going to waste at cafes, restaurants and shops, just because it hasnapost sold in time. You donapost know what you are going to get, so it can be a gamble, but I was willing to put it to the test. I had a long day at work and missed the chance to go to the supermarket for our weekly shop as needed to get my boys from school and nursery. Instead of spending ¬£ plus on a takeaway for the four of us, and still wanting to get some nutrition, I put my faith in ordering two carvery magic bags from West Bulls pub, part of the Stonehouse pizza and carvery company.  I placed our order - which came to ¬£. in total - what a steal ! - and my husband went to collect the bags at the specied time slot we had. When he got there, all he had to do was show our order on the app and the bag was waiting for us. When he got home and we opened the bag in front of us, I was blown away by the sheer amount of food. We could easily have fed another family-of-four. We had Yorkshire puddings, mounds of mashed potato and roasties, dozens of slices of tender roast beef, lashings of gravy, four humungous sausages, stuffing balls and lots of fresh vegetables including carrots, peas, broccoli, sweetcorn and cabbage.  I plated up for four - and there were still lots left over. I wouldnapost be exaggeratingI said we could have fed two more adults and two more children. And, most importantly - the taste  It was delicious and it tasted very fresh and no dferent to asyou were eating homecooked food. My personal favourite was the roast beef and vegetables , whereas my husband and boys loved the sausages and Yorkshire puddings. I knew it was good as the boys in the family were so stuffed, they couldnapost even manage a dessert. In-fact my husband couldnapost eat anything until late afternoon the following day. I will definitely use the app againwe fancy a treat and a bargain price. I also felt good that we had stopped food going to waste. I am even thinking of going for a magic bag from Starbucks or Costa for an afternoon work pick-me up. news uk-news new-details-operation-london-bridge-"Prince Philip: Royal family pays tribute on anniversary of deathByZoe ForseyFeatures Editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsNew details about how churches across the UK will mark their respects when the Queen dies have been revealed.Operation London Bridge, the plan for the days following the Monarchaposs passing, will see the country enter a period of official mourning.Royal Household to the Central Council of Church Bell Ringers will request that religious buildings ring their bells with muffles in order to create a more solemn sound. However many churches have now realised their leather muffles are rotten as they have not been used since King George VIaposs death  years ago.As a result, leatherworkers have been inundated with orders as churches rush to ensure theyaposre ready for the sad day, reports the Mail on Sunday. Sales have reportedly doubled in the past few months. Vicki Chapman, from the Central Council of Church Bell Ringers, told the newspaper that adding the muffle turns the bellsapos normal dong, dong, dong into more of a thudding sound. She said: We have spent a lot of time talking to the Royal Household and Lambeth Palace about the day the monarch passes, which we hope will not be any time soon. It is important as it is about paying due reverence to the service of the monarch and commemorating her le.‚Äù  Last year full details of Operation London Bridge were leaked, giving a full day-to-day run down of what will happen when the Queen passes away. The day will be known as D Day, with the days following called D Day plus the number of days that have passed. For example the second day will be D Day Plus One. Prince Charles - who will become King upon his motheraposs passing - will address the nation on the day of her death, while the Prime Minister will be the first government member to issue a statement. Government departments have been instructed to have flags at half mast within  minutes of the announcement, with Cabinet members set to be called with the sad news and urged to show discretion.  The Queen will be buried  days after she dies, it is expected, and Charles will embark on a tour of the UK before the burial is held. The sovereignaposs coffin will lie in state for three days at the Houses of Parliament, with authorities anticipating hundreds of thousands of people to descend on London - sparking fears over gridlock, policing and even food shortages. Any other Parliamentary business is set to be suspended for  days, it is reported. The day of the funeral will be a Day of National Mourning, but employers will not be compelled to give staff a day off. The service will take place at Westminster Abbey, and a two minute silence will be held across the UK at noon. A committal service will be held at St Georgeaposs Chapel, which is at Windsor Castle, where the Queen will be buried at King George VI Memorial Chapel. news uk-news queen-reveals-shes-exhausted-after-"Queen reveals she was ‚Äòtired and exhausted‚Äô during bout of CovidByRussell MyersRoyal Editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments The Queen has revealed the toll that Covid took on her, as she spoke to patients and NHS staff about the ‚Äúhorrible‚Äù pandemic. The -year-old monarch tested ¬≠positive for coronavirus in February but carried on performing duties in isolation from Windsor Castle.She spoke about her condition during a video call with the Royal London Hospital to mark the official opening of its Queen Elizabeth Unit. Talking to former Covid patient Asef Hussain, and his we Shamina, the Queen said: ‚ÄúIt does leave one very tired and exhausted, doesn‚Äôt it  This horrible pandemic. It‚Äôs not a nice result.‚Äù Mr Hussain was the third member of his family to be admitted to hospital with Covid in December .  While he was in a coma for seven weeks after being put on a ventilator, his brother died and his father passed away. Mrs Hussain told the Queen at one point there were  friends and family on a Zoom call praying for her husband. The monarch made them smile when she joked: ‚ÄúSo you have a large family, or a large influence on people ‚Äù  On Wednesday, she heard how the -bed unit in East London was built in record time to treat around  patients. Her Majesty was told by one senior nurse: ‚ÄúWe held their hands, we wiped their tears and we provided comfort.‚Äù  Hospital chaplain Imam Faruq Siddiqi explained that families ‚Äúfelt a sense of hope‚Äù when he visited their loved ones. ‚ÄúAlthough I didn‚Äôt hold any miracles, I hope I was able to bring some sort of comfort to them through my presence and prayers,‚Äù he said. The Queen said: ‚ÄúIt obviously was a very frightening experience to have Covid very badly, wasn‚Äôt it ‚Äù He replied: ‚ÄúWhat made it worse was being by themselves.‚Äù ‚ÄúExactly. So they were alone, too,‚Äù the monarch said.  She was also introduced to the men who built the care unit in just five weeks, Paul Chandler and Jeff Barley. Her Majesty said: ‚ÄúIt is very interesting, when there‚Äôs some very vital thing, how everybody pulls together. Marvellous, isn‚Äôt it ‚Äù Mr Barley hailed the ‚Äúlittle bit of Dunkirk spirit‚Äù involved, prompting the smiling monarch to reply: ‚ÄúThank ¬≠goodness it still exists.‚Äù The Queen, who had ‚Äúmild cold-like‚Äù ¬≠Covid symptoms, has been suffering from mobility issues, forcing her to cancel a number of public engagements. Buckingham Palace announced on Friday that she had decided not to attend an annual Easter church service. Prince Charles will for the first time represent her at the Royal Maundy Thursday service at St George‚Äôs Chapel at Windsor Castle, Berks. Keep up to date with all the latest news from the Queen, Charles, William, Kate, Harry, Meghan, George, Charlotte, Louis, Archie and the rest of the family. Weaposll send the best Royal news directly to your inbox so you never have to miss a thing.to our newsletter here. It will be only the fth time she has missed the event in her -year reign. Aides have insisted she is determined to attend her Platinum Jubilee ¬≠celebrations in June. A source said: ‚ÄúShe has good days and less good days but is pin sharp and carrying on with daily duties.‚Äù Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON The QueenRoyal FamilyCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: real life castaway buys tropical
story: Real-le Castaway buys tropical island for ¬£, so he can live as a recluseBrendon Grimshaw, from Dewsbury, in Kirklees, West Yorkshire, bought Moyenne, a tiny island just half a mile wide in the luxurious Seychelles, for just ¬£,Brendon Grimshaw bought Moyenne for just ¬£, in  Image: Daily MirrorByConnor TealeLucy LeesonRyan Merrield:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsAn ex-newspaper editor bought a tropical island for ¬£, and dedicated the rest of his le to restoring its appearance and nurturing its wildle. Brendon Grimshaw, from Dewsbury, in Kirklees, West Yorkshire, abandoned his high-pressured old le in the face of unemployment - before the age of  - and took an extended holiday. In , he purchased Moyenne, a tiny island just half a mile wide in the luxurious Seychelles, a cluster of islands in the Indian Ocean.The ex-journalist immediately fell in love with his new home, with its tranquil silence and wild tangle of vegetation, Yorkshire Live reports.Brendon lived almost completely alone on the island. Moyenne had been left abandoned for decades, prior to his arrival and was so overgrown that falling coconuts were said to never reach the ground.  It has previously been likened to a tiny rainforest erupting from the ocean. With the help of -year-old Rene Antoine Lafortune, the son of a local fisherman, Brendon set about forging paths through the undergrowth. They also planted trees in an attempt to transform the island. Brendon built a humble wooden home for himself. But to truly transform the island he knew he would need to nurture itaposs wildle back to full health. He gradually introduced giant tortoises to his corner of the Indian Ocean and eventually shared Moyenne with  of the indigenous creatures.  Brendonaposs relentless hard work inevitably attracted the attention of wealthy investors, who viewed the Seychelles as a tropical paradise and an ideal spot for a luxury holiday destination. The aposreal le Robinson Crusoeapos - also since compared to the Tom Hanks character in the  film Castaway - is said to have turned down close to ¬£million for his small island. But he wanted to ensure its future in a dferent way, and not to line corporate pockets. As he had no children to pass the island to at the time of his death, Brendon signed a perpetual trust with the Seychellesapos Ministry of Environment in . The agreement marked the islandaposs transformation into a National Park. To this day, it remains the smallest island in the world to hold that title. Brendon passed away in  and his grave sits alongside that of his father, who came to live with him in later le. His tombstone reads: Moyenne taught him to open his eyes to the beauty around him and say thank you to God. The island is now overseen by the Moyenne Island Foundation and remains largely undeveloped.A restaurant serving local dishes, a small museum dedicated to Brendonaposs le, and two nurseries for giant tortoise hatchlings form the only additions to the area, reports the BBC. No more than  visitors are allowed on the island at any one time, even during peak tourist season. title: secret burglars symbol appears houses
story: Secret burglars symbol appears on houses leaving residents terried theyre targetsPlain circles as well as circles with a diagonal line have been drawn in white chalk on Stoke-on-Tren properties, with the method often associated with burglaries as well as dog theftMysterious chalk markings have appeared on houses in Beville Street, Fenton Image: Stoke Sentinel BPM MediaByRuby Davies:,  Apr |commentsWorried residents of a Stoke-on-Trent street say they are concerned after a number of mysterious chalk markings were left on their houses. Several homes in Beville Street, Fenton, have had chalk marks left on the walls, sparking fear among families.Plain circles and circles with a diagonal line have been drawn in white chalk on the properties. The method is often associated with burglaries and has also been linked to dog thefts, the Stoke Sentinel reports.However, utility workers are also known to leave signs on walls to indicate an area has been checked for potential issues like a gas leak or to earmark where a water pipe is located.  Nick Taylor lives in one of the homes that has been marked in Beville Street. The -year-old says it has left him feeling aposworriedapos. He said: Iaposve heard about people doing it. Itaposs usually done for dogs. My doorbell picks up on anyone who walks outside my house, so I will have a look through my doorbell footage for anyone suspicious. Iaposll be keeping an eye out and Iaposll wash the mark off and have a look up the street. Cha Colemanaposs property, in Beville Street, has also been marked. The -year-old said: Itaposs peculiar. A lady messaged me a few weeks ago about people using chalk to mark houses.  I never saw anyone do it. Iaposm a bit creeped out. Iaposll just be keeping an eye out. Touch wood, weaposve lived here since  and had nothing other than two bikes stolen last year. I work from home, so Iaposd see themthey tried to break in as Iaposm home all the time. Maybe itaposs just a utility company because itaposs on almost every house. George Millwardaposs property in Beville Street has not been marked with the chalk, but he says everyone in the street is keeping an eye out. The -year-old said: Iaposve been told itaposs burglars. We donapost have one on our house, but one or two have got them. Iaposm not worried about it because Iaposve got nothing for them to pinch. But everyone is keeping more of an eye out. We always do, me and the we.  I hope itaposs just something innocent. The police have been informed by a woman up the road. She told the police about it after she had a marking appear. The Safeguarding Hub - which shares home protection advice and information across the UK - previously said: Between us, we have a fairly extensive knowledge of burglary. We have spent many hours speaking to distraught victims, visiting crime scenes and dealing with burglars. We have actually seen and experienced these symbols being used by criminals. This is not to say that this is a common practice between bands of thieves, for most burglars work alone. We do not want to scaremonger and we can say confidentially that the use of these symbols is very rare.  But,you are a caregiver to an elderly or vulnerable person and spot strange marks outside their home, do you really want to dismiss it out of hand without just ensuring that the symbol is legitimate  Elsewhere in the country, the symbols have been dubbed the aposDa Pinci Codeapos with dferent signs for aposnothing worth stealingapos, aposwealthyapos and aposgood targetapos. A triangle symbol is used to show a single woman lives in the property on her own, or vertical lines could imply a house has obvious valuables inside. Also keep an eye out for the letters ‚ÄòM‚Äô, which tells other burglars to strike in the morning, whereas ‚ÄòN‚Äô means a night-time intrusion. title: two bed flat goes sale
story: Two-bed flat goes on sale for less than the price of a used family carThe property at Grimsby‚Äôs Thorgam Court, which forms part of a three storey block on Harrison Street, is on sale for just ¬£,The two-bed flat in Grimsby will be auctioned off later this weekByCaroline Hemmingham:,  Apr  A two-bedroom flat is up for grabs for less than the price of a used family car, a steal in a market currently touted as being unaffordable.The first floor property at Grimsby‚Äôs Thorgam Court, which forms part of a three storey block on Harrison Street, is on sale for just ¬£,. The home is advertised by Taylor James Auctions LTD, Birmingham, on Rightmove, where it is described as requiring ‚Äúsome updating throughout‚Äù.However, on a video walk-through of the flat there donapost appear to be any glaringly obvious structural issues,Grimsby Live reports.During the virtual tour, you can see the hallway, bathroom, a living room which leads into a small kitchen, and two bedrooms.  According to the property information on Rightmove, at ¬£, and with a deposit of ¬£, monthly repayments on a mortgage for this property in Grimsby at . per cent annual interest would work out at just ¬£ over  years. The auction will take place online on April  via the companyaposs website and anyone wishing to bid must pre-register no later than am of that day.News of the unusually low sale price comes just weeks after The Mirror reported on the average house price having increased for the seventh consecutive month ‚Äì up to .%.As Brits continue to struggle with the rising costs of fuel, energy and food, the boom in the UK property market refuses to cool down. This is thought to have been in part caused by the easing of social restrictions, which has seen the migratory trend of deurbanization reverted. Britain has in recent months witnessed an influx of people relocating back to urban centres, spiking rent prices up by .%. Robert Gardner, Nationwide‚Äôs chief economist, said: ‚ÄúA combination of robust demand and limited stock of homes on the market has kept upward pressure on prices. ‚ÄúThe continued buoyancy of the housing market is a little surprising, given the mounting pressure on household budgets from rising inflation, which reached a -year high of .% in January, and since borrowing costs have started to move up from all-time lows in recent months. The strength is particularly noteworthy since the squeeze on household incomes has led to a signicant weakening of consumer confidence.‚ÄùAs per the recent Halax House Price Index report, the average house price has continued to increase, whilst the Office for National Statistics revealed that the average cost of renting in the United Kingdom increased by % in , the biggest yearly increase since .Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Housing" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: uks secret nuclear bunkers hidden
story: UKs secret nuclear bunkers hidden in forests and under streets amid Soviet war fearsThe top-secret network of bunkers was built during the Cold War when Britain was an ally to the United States, and the threat of imminent nuclear war with the Soviet Union loomed largeThe hidden nuclear bunker in Worsley Woods Image: SubmittedByLouisa Gregson:,  Apr |comments Tucked away in the far corner of woods, hidden hundreds of feet underground and filled with subterranean corridors and rooms that serve as an eerie reminder of past tensions - the UK is home to a string of little-known nuclear bunkers.They were built at a time when there was very real fear of a nuclear war, with some constructed entirely in secret.During the Cold War Britain was an ally to the United States, who were at war with the Soviet Union, and needed its own nuclear deterrent, the Manchester Evening News reports.A fascination for urban explorers and even a destination for illegal ravers, hereaposs a round up of some of the secret shelters and whataposs become of them in the years since the war. Trafford  Builders uncovered a -year-old nuclear bunker under Trafford town hall as part of its multi-million pound renovation. A maze of bricked tunnels, foot-thick steel and reinforced concrete, the vast chamber was designed to house top brassthe nuclear sirens sounded. The ,sq ft fall-out shelter was designed as part of the council‚Äôs s extension to the town hall. Its inclusion in the plans caused outrage among anti-nuclear campaigners, who furiously attacked it as a waste of money. But town hall chiefs said it was an ‚Äòessential‚Äô part of its civil defence against an all-out attack. Now empty apart from a generator and air filtration system, the labyrinth, built by structural engineer Ray Higham once included a cavernous storage room of dried food, government radio equipment and ‚Äì rumour has it ‚Äì a morgue.Cheadle Built in the height of The Cold War, The Mill Lane bunker in Cheadle, which was designed to withstand direct missile attacks, was intended to house bigwigs while they sat out nuclear hostilities before emerging into a devastated but presumably fall-out free world.Ten years after being put up for sale by the Ministry of Defence, the bunker was demolished to make way for more car parking spaces for staff working at the nearby Alexandra Hospital.Although it had  rooms, the musty-smelling bunker, built with five feet-thick concrete walls, was built to accommodate up to  people, the bunker was intended as a command post for ministers in the event of a nuclear holocaust and contained an antiquated telephone switchboard as well as emergency generators and telecommunications equipment. Manchester city centre  Manchesteraposs nuclear bunkers - hidden ft beneath the streets between St Peteraposs Square and Piccadilly Gardens - were refurbished and offered for rent as offices. The network of tunnels, which spreads under the city out to Ardwick and Salford, removed from the protection of the Official Secrets Acts in the s, are still guarded around the clock by security staff. But they are unknown to the vast majority of people who walk above them daily. The entrances to the tunnels, including two in George Street, are surrounded by barbed wire and security gates. Telephone Exchange, as it is called, has a main tunnel running more then  yards from St Peteraposs Square up to the Piccadilly Plaza Hotel in the city centre. Smaller tunnels run across the city. They were built in the s when the fear of nuclear war was at its height and were so secret that Polish immigrants unable to speak a word of English were employed to build them. In the event of the city being damaged by an atomic bomb, the tunnels would have be used to maintain vital telecommunication networks with other cities across the UK. Worsley Woods Tucked away in a far corner of the RHS Bridgewater site in Worsley, a relic from the Cold War is now camouflaged by graffiti as well as foliage, and has been a destination for so-called aposurban explorersapos.Dug into hillside in , the bunker was constructed when the potential of a nuclear strike by a Joseph Stalin-led Soviet Russia was deemed to be at its height.It was built by the War Office as an anti-aircraft operations room on land at Worsley New Hall, and was part of a national network of defences which included an alternative seat of government to the House of Commons - underground at Box Hill near in Corsham in Wiltshire. Oldham  At the height of global panic, a nuclear bunker was built under the then newly-constructed Oldham Civic Centre. It was designed to act as a safe room to protect the town‚Äôs decision-makers and civic leaders from any nuclear attack or fall-out. Thankfully it was never used, but many thousands of people have walked into the ft-high tower off West Street ever since without knowing what lies beneath their feet. Today the bunker, made up of subterranean corridors and rooms, is used for storage. The dferent chambers, reinforced by concrete and brick, were part of the centre‚Äôs overall design. It opened in  but the bunker wasn‚Äôt publicised. title: uk weather 20c heat blast
story: UK weather: C heat blast for some but others face chilly start to Easter holidayWhile some of us will once again be putting away the winter woollies this week, the chill and rain will stick around for those in Scotland and the north-west of EnglandThe current cold snap will dissipate for many this week Image: PAByAlice PeacockNews Reporter:,  Apr |commentsTemperatures are expected to climb up as high as C in some parts of the UK in the lead up to Easter, though others face a chilly start to the long weekend.Forecasters have said Britain is in for some warmer weather this week as bitter winds and frost give way to a warm ‚Äútropical‚Äù blast.The current cold snap that followed a spell of hot weather in late March will sht, enabling Brits to get out in the sun over the bank holidays.Warm winds will flood into Britain, steered around high pressure similar to the driver of the march mini heatwave. Met Office weather meteorologist Aidan McGivern said: ‚ÄúWarmer weather is on the way for the start of the week, and we could even see C in the southeast. ‚ÄúThe general trend is for it to turn warmer with higher pressure increasingly likely through the week and into the following week. ‚ÄúThere is still the chance of some rain mainly in the west.‚Äù While some of us will once again be putting away the winter woollies, those further north in Scotland and the north-west of England are likely to see rain and some colder temperatures.  Mr McGivern said: ‚ÄúInto Monday, low pressure becomes more and more erratic, but it looks likely that northern and western parts of the UK will bear the brunt of any wetter weather. ‚ÄúLow pressure is slowly progressing from the west bringing some rain in on Sunday, most likely in north-west of the UK, western Scotland, western England and north Wales. ‚ÄúCold air remains in the far north with the potential for snowthat rain mixes with cold air as it approaches from the west.‚ÄùThe rain is forecast to ease from Good Friday until April , as it moves eastwards,The Independentreports. According to the Met Office‚Äôs longer-term predictions, showers were possible in the Midlands over the Easter period. ‚ÄúFor the rest of the period, a northwest-southeast split is likely, with the northwest remaining more changeable with strong winds and rain at times,‚Äù the Met Office said. ‚ÄúSome rain may occasionally spread into parts of the southeast at first, but it is likely to turn dry and become generally much more settled, though perhaps rather cloudy, in the south, with lighter winds through to the end of this period. ‚ÄúTemperatures are expected to be above average, and warm at times for the south.‚Äù  Jim Dale, meteorologist for British Weather Services, last week said the general trend for this week was a rise in temperatures. If things play out, we could be looking at C or C in the south over Easter,‚Äù he added. Warm weather comes with a warning for hay-fever sufferers with tree pollen levels predicted to soar next week. Airborne allergens expert Max Wiseberg said: The start of the tree pollen season has been slow, with the poor weather so far most of this spring. But it looks asthe season could start in earnest with high pollen counts forecast across the South and East of England on Monday. news uk-news what-your-british-gas-smart-"British Gas explains how to read a digital gas meterByDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Apr |commentsBritish Gas customers have been complaining of aposfaultyapos smart meters that display larger than normal readings - or no readings at all. Frustrated customers have been speaking to The Mirror about their British Gas smart meter struggles with claims of them not working, showing large readings, and frustrations over not understanding the problem or being able to get it sorted quickly.Jamie Watkinson-Harvey described British Gas smart meters as simply not fit for purpose and told The Mirror one meter even claimed he was using ¬£, per day. Charlotte, who described herself as a disgruntled customer, says she has experienced issues with her smart meter since February. Another customer, who wished to stay anonymous, told The Mirror: Both my gas and electric are supplied by British Gas. My smart meter stopped working as of the March . Unfortunately no engineer available until the July . With many reporting issues with their smart meters and looking for answers, we have looked at what British Gas advise. Have you experienced any issues  Email webnews@mirror  If your meter isnapost working British Gas saysyour meter is damaged, they can send someone out to make sure you and your home are safe. You can call their Pay as you go enquiries line which is open Monday to Friday am to pm for general enquiries and  hours a day, seven days a week for emergencies.If you donapost have a pay as you go meter you can call the energy companyaposs Account enquiries line. Whatmy meteraposs damaged If you think your meter is damaged, you are advised to immediately get in touch with the Gas Emergency Services. If you notice any sparking, smoking or burning coming from your meter, British Gas says you should ring the fire brigade.Turn off all your appliances and call your local electricity distributor.  Whatmy meter reading hasnapost changed, or is going backwards  This could mean your meter is recording your energy usage incorrectly.If you have a pay as you go meter call the Pay as you go enquiries line as soon as possible to make sure you are only paying for what you have used.If you donapost have a pay as you go meter call the Account enquiries line. What does the message on my meter mean  Are you getting a message on your meter you donapost understand  You can view the Understanding messages on your meter page for help on this.Why has my smart meter stopped working British Gas say they need to establishthe problem is with your smart meters or your smart energy monitor. Click here to checkthe problem could be with your smart energy monitor.They said there are also occasionally problems with the technology that supports smart meters. British Gas deals with issues on a case by case basis to work out what they can do to help.Energy update on April  British Gas put out a statement on their website on Saturday saying: We‚Äôre receiving a high volume of customers trying to contact us, so wait times are much longer than usual. We understand that this is a worrying time. If you‚Äôre looking for ways to reduce your bills, lowering your energy usage may help. View some energy saving tips. There is also support through our charitiesyou are struggling to pay. Find out more about the changes in the energy market. title: woman who lost job lived
story: Woman who lost job lived on beans and toast for weeks so she could feed her catKelly Blakeley, a Leeds local, has struggled to afford food for both herself and her cat since she lost her job at the beginning of the pandemicKelly found a leline in the form of a St Giles Trust Pantry, a food bank in Chapeltown, Leeds Image: Samuel PortBySamuel PortAlice PeacockNews Reporter:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr  A woman who lost her retail job at the start of the pandemic ‚Äúlived on beans and toast‚Äù so that she could still feed her beloved cat when money was low.Kelly Blakeley, from Leeds, has struggled to afford food for both herself and her cat since she lost her job back in . The -year-old dotes on her cat Tigger, a tabby who she rescued from the streets, to the point where sheaposll put his needs first.The former retail worker, who now receives Jobseeker‚Äôs Allowance, told LeedsLive : ‚ÄúNo matter what money I‚Äôve got left over after paying the bills, no matter whether I could afford to buy food for myself, my cat came first and I always came second.However, in August last year, Kelly found a leline in the form of a St Giles Trust Pantry, in Chapeltown, Leeds. The food bank lets people in need fill up two big bags of groceries for the small price of ¬£..  ‚ÄúSo I could live on beans and toast for a fortnight so I could feed my cat. I‚Äôve lived on beans on toast and eggs on toast. Since coming down here, as you can see, I‚Äôve been able to get a full shop. With the cooked meat that they do, I mainly get it for my cat. If I can‚Äôt afford cat food, I know that my cat has got something to eat.‚Äù The food bank, which is located on Saville Mount, has been open for around  months. The staff understand that accepting help with necessities like food can be embarrassing and challenging for those in need, so they‚Äôve tried to make the visit as nice as possible. There‚Äôs a comfy sofa that people can sit on, along with a coffee table and a rug which make the centre feel homely. Staff offer out cups of tea or coffee while they chat with people who come in for support. Sybil Beckford, a grandmother-of-one and mother-of-three, said she was struggling to pay for food before visiting the food bank. The -year-old cleaner recounted how she would often be unable to pay the bill at the supermarket counter, surprised at the rising prices for food.  Sybil said: ‚ÄúThis place makes a big dference. ‚ÄúWhen you go into town to buy certain stuff, the prices keep going up. I‚Äôm one of those who pick something [an item] up in the shop and don‚Äôt look at the price. Then when I take it to the counter, I can‚Äôt pay for it.‚Äù Staff at the St Giles Trust offer a range of services, which also includes offering support to ex-convicts who are rehabilitating into society, vulnerable women, children and families. Gill Gaunt, the community service delivery manager, said: We like to be informal so people can come in and have a chat to us, it‚Äôs all confidential, about any issues they may have. Some people come in who have issues around social services, around their children, and we offer a lot of advice.  The -year-old, who has been a part of the trust for  years, added: ‚ÄúWe wanted to make it feel like everyone who comes here could just have a chat with us. Iaposm sort of like a manager here but I‚Äôm just the same as everyone . Eva Bennett-Gibson, who has been working as a children and families case worker there since , can often be seen loading up people‚Äôs shopping bags with all the grocery items. ‚ÄúPeople know they can come here and take home some food without being judged and not looked down upon,‚Äù Eva said. ‚ÄúThey know that we‚Äôre here with open doors. We‚Äôre supportive when people come in and take them around, make sure they know there‚Äôs support on offer all the time and we‚Äôre here to help.‚Äù Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON povertyFood banksCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: gross secret hiding your mattress
story: Gross secret hiding in your mattress and how often you should change your sheetsCleaning is never a fun activity and many avoid doing it whenever they can, but according to the experts its vital to disinfect and wash germ hotspots in our bedroom regularlyHow often do you change your sheets  Image: Getty ImagesByZoe ForseyFeatures Editor:,  Apr |commentsWe spend about a third of our lives in bed, but it never quite feels like enough. However it turns out our bedding and mattress are a hotbed for bacteria and other gross things, and many people are guilty of not washing their sheets often enough.Some people may go a few weeks or even a month without changing the duvet cover, but the experts at online-bedrooms stress it needs to be done once a week.They explain that your favourite pillow can accumulate over several thousand times more bacteria than a toilet seat in just seven nights. Luckily, the organisms found on pillowcases are largely harmless and are simply a build up of skin cells, sweat and saliva. Another mistake many of us may be making is how often we change our mattress. Itaposs hardly an exciting purchase, so many people donapost really think about splashing out on a new one unless they need to.  However, it too is a nesting place for germs and you could be sharing your bed with yeast, mould and bacteria. As well as microbes, skin cells and food particles that are transferred to our mattresses from our bodies, a factor in making mattresses such a germy spot is gravity. Airborne particles of dust and debris float around the bedroom before settling on the bed. The experts recommend replacing your mattress every seven to eight years.Nic Shacklock from online-bedrooms said: ‚ÄúIt is no secret that germs live all over our houses, however there are lots of hidden spots that we may not ever think about during our cleaning rituals.‚ÄúSpots like pillowcases and curtains might look fresh and clean, they are hiding a range of nasty bacteria that could lead to enhanced allergies, unpleasant odours and skin issues.‚Äù Bur perhaps the most surprising germ hotspot is bedroom lamps, which collect a huge amount of germs but tend to be missed during cleaning. Their surfaces offer space for dust and dirt to settle and are common touch points so need to be wiped and disinfected every week. title: i gave council house luxury
story: I gave my council house luxury makeover - but trolls say I should give it upA mum has revealed how shes spent eight years giving her council house a luxury makeover, but cruel trolls have suggested she should give up her home for the more needy Image: abitofme TiktokByEmma RosemurgeyAudience WriterSamantha BartlettSenior Lestyle  Travel Reporter:,  Apr |comments A mum has revealed how sheaposs completely transformed her council house with a luxurious makeover - but trolls say she should give up her home for those in more need. The mum, who posts from the handle @bitofme on TikTok, regularly shares updates of the transformation of her council owned property, which she has rented for the last  years. She has added chic wooden ling to her living room, as well as redecorating her bathroom, her daughteraposs bedroom and giving her garden a Mrs Hinch-inspired makeover, the Daily Star reports.The gorgeous home transformation is undoubtedly impressive, however the mum has been met with some negative comments from people who have suggested thatshe can afford to redecorate, she should buy her own home. And although some are impressed at her makeover skills, others say she should buy her own homeshe has enough money to do so. If you can afford to do all that, do you really need a council house  There are people living in poor conditions waiting for one of these homes, one TikTok user suggested. The mum followed this by making another video showing off her pristine home, as she captioned it: Why would I give up everything Iaposve worked for  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Another TikTok user asked: I think what they are saying is how did you get a council houseyou have all this money to decorate it  The mum replied to them: Yes I work, theyaposre not given to people on low incomes anyone can apply. I had this  years ago when I was  with a baby and nowhere to live. Everything was done on a budget, sale items, discounts and over the space of the last three years. I understand people are waiting for council homes but we love ours, I canapost give it up. She went on to explain that she had been offered the right to buy a few years ago, but hadnapost been able to afford it, so had secured letime tenancy instead. All the council owns is the bricks and mortar everything  is my home. Iaposve spent the last eight years rebuilding my le and my home, she wrote.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it.
