story: Gigha Primary School pupils shared their favourite parts of the island in celebration of  years of community ownership.Pupils and staff from the school joined islanders and visitors at a flag-raising ceremony on Tuesday March , in recognition of the anniversary.During the event, the children sang the song One More Step Along The Road I Go.To mark the occasion, pupils and their families created designs which were added to wooden discs using pyrography before being hung up on display.Pupils also created an island frieze which was shared with visitors at the event.Each pupil planned and designed a cm-wide piece of artwork to show their favourite part of the island, complete with a written description of its importance to them.These pieces were joined together to make the final collaborative frieze to represent their island.Pupil Ella said: #The Twin Beaches are the nicest place on Gigha because I like the waves and also the sun. I like the sunlight and the boats bobbing around.#A family of friendly #Furbochs# is encouraging people to explore and appreciate the wonders of nature on Gigha.The furry creatures are helping the organisers of the Our Gigha and Mewellbeing project by travelling round the island in their own little shepherd#s hut, full of fun and nature-based activities for the young and not-so-young to enjoy.There was great excitement at Gigha Village Hall on Saturday, March , when the Furbochs ‚Äì which feature in their own storybook ‚Äì popped in for a visit before heading out on their adventures.The OGAM project is funded by the Wellcome Trust, through the British Science Association‚Äôs Ideas Fund, which enables communities to develop and try out ideas that address problems related to poor mental health.This allows researchers and communities to work together to explore ways of improving mental wellbeing.#On Gigha, we are researching whether community-led nature interventions, including the Furboch house and its activities, as well as The Gigha Furboch storybook and an outdoor shelter for young people, can help to improve the wellbeing of children and families,# said an OGAM spokesperson.#Covid has been dficult for many of us, but we know that getting outdoors can really help with our physical and mental health.#The OGAM project was designed to help make getting outdoors a bit dferent, fun and a little quirky, whilst making the most of what our beautul island has to offer us!#The Furbochs have been more than happy to help us and have offered up their shepherd‚Äôs hut to be used by whoever comes to visit.#Please use anything or everything in there and look after it the best you can for others to enjoy.#We would love to know what thoughts you have about our project and there is a feedback logbook in the Furboch house, which we would appreciate you completing after a visit.#We know that sometimes things can get lost or broken andyou notice anything, or have any other comments or suggestions, please add a note in the section at the back of the logbook to enable us to make sure things are the best they can be.#Gigha children are helping with the research but anyone is welcome to visit the Furbochs ‚Äì there is a map outside the village shop which offers a clue on where to look for them.#We hope you enjoy your time with the Furbochs and using the things in their hut,# added the spokesperson.#The project is based on honesty, trust, respect for our environment and for each other and with a shared desire for everyone‚Äôs wellbeing.#Sometimes le can be tough but a little chill-out time with those we love and with nature can make a dference.#

title: from our files april 8 2022
story: Kintyre continues to impress at a national level and this time a local junior wind band has taken gold in London.It was the first time in  years that an Argyll band qualied for the National Concert Band Festival and the Kintyre Schools Junior Band certainly did the area proud.This is the first time the junior band has made it to the national finals, with the senior band being the last ones to make it, taking gold in .The wind band received the gold award at the regional finals in October, and got to work to raise the much-needed funds to allow the band to travel to London to compete.The young band made up of children from primary six to S played in the Dukes Hall at the Royal Academy of Music and impressed the judges.They were playing in the Junior Band Contest for children under the ages of  and excelled themselves the band also boasts members from Lochgilphead.Many of the other bands in the national final were from private schools with renowned music departments, so this is yet another accolade they can add to their belt.Conductor Katy Welch runs the band with help from James McVicar, who is the conductor of Campbeltown Brass and once played in the junior band himself.‚ÄòI am hugely proud of them all they are all amazing and a credit to their parents and schools,‚Äô said Katy.Thanks to the efforts of the band, and generosity of the local community and businesses, the band managed to raise ¬£, in just over eight weeks, to enable them to compete and travel to London.‚ÄòIt is just amazing, we still can‚Äôt believe it. I don‚Äôt think the children realised when we were in London of their achievement it‚Äôs fantastic.‚ÄòWe would like to thank everyone who helped us to raise the funds to allow us to go, including Bradan Ltd, Campbeltown Rotary, Campbeltown Common Good Fund, Numero Dix, Jenny Black and the Co-Operative.‚ÄôKaty told the Courier the band plans to keep practising and entering competitions and work towards the regional qualiers in October.‚ÄòMost of the kids hadn‚Äôt been to London, let alone competed in a national competition. What an achievement for them,‚Äô said Katy.TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGOAn Islay mother is threatening to seek legal advice to stop Argyll and Bute Council closing Newton Primary School.The parents of pupils at the school are frustrated that their best efforts to have what they claim are flaws in the consultative document corrected have been rejected by the council.The mother, who has a five-year-old daughter at the school, said: ‚ÄòThe astonishing and arrogant attitude of the chief education officials whenever we raise our genuine concerns makes all of us parents very, very angry.‚ÄòWe must seriously think of taking legal action against the council and will in any case report the situation to the local government ombudsman.‚ÄôBacked by Islay councillor Robin Currie, the parents took their arguments to the Mid Argyll, Kintyre and Islands and the Oban Lorn and Isles area committees.The issue of transport was one subject the parents planned to raise. Some children will have to leave home at .am to catch the bus.FIFTY YEARS AGOWork on the ¬£,-plus harbour contract awarded to FJC Lilley‚Äôs Marine section will start on Monday.The decision to award the contract to Lilley‚Äôs was taken at the Finance Committee meeting of the Town Council earlier this week.The work will involve the erection of sheet piling of outer and inner berths, reconstruction of the town‚Äôs fish market, affording drive in out facilities, and many other much-needed improvements.Additional piling will be provided for deep water berths suitable for large Navy vessels.Harbour Committee Convener Councillor Dan Black expressed the sincere hope that the commencement of the work in the very near future would ease the local unemployment situation.A spokesman for the company said earlier this week that six locals would be taken on as soon as possible.SEVENTY YEARS AGOMajor Duncan McCallum, MP for Argyll, asked the Secretary of State for Scotland in the House of Commons last weekhe was aware that much good agricultural land in the Campbeltown area was being lost to flooding caused by the Backs and Machrihanish waters and what steps he proposed to take to ensure that this land was reserved for agricultural production.He also asked the Secretary of State, in another question,he was aware of the necessity of redeveloping the land drainage scheme for the Campbeltown-Machrihanish area that the farming community were unable to finance such a scheme themselves in its entirety andhe would devise some new plan to carry out this urgent work for which a rate or levy to cover the interest charges on capital expenditure could be raised from the proprietors and farmers whose lands would be restored to regular cultivation.Mr W McNair Snadden MP, Joint Parliamentary Under Secretary of State, replied: ‚ÄòThis is one of the major drainage problems which can only be solved by new legislation.‚ÄòIn our consideration of legislative proposals, we will carefully examine the method suggested.‚ÄôMajor McCallum has been corresponding and having consultations with Ministers and Heads of Departments for nearly three years on this flooding at Machrihanish.The biggest Naval exodus from Campbeltown since the war, when Campbeltown was a Naval base, took place on Monday when between  and  Navy men left at .pm in a specially chartered British Railways paddle steamer for Gourock to catch train connections for the south and a further  went by two extra large British European Airways planes which had been put on to the route for the purpose.The men were all from the Royal Naval Air Station at Machrihanish, HMS Landrail, and were in good spirits.They were going on Easter leave.Now there is only a skeleton crew left at the station for the next  days.

title: funding to help revitalise town cinema
story: Campbeltown Community Business , which owns and operates the cinema, has been awarded ¬£, from the Scottish Government through Screen Scotland#s Recovery Fund for Independent Cinemas.The ¬£. million fund supports new activity and initiatives that help address the fundamental shts to the industry brought about by Covid-.Sid Gallagher, chairman of CCB, said the board of directors was #delighted# to be successful in its funding bid and thankful not only for the financial assistance but also for the¬†support and guidance offered throughout this and other processes.He added: #We are deeply indebted to CPH manager Ellen Mainwood and the team at the cinema for obtaining the funding by making a well-thought-out application.#They have put together a collection of ideas and strategies that will ensure a vibrant cinema scene in Campbeltown to get people coming to the pictures more frequently or perhaps for the first time.#New activities will include some calculated risks in the form of more independent, archive and foreign language films what is called #strand programming#.#There is still a commitment to obtaining mainstream films on release and the funding will assist with this.#We have a target to increase attendance at mainstream films by  per cent by  and hope this will be well advanced within the funding period.#Mr Gallagher added that the cinema#s new booking system, which was financed by the funding, will help staff keep in better contact with customers, allowing them to share news of interesting programming and offers, including a new loyalty scheme.#Through the funding, we will be able to support staff with training programmes and flexible and increased working hours,# he added.¬†#Overall, it is a great package with lots of positives.#Sambrooke Scott, head of audience development at Screen Scotland, said: #Scotland has a marvellously unique cohort of independent cinemas serving communities across the country, from historic purpose-built venues to arts centres and multi-screen cinemas.#Despite facing unprecedented challenges as we adapt to living with Covid, they have continued to provide vital cultural, social and economic hubs for the towns and cities they serve.#This fund will ensure they are able to continue that work and make vital changes to welcome cinema-goers back, to reach new audiences and future generations to come.#Culture Secretary Angus Robertson said: #We#re delighted to support independent cinemas across the country to build back and adapt their businesses in the light of the challenges faced by the industry throughout the Covid pandemic.#Local cinemas are a focal point for communities and these funds will help them to develop new activities to re-engage with, and grow, their audiences.#Mr Gallagher added: #We are extremely lucky in Campbeltown to have a local picture house, especially one that is so distinctive and historic.#The funding will help CPH to keep providing great films and comfort to everyone. Please come out and support us. We need people#s interest and, most of all, custom.#

title: leader april 8 2022
story: Well done to the East Kintyre Renewable Energy Groupvolunteers for securing a better deal on community benefit funding for Kintyre.Kintyre#s coastal location makes it an attractive target for windfarm companies, as can be seen from a map of developments which are operational, consented, awaiting planning decisions, at appeal and scoping on the Kintyre Wind website at www.kintyrewindThe world undoubtedly needs to do more to meet energy demands and net zero targets but Kintyre seems to have its fair share of windfarms. If they are consented, though, at least it can benefit the community.Whether you love or loathe them, turbines are now a major part of the landscape of Kintyre and it is only right residents are compensated for having the natural beauty of their locality compromised on such a large scale.The people of Kintyre should be thankful to EKREG for working with partner groups to broker the best deal possible.The group#s work in securing such signicant additional funding could effect real improvements across Kintyre.

title: letters april 8 2022
story: It was great to see a local walk being promoted in last week‚Äôs Campbeltown Courier, but I was a little alarmed to see the route recommended walking through fields at lambing time.It also said most routes are suitable for dogs on leads but just the sight of a dog can cause a sheep to abort her lamb.People should absolutely enjoy the outdoors and Kintyre‚Äôs stunning scenery and history but I‚Äôd recommend completely avoiding fields where there are pregnant sheep and lambs.Over the last two years, mainly due to the failing health of my elderly parents, I have had cause to interact increasingly with many aspects of Campbeltonian society, including medical, social care, charities, neighbours and local businesses.I have been hugely impressed by the pleasant, helpful attitude displayed by the vast majority of people I have encountered.#No problem,# is often said and, indeed, meant. Many are willing to go the extra mile to help.I am pleased to congratulate, and thank, Campbeltonians for their collective attributes, which the rest of the country would do well to aspire to.I would like to set the record straight regarding South Islay Development ‚Äôs Port Ellen playing fields #community hub# development which was covered in last week‚Äôs Campbeltown Courier.I am one of the objectors who went round every door in Port Ellen. We gathered hundreds of signatures against this, which got the first lot of plans scrapped.So SID changed the plan to suit the roads department and resubmitted the planning application.Most of the objectors didn‚Äôt know they had to object again.SID didn‚Äôt knock on every door and ask how folk felt about it. They put leaflets through people#s doors and a lot of people didn‚Äôtthem.They also had open days, normally through the week, when people are working and can‚Äôt attend.And that is the reason I, for one, couldn‚Äôt attend the virtual planning, protective services and licensing committee meeting. People have full-time jobs and can‚Äôt attend these things at am on a Thursday.The community of Port Ellen is ided over this development.This was always intended to be a community space and now it‚Äôs being developed for tourism.We know and understand something has to happen in the area but it should have been to benefit the community, not more space going to tourism.The campervans are an eyesore but don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre saying we don‚Äôt want them on Islay, but there are places better suited for them outside the village.Equally, the people in these campervans will probably pick somewhere they have a good view, quiet and relaxing, rather than by the main road, where all ferry traffic passes.Islay will soon be unrecognisable, all for tourists and nothing for the locals. It will soon be another Skye.It‚Äôs unaffordable for people to come here for a week#s holiday.

title: photograph of the week april 8 2022
story: Susan took the shot last week while enjoying a walk with her dog.If you have a photograph you would like to share, please email it to editor@campbeltowncourier.

title: thought for the week april 8 2022
story: Perhaps, like mine, it‚Äôs not as good as it once was, and you forget things you should recall.Or perhaps it‚Äôs too good, and your recall things you should forget.What about God‚Äôs memory  Surely, he doesn‚Äôt forget.No, he doesn‚Äôt. Since God is eternal and therefore stands outside of time, it may be that every moment in time is always present with him.And yet, the Bible often speaks of God not remembering something ‚Äì people‚Äôs sins.One example is Jeremiah chapter  verse : ‚ÄòFor I will forgive their wickedness and will remember their sins no more.‚ÄôIt is not that God forgets in the way that I forget where I have left my wallet or car keys.In the Bible, ‚Äòto remember‚Äô is another way of talking about keeping a promise. We use ‚Äòto remember‚Äô in that way too.‚ÄòDon‚Äôt forget to phone me when you arrive home,‚Äô shouts Morag, as her daughter heads home after visiting her.‚ÄòDon‚Äôt worry, Mum. I‚Äôll remember.‚ÄôSure enough, Morag‚Äôs phone rings later, and the voice at the other ends says: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs me. I‚Äôm home.‚ÄôGod does not forget our sins in the sense of pretending they never happened or ignoring our failure and refusal to do what he wants.Instead, he remembers his promise to forgive the sins of anyone who asks him to do so.He is able to do this because Jesus has died on the cross to deal effectively with sin‚Äôs penalty.So, when you trust in Jesus, God refuses to hold your sin against you, but treats you in the way you do not deserve. He forgives you and remembers your sins no more.

title: west road overnight surfacing works rescheduled
story: Due to operational reasons, the project will now begin on Sunday, April , for  nights.No works will take place on Fridays or Saturdays. All works are expected to be complete by Monday May , subject to weather conditions.The works will be carried out using a full road closure between pm and am to protect of operatives and road users.Amnesty periods will be provided at pm, pm, midnight, am and am and road users are encouraged to arrive at the works location prior to these times to ensure they are accommodated.The A will remain open outwith working hours however, a reduced speed limit will be in place and road users should drive with care as they will be running on a temporary surface.Emergency services will be able to pass through the works at all times. Local access for residents and scheduled bus services will be maintained as far as reasonably practicable.All relevant stakeholders have been informed of the changes.Real-time journey information is available from Traffic Scotland on www.trafficscotland.org, Twitter at @trafficscotland or via the mobile site my.trafficscotland.org

title: cans films festival restocks food bank shelves
story: During the event, with its name inspired by the world-famous Cannes Film Festival, cinema-goers exchange items for the food bank for tickets to a series of special film screenings.Throughout March, musical fans swapped an estimated  to  carrier bags# worth of tins of food, packets of dried goods, toiletries, treats and more for seats at screenings of The Greatest Showman, The Wizard of Oz, Encanto and Dirty Dancing.The inaugural Cans Film Festival, held in February , was so successful there were plans to make it an annual event but this was disrupted by the Covid pandemic.The  festival was possible thanks to funding from the CalMac Community Fund, which aims to benefit the lives of people living across the west coast ferry network by helping groups working to address mental health, well-being and social isolation issues.Mhairi Hendrie from Campbeltown Picture House said: #I#d like to say a huge thank you to the more than  people who attended the screenings.#Thanks to CalMac for generously sponsoring the screenings, enabling us to make four huge donations to Kintyre Food Bank on behalf of everyone who attended.#We#re hoping to make it a regular event every year.#Mary Anne Stewart, chairperson of Kintyre Food Bank, added: #On behalf of myself, my committee and clients, I#d like to say how grateful we are for the huge generosity of the people who gave items during the festival, particularly at this time of ever-increasing crises.#It is great to have a donation like that at a time when the food bank is getting so much busier.#

title: clean sheet for pupils u13s in eight goal spectacular
story: Campbeltown Pupils sproduced a fantastic display at home last Sunday, in a Glasgow and District Youth Football League clash with Hamilton-based Accies United.The Kintyre side got off to the best possible start, going - up in the first five minutes.The first goal was scored by Jake McEachran who reacted quickly to a loose ball in the box to score with a clever overhead volley.Soon after, a penalty box clearance was charged down by Logan Norris, the ball flying into the Accies# net, quickly followed by a Ryan Johnston cross that was deflected in for an own goal.The locals continued to pin back their opponents and almost added to their lead with shots from Johnston and McEachran coming back off the bar.The continuous Pupils# pressure paid off when Rio Arkell scored a fourth, after unselfish set-up play from McEachran, before a long-distance free kick from Johnston was initially saved by the keeper before squirming over the line.Just before half time, Alan Myles in the Pupils goal tipped away a fine Accies free kick to make the half time score -.The Pupils played into a strong breeze in the second half, with keeper Myles, the back four of Robert Kerr, Liam Judge, Norris and Harvey Black, and holding midfielder Mason Graham looking to keep Accies at bay for the Pupils# first clean sheet since moving to -a-side.The Pupils continued to play good football and were rewarded midway through the half with the goal of the game, as Johnston found the top corner from  yards for a brilliant goal.Substitutes Alexander Semple, Finn McCallum and Stuart Conley came on to good effect and goals seven and eight capped off a great team performance. Taylor Purser followed up to slot the ball into the net after a good save, before a great run and fine finish by Jack Green.The young Pupils play their last home game this Saturday against league leaders Finnart s, with a .pm kick-off.

title: dunaverty am am title goes to mid argyll
story: The weather was kind on the day, with near perfect golfing conditions, and the course was fantastically turned out by greenkeepers Jonathan Barbour and Campbell MacBrayne.Scoring was low and very close, with nine teams within two shots of the winners.With a fantastic score of , the winning team of Ross Sinclair, Kenny Cameron, Scott Cameron and Roddy MacDonald, from Mid Argyll, took the title by a better inward half from Kevan Gilchrist, Graham Gilchrist, Alan Glendinning and Andy Robertson.#A great day was had by all and thanks go to Glen Scotia Distillery and its manager Iain McAlister for their fantastic support,# said a club spokesperson.#Thanks also to all the committee members for organising and running the day, the greenkeepers for the superb condition of the course and The Tea Box, under the stewardship of Rona Burton, for looking after all members and visitors.#Result:  Ross Sinclair, Roddy MacDonald, Kenny Cameron and Scott Cameron, ,¬† bih  Kevan Gilchrist, Graham Gilchrist, Alan Glendinning and Andy Robertson,   Scott MacBrayne, Peter Paterson, Mark Paterson and Grant Grant, , best last six.Spot prizes: nearest the pin in two at the first: Gus McConnachie, cm nearest the pin at the seventh: Tommy Blue, one metre nearest the pin at the th: John Marrison, three feet ladies# longest drive: Sophie Garrett gents# longest drive: David Devine,¬† Glencruitten lowest combined team score at the th: Donald Brown, Stewarton, Laurence Ferguson, Campbell McCallum and Duncan Watson III, nett  total.

title: hop on down to wee toon easter walk
story: The egg-stravaganza takes place on Easter Sunday between am and pm with the route marked out with decorated wooden eggs.#There will be  clues to solve, so remember to mark your sheets with the punch markers,# said organiser Mandy Robertson. #We will have goodie bags for about  children, so apologieswe run out.#Let‚Äôs hope we have good weather for egg hunting.#

title: big screen premiere for film making pupils
story: The children of Clachan, Rhunahaorine and Glenbarr primary schools spent ten Fridays, from September  to March , attending workshops at the cinema led by professional film-maker and animator Alasdair Satchel.The youngsters learned the fundamentals of animation, working with shapes moving through space at dferent speeds, using stop-motion.They tried their hand at creating animations using plasticine models, paper characters, #Stikbot# figures and even their fellow pupils!During one session, Jim Parkyn from Aardman Animations, the legendary studio behind Wallace and Gromit and Shaun the Sheep, joined the students to share his expertise, including how to make models from single pieces of plasticine.After experimenting with the dferent stop-motion animation techniques, the children chose their favourites and made their own animations.They also created their own soundtracks for their movies, which featured a iety of characters including unicorns, superheroes, monsters, mermaids, princesses, giraffes, turtles, frogs and much more.The schools initially received a grant from West Kintyre Windfarm Trust in January  to work on the partnership project with Campbeltown Picture House, which provided its premises and staff at a discounted rate.The pupils were supported throughout by cinema staff member Mhairi Hendrie and Eoin Bruce from Campbeltown Grammar School.It was originally hoped the project would be completed within the   session but this had to be postponed due to Covid lockdowns and restrictions.Finally, last Friday afternoon, the fruits of the pupils# labour were showcased to their families at a special screening and awards ceremony at the cinema.The event began with Clachan#s and Glenbarr#s animations, after which each pupil was presented with an Oscar-like statuette by Margaret Pratt, convener of West Kintyre Windfarm Trust.After a short interval, Rhunahaorine#s animations were screened before Mrs Pratt presented the students with their statuettes.After a round of applause for the young film-makers, Catriona Brown, head teacher of Rhunahaorine Primary School, thanked Mrs Pratt and West Kintyre Windfarm Trust, Campbeltown Picture House, particularly Miss Hendrie and manager Ellen Mainwood, Mr Satchel, Mr Bruce and all volunteer helpers from the three schools.Miss Hendrie told the Courier: #It has been a joy to work with all the children for the last few months.#Seeing them learn and make amazing animations has been a real treat. I#m so proud of what each and every one of them has achieved.#

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as ‚Äúa real dream come true‚Äù.She said: ‚ÄúWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.‚ÄùMeanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ‚Äì The Cheese Lady ‚Äì has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ‚ÄúWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.‚ÄúWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.‚ÄúAlso, I‚Äôm hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.‚ÄùSvetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ‚ÄúWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  That‚Äôs fantastic.‚ÄúAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.‚ÄùFellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ‚ÄúI think we are in a good place.‚ÄúWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!‚Äù

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than ¬£,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: ‚ÄúWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.‚ÄúMary has raised a fantastic ¬£, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.‚ÄùLast year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised ¬£, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Roman‚Äôs Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: ‚ÄúThis year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.‚ÄúI‚Äôm walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!‚ÄùPeople can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: rev-basil-clark-not-currently-active-ministry-complaint-made
story: The Very Rev Basil Clark, of Our Lady of Loretto and St Michael Catholic Church in Musselburgh and St Martins RC Church, Tranent, will not be in post while the complaint is being investigated.A spokesman for the Archdiocese of St Andrews  Edinburgh said in a statement: "A complaint has been made against a priest based in the Archdiocese of St Andrews  Edinburgh."While it is being investigated, he will not be in active ministry."No further details are being released by the Archdiocese of St Andrews  Edinburgh and the nature of the complaint has not been disclosed.The Courier has so far been unable to reach Father Clark, who lives in Musselburgh, for comment.During his absence, the parish will be administered by Father Andrew Garden of St David‚Äôs, Dalkeith.

title: airbnb-ranks-oxfordshire-town-top-easter-staycation-list--see-full-list
story: The holiday home rental company has rounded up the top  trending destinations that you can visit this Easter break.¬†Whether youre looking for a sun-soaked holiday at the seaside or youre curious to explore a popular spot closer to home, this list might just be the inspiration you need.¬†‚ÄúThe nation is set to enjoy the first Easter weekend without Covid restrictions in two years, and it‚Äôs great to see Brits are exploring up-and-coming areas of the UK to make the most of it," Amanda Cupples, General Manager for Northern Europe at Airbnb said.Dunbar. Credit: Tripadvisor Ms Cupples added: "The top trending destination list provides ample inspiration for those looking to get away and explore a new place over the long weekend.¬†‚ÄúBy visiting these local destinations,¬†Brits are supporting local economies and communities, and for those based in these destinations who are considering listing their Home on Airbnb, now is a great time to sign up.‚Äù:¬†Family friendly properties abroad in Spain, Greece and more for Easter from Vrbo:¬†Travelodge unveils Easter holiday deal with rooms for ¬£ - How to bookSee which East Lothian¬†town made the cut and how it ranked with other popular staycation destinations across the UK.¬†We cant say that were surprised to see sunny Dunbar make the list of Airbnbs top trending destinations to stay this Easter.¬†With no shortage of places to eat drink and unwind, this seaside town has plenty to offer tourists on a little Spring holiday.Find out how you can make the most of your visit on the Tripadvisor website.Its not the only beach spot to have made the rankings either with¬†Prestatyn in Wales¬†topping Airbnbs list.Not to mention,you fancy venturing down south, Lowestoft in Suffolk has also been proving popular with travellers.:¬†Best beaches in Scotland - See the top  according to Tripadvisor reviews:¬†The  best hotels in Scotland according to Tripadvisor reviews¬†Inspire your next trip by browsing the current available listings in these areas on the¬†Airbnb website.¬†Youll find everything from a secluded barn conversion in Burton Leonard to a peaceful cottage with a hot tub on¬†Loch Lomond.¬†Find out more about these properties and others like them by¬†visiting Airbnbs wishlist.

title: ormiston-manager-richie-weir-relieved-no-match-wedding
story: However, the Ormiston Football Club boss has a more important time to remember tomorrow‚Äì his wedding day at pm.He will tie the knot with Ann Clyne before jetting off on honeymoon to Las Vegas.Much to Richie‚Äôs relief, Ormiston do not have a game on Saturday, while a scheduled midweek cup clash with Dunbar United has also been pushed back.Richie and his we-to-be live in Ormiston and were looking ahead to the wedding at the Stair Arms, near Pathhhead.He said: ‚ÄúEverything is all organised.‚ÄúIt is just a case of getting stuff up to the venue and then it is just a case of getting up there.‚ÄúAnn is staying up there the night before and we are all set.‚ÄúWe have just got the usual wee bit, like cases to pack for the honeymoon, to do.‚ÄùOrmiston had been due to welcome East Lothian rivals Dunbar for the first time ever in the East of Scotland League Cup on March .However, the game was postponed and, with New Recreation Park not having floodlights, Richie was worried that the game would be rearranged for just over  hours after saying ‚ÄòI do‚Äô.Fortunately, with both teams unable to progress to the knockout stages, the game has been pushed back and a date is yet to be confirmed.Richie told the Courier: ‚ÄúAll the players are invited to the reception at night and the committee as well.‚ÄúIt was a joint decision to get the game off and make sure there were no rough players on the Saturday.‚ÄúIt was always down to be a free week but I think there was the potential to put a game in there.‚ÄúThe way the fixtures worked out, we were going to be free on Saturday anyway.‚ÄúThe way we have been the last couple of weeks with injuries, we were down to the bare bones anyway and it would have made it hard for Saturday.‚ÄùThe stretched squad even reached the stage where Richie, who works for Network Rail, had to pull on his boots for last weekend‚Äôs league tie with Coldstream.However, he was given a strict warning from his we-to-be, who works at Charles River, near Elphinstone.Forty-two-year-old Richie said: ‚ÄúI had to play  minutes and pull the boots back on.‚ÄúWe had six guys missing due to Covid, injuries, and we had a couple of guys working as well.‚ÄúOne got injured in the warm-up and had to pull out so I started the game and played the full  minutes.‚ÄúI was going to be a sub but got told by Ann: ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt come back injured, come back unscathed!‚Äô‚Äù

title: brunton-puppet-festival-music-comedy-drama
story: The Brunton is hosting Stories Just In Case, entertaining stories and puppetry for children aged four and over, presented by the Clydebuilt Puppet Theatre on Wednesday.Lempen Puppet Theatre Company brings Flotsam  Jetsam, visual theatre with original music next Saturday .The performance tells a hopeful adventure story about two very dferent creatures that must learn to work together.Other attractions at The Brunton include Irish legends The Fureys, whoto the Musselburgh theatre for a night of music, songs and stories this evening .The band, who have been entertaining audiences worldwide for  years, will sing their classics including I Will Love You, When You Were Sweet , The Green Fields of France, The Old Man, Red Rose Cafe, From Clare to Here, Her Father Didn‚Äôt Like Me Anyway, Leaving Nancy and Steal Away, plus songs from their new CD, The Times They Are A Changing.Jack Docherty , the BAFTA award-winning star of Scot Squad and Absolutely, and one of Scotland‚Äôs favourite comic performers, brings his critically acclaimed play Nothing But to The Brunton tomorrow .A love letter to Edinburgh, the Fringe and summer rain, Nothing But is a tender, playful, darkly comic tale, in which Jack grapples with lost youth, infatuation, fatherhood, sex, secrets and truth. The show achieved rave reviews and a sell-out run at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe last year.The Royal Opera House Live screening on Wednesday is The Royal Opera with Giuseppe Verdi‚Äôs La Traviata ‚Äì one of the best-known operas in the world.Set in th-century Paris, courtesan Violetta sings some of the composer‚Äôs most acclaimed arias, including Sempre libera, in her poignant and passionate encounters with Alfredo and Germont.Richard Eyre‚Äôs production for The Royal Opera recently celebrated  years on the Royal Opera House stage and this year s acclaimed opera star Pretty Yende as Violetta. The opera is sung in Italian with English subtitles.Trio Doyenne‚Äì pianist Monika Masanauskaite, violinist Michelle Dierx and Shannon Merciel on cello ‚Äì perform next Tuesdayas part of the Lunchtime Classical Concert series at The Brunton.Audiences can enjoy soup and a sandwich in the upstairs bar before an hour of classical music follows.In the programme next Tuesday is Brahms‚Äôs B minor piano trio and, as an opener, the group play a trio by the early th-century French composer Lili Boulanger, who died tragically young as she was turning into a major musical talent.The National Theatre Live screening on Thursday, April , is Henry V.Kit Harington, who became a global star after playing Jon Snow in Game of Thrones, plays the title role in Shakespeare‚Äôs study of nationalism, war and the psychology of power.Fresh to the throne, King Henry V launches England into a bloody war with France. When his campaign encounters resistance, this inexperienced new ruler must prove he is fit to guide a country into war.Captured live from Donmar Warehouse in London, this modern production, directed by Max Webster, of Le of Pi, explores what it means to be English and the relationship to Europe, asking: do we ever get the leaders we deserve Full information about these events can be found at thebruntonTickets can be purchased directly through The Brunton‚Äôs website or via the box office on   , open from Monday to Saturday, am to pm.

title: haddington-teenager-overwhelmed-meeting-hibernian-heroes
story: Lewis Kerr has been taking part in the Bridge Centre Motorcycle Project and staff at Knox Academy Meadowpark were so impressed with his efforts that they decided to mark his progress.The -year-old was rewarded with a trip to the Hibernian Training Centre at East Mains, near Ormiston.Despite many members of the Easter Road squad being on international duty, he got more than he bargained for during his visit with Paula Lackie, a school and family support worker at the Haddington school.He said: ‚ÄúI have been a season ticket holder of Hibernian Football Club since .‚ÄúMrs Lackie took me up to the training centre for a look around.‚ÄúWe weren‚Äôt expecting to see any players as it was the start of the international break.‚ÄúWe went into the main entrance and we were welcomed by one of the staff members.‚ÄúHe asked me who my favourite player was and I replied: ‚ÄòIt was Martin Boyle but now that he‚Äôs left it is probably Kevin Nisbet or Sylvester Jasper.‚Äô‚ÄúAs Mrs Lackie was talking to the staff member, Kevin Nisbet approached me on a pair of crutches.‚ÄúI asked him for a photo and he politely agreed.‚ÄúMy breathing got quicker in excitement.‚ÄúAs we were about to leave, we saw Paul McGinn and Kyle Magennis in a black car.‚ÄúI approached them and askedI could take a photo with them.‚ÄúI was overwhelmed with excitement and I can‚Äôt thank them enough for taking the time to talk and take pictures with me.‚ÄùThe teenager has been taking part in the Bridge Centre Motorcycle Project : mentoring programme.At the same time as learning motorbike skills, Lewis and his mentor focus on personal development, resilience and le skills.The programme, which takes place over a six-week period where Lewis attends the Poldrate venue every Thursday as part of a certied course, is tailored to Lewis and the personal goals that he has set.Mrs Lackie told the Courier she had noticed a real dference in Lewis since participating in the programme and wanted to mark his progress.She said: ‚ÄúLast week, I thought it would be nice to reward his excellent work with a visit to his favourite football team‚Äôs training ground.‚ÄúThis was very ad hoc and we didn‚Äôt expect what followed.‚Äù

title: young-artists-sought-design-fringe-sea-programme-cover
story: The winning entrant will be featured front and centre on the festival‚Äôs promotional material, including , programmes and posters all over East Lothian and Edinburgh.The competition is open to all primary school pupils in East Lothian and should feature a bright and colourful image that encapsulates the county, North Berwick or their favourite memories of the festival.The winner will receive FBTS show tickets and food from the festival vendors worth ¬£, as well as an FBTS t-shirt.Runners-up will receive a family ticket to one of the FBTS family events, which will be hosted between August  and .Rory Steel, festival director, said: ‚ÄúWe have run this competition over the past couple of years and the team at the festival have been blown away at the standard of entries.‚ÄúThere is certainly a lot of artistic talent amongst East Lothian children and this is a great way to keep them occupied during the Easter holidays.‚ÄùIllustrations should be submitted in a portrait orientation by Wednesday, May , to the festival office, Fringe by the Sea Competition, The Lighthouse, The Heugh, North Berwick, EH PX.All entrants should include name, school and class alongside a contact number.FBTS has already announced several acts to perform at this year‚Äôs festival including Frankie Boyle, Happy Mondays, Texas and The Manfreds.Visit fringebythesea tickets for tickets.

title: macmerry-anniversary-joy-couple-toast-60-years-together
story: Margaret, , and Leslie Somerville, , of Westbank Road, spent an afternoon with family to celebrate reaching the milestone.When asked about the secret to keeping a marriage going for so long, Margaret said that. . . there wasn‚Äôt one!She told the Courier: ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt think of anything really we are happy, and we just get on with it.‚ÄùThe couple first met ‚Äúup the dancing‚Äù in North Berwick and sparks flew.About a year later, the pair were married at the Methodist Church in Cockenzie on March , .The couple moved into their first house together in Fenton Barns shortly after, where they would raise their family.Leslie worked in the building trade, primarily with Campbell and Smith, while Margaret worked in a iety of roles but spent most of her time with GGS Engineering as a cook.The Somervilles have three children ‚Äì Yvonne, , Neil, , and Michelle,  ‚Äì and five grandchildren ‚Äì Lee, , Ryan, , Adele, , Connor, , and Shannon, .Margaret told the Courier that witnessing them all grow up and get married were the couple‚Äôs best memories.She said: ‚ÄúThe best [memory] was just seeing the family growing up and getting married.‚ÄùTheir daughter Michelle spoke of how proud she was that they had reached the milestone but also how much they had sacriced for the family over the years.She said: ‚ÄúMy dad was always working constantly to make sure we could go on holiday.‚ÄúBoth have worked all their lives but they have always been there for the family.‚Äú[I am] really proud because they‚Äôve had, like everybody, their ups and downs and the hard times, but they were always there for us.‚ÄúThey‚Äôve been together for so long and kept on going because they constantly niggle at each other!‚ÄùMichelle said that her most cherished memory of her parents was when she had her first child.She said: ‚ÄúFor me, it would be when I had my son, their first grandson, and they were fantastic, and I would probably say it was one of their proudest moments.‚ÄúThey were always there, always babysitting.‚ÄùMargaret and Leslie recently welcomed their first great-grandchild, Ellis ‚Äì and that, Michelle thinks, is one of their proudest moments.She said: ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre over the moon that they‚Äôve got a great-grandson, it was the one thing they desperately wanted.‚Äù

title: tims-tales-blackbirds-gift
story: The sunshine was breaking through the last remaining wisps of morning mist. Signs of spring, my favourite season, were visible all over our garden. The blackbird was perched on the fence and I opened the window so I could hear his song better.I watched him for a moment. He is a regular visitor but he seemed particularly vocal this morning. Then I noticed there was a female blackbird as well. I felt privileged that I could witness their visit to our small rewilded garden, which we have tried to make bird friendly.Then the singing stopped and they both seemed to be peering down at the patch of soil where we have recently planted wildflower seeds and vegetables. The male landed on the soil and began hopping in a zig-zag fashion, stopping every now and then. At first I wonderedthis was a dance to impress the female, but soon realised he was looking for breakfast.Blackbirds love earthworms and I supposed the overnight rain on the exposed soil of our newly seeded flowerbed meant it was a good moment to go hunting for his favourite food. He was looking for worms, but also listening for them, as blackbirds can hear the sound of them moving underground. I find that almost dficult to believe, but apparently it‚Äôs true. It was fascinating and joyous to watch.But I don‚Äôt knowhe caught any worms. My attention was taken by the sound of our kids getting up. School day morning routine beckoned. Time seems to vanish in the drama of it all, and so after I kissed my we goodbye as she headed for work, I quickly got busy making the kids‚Äô breakfast.It was at this moment an emotion overtook me: guilt. I often feel a sense of guilt when I know others are suffering terribly. One solution could be to disconnect from it, not think about it, or even try not to care. After all, we have our own family worries and problems to sort out.But the guilt comes from the empathy I feel and I don‚Äôt want to disconnect from that. I don‚Äôt think I could stop caring evenI tried. The world needs more empathy, not less. But there is a downside to it: it can become overwhelming and even affect my mental health.Guilt in this context is such a useless emotion. It doesn‚Äôt help those who are suffering and it certainly doesn‚Äôt help the person feeling empathy. So as my guilt arrived at the breakfast table that morning, I gave it short shrt and became determined to replace it with two things.The first was to learn the lesson the blackbird had taught me moments before, to enjoy the moment and the gts around me. It put me in mind of a beautul short film of the artist David Hockney, made by Louisiana Museum of Modern Art. It‚Äôs titled The World is Beautul and he talks about the beauty around us and that when bad news is dominating our senses, the arrival of spring is good news. The important thing is to really notice the gts around us, which Hockney says he does with ‚Äúintensity‚Äù.So I took up his advice and, on my walk to school with my son, I made sure I was fully present for him as he talked about monsters, Dr Who and his favourite scenes from Clash of the Titans. I savoured every moment of our connection and conversations.On myto the house, I made an extra effort to notice the beauty of spring‚Äôs arrival and other gts: the diamond-like sparkle of the dew drops on the grass, and the patterns made by the children running and playing amongst them, the dedication of George the lollipop man in keeping us all safe, the brief and faint rainbow in the sky above us, and the shimmer of the sea below the trees in bloom, and the yellow carpet of daffodils dancing in the breeze the birdsong, the smiles and greeting of people, the sense of community, the warmth of the sun the fact of being alive and having loved ones in my le.The walk was only four minutes, but when we notice the beauty and gts we have around us with the intensity that Hockney mentions, then we don‚Äôt measure with time.The second thing was to change my guilt into acts of compassion that can make a dference, no matter how small. Donate, write a letter, send a message of support, whatever. That way, empathy works for positive change for those in need.I already knew all this, but it seems I constantly need to relearn it. And that morning, the blackbird helped me to do so. His song was an awakening gt, his zig-zag hop across the soil a reminder that we should have moments when we pause to look and listen with ‚Äúintensity.‚ÄùAsto confirm this, he was still there on the fence when I ed home. I‚Äôd love to say he had a worm in his beak, as that would have been such a poetic ending, but he didn‚Äôt. His companion wasn‚Äôt there and he flew off as I watched him.He‚Äôd made my morning by making a positive dference in ways he will never know or understand, and not just for me.

title: pictures-thousands-new-trees-planted-butterdean
story: At the end of last month, local school groups and corporate volunteers got out their gloves, boots and shovels to help plant new trees.The trust also ran a community day on Saturday, March , that saw  people participate and help populate the wood with thousands of native trees., Abbie , Dad Corin and Daisy the dog! " alt"East Lothian Courier: This is the McCrum family of Tranent.Mum Leigh, Ella , Abbie , Dad Corin and Daisy the dog! " class"editor-image"The McCrum family of Tranent.¬† Mum Leigh, Ella , Abbie , Dad Corin and Daisy the dog!¬†Woodland Trust Scotland recently acquired two open fields adjacent to Butterdean Wood, thanks to support from Bank of Scotland. The first was planted last autumn.This time, people of all ages came out on the Saturday to help plant the new trees.Freya Brown of Pencaitland BrowniesGeorge Anderson, of Woodland Trust Scotland, said: ‚ÄúWe are so grateful that our partnership with Bank of Scotland has allowed us to add this new area of woodland.‚ÄúIt will be a marvellous haven for people and wildle but also a carbon store to help in the fight against climate change.Ben Murray, his grandad John Jeffrey and his dad Andrew Murray‚ÄúOver the week we had primary one pupils from Haddington Primary School and Bank of Scotland staff in to get spring planting started.‚ÄúThen on the Saturday,  people came to our community planting day and filled the entire field with native trees.‚ÄúWe hope everyone willto see how their trees are doing over the years.‚ÄùSouth Scotland MSP Craig Hoy was among those helping out on the dayAmong those taking part was South Scotland MSP Craig Hoy, who added: ‚ÄúThe work of Woodland Trust Scotland has been pivotal in creating, protecting and restoring native woodland heritage and fighting against climate change.‚Äù

title: thousands-spent-upgrading-dunbar-high-street-lighting
story: East Lothian Council plans to upgrade the lights over the coming months, after concerns were raised about the number of faulty lights on the street.Councillor Norman Hampshire, ward councillor and council leader, gave the update to Dunbar Community Council last month.He said: ‚ÄúWe have got an agreement to replace all fittings.‚ÄúThey are going to be LED lights and they are looking at dferent options.‚ÄùOne of the issues is that High Street ‚Äì and much of Dunbar to the north-east of the East Coast Mainline ‚Äì falls within the town‚Äôs conservation area.Changes to the look of the street lights would need to receive approval from East Lothian Council‚Äôs planning department.Mr Hampshire said that the design had ‚Äúto match in with the streetscape‚Äù.He said: ‚ÄúThe intention is as soon as they get that then they will replace all the light fittings.‚ÄùIt is hoped that modernising the lights will also lessen the cost of maintenance.A spokeswoman for the local authority confirmed that work was due to take place this summer.She said: ‚Äú¬£, was the estimate for full new replacement.‚ÄúHowever, we have been offered a retrofit solution from the original supplier .‚ÄúIt‚Äôs much cheaper at about ¬£, and there is currently a - week delivery, so hoping to have this completed July August .‚Äù

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-1997-1972-1922
story: ‚ÄòTENT slashing brought terror for children‚Äô was the front page headline on the April ,  edition of the East Lothian Courier.A fun night camping in the back garden turned to terror for three young friends last week, when a thug slashed at their tent with a kne ‚Äì narrowly missing one of the children.The unknown attacker slashed through the fly sheet of the small tent as Martin Runciman, , his cousin, Daniel McFarlane, and Paul Harvey, both aged , screamed with fright.The mindless attack lasted for less than a minute, before the culprit escaped over the garden fence.Later the youngsters found a kne nearby and handed it to police probing the incident, believing it may have been dropped by the man as he fled.Martin, at whose home in Gardiner Crescent, Prestonpans, the attack occurred, has been left shaken by the incident....and  years ago‚ÄòIncrease in Ranco labour force is marvellous news‚Äô said the East Lothian Courier on April , .The news that another  jobs are to be made available at Haddington by American-owned firm of Ranco Motors Ltd., was welcomed this week as a shot in the arm for the employment situation in the County as well as the town.Provost A. F. Spowage of Haddington commented: ‚ÄúI think this is really marvellous news. We had heard some time ago in the Council that this would probably be coming off but we were not sure.‚ÄúThis is really a vote of confidence in the company here. From the employment aspect at a time like this it could not be better. It will help the employment situation in the County and not only Haddington.‚ÄùThe announcement that more workers would be taken on at Haddington ‚Äì where Ranco Motors had premises at Hospital Road and the Dunbar Road ‚Äì came close on the heels of the disclosure that the company‚Äôs Tannochside factory in Lanarkshire is to shut later this year....and  years agoA NUMBER of housebreakings were reported in Dunbar, reported The Haddingtonshire Courier on April , .During the weekend, four cases of housebreaking, extending over three nights, were reported to the police.Two private houses and a hotel in the east end of the town, and a smith‚Äôs shop at Broxburn were entered and ious articles stolen.No trace of any suspicious person could be found until on Monday morning it was discovered that a man had been living unobserved in an unaccompanied house, laying low during the day, and, it was suspected, sallying forth at night.

title: made-east-lothian-invite-people-get-creative
story: MADE in East Lothian launched its Creative Connections scheme at the end of last month.The Haddington-based social enterprise held an open day and is looking for people to promote its ethos of make, create and reuse.Fiona Lambert, MADE in East Lothian director, was working on upcycling a well-loved rocking horse as a project commissioned by a member of the public.A series of events and workshops are planned over the next six months to encourage creativity within the East Lothian community and to support local artists and makers.For more information, go to madeineastlothian.org

title: medical-practice-promoting-cold-water-swimming-aid-health
story: Swim-in-the-sea sessions kickstarted on Friday at am and will continue at the same time each week at the Boatshore, Cockenzie.A spokesperson said: ‚ÄúWe are pretty convinced about the benefits of cold-water swimming for both our physical and mental health.‚ÄúIt seems particularly helpful in managing feelings of stress, anxiety, panic attacks and low mood‚ÄúThere is also a growing body of evidence that it can help painful conditions including fibromyalgia and might even boost our immune systems.‚ÄùThe surgery recommends attendees bring a towel, warm clothes and a hot drink with them and has posted additional safety advice on its website.

title: david-allan-tributes-paid-former-preston-lodge-head-teacher
story: Headteacher of Preston Lodge High School from  to , he made a major contribution to the le of the school and the community it serves.Mr Allan, described as Preston Lodge ‚Äúthrough and through‚Äù, has been fondly remembered by current and former staff, as well as former students and their families.Born in , David attended Preston Lodge High School himself, excelling in sport he became captain of the senior rugby team before also becoming captain of the cricket team.He also enjoyed a successful athletics career during his years at school, and was house captain of Grange.Mr Allan studied chemistry at the University of Edinburgh before training as a teacher at Moray House, saying at the time: ‚ÄúFor me there was never any choice. It had always been my ambition to teach.‚ÄùFollowing five years at George Heriot‚Äôs School in Edinburgh, Mr Allan ed to Preston Lodge as head of science.It wasn‚Äôt long before he had climbed the ranks, and he was appointed headteacher in .He said then: ‚ÄúI am tremendously excited, but a little frightened when I think that I have achieved the actual job of running the school involving teachers who taught me.‚ÄùThroughout Mr Allan‚Äôs  years in the role, many positive changes were introduced and the headteacher gained a strong reputation within and beyond the community, with his enthusiasm ‚Äúbringing the best out of a whole generation of students‚Äù.A minute‚Äôs applause was held for Mr Allan at a recent Preston Lodge RFC game.A spokesperson said: ‚ÄúWe were saddened to hear of the passing of our former president, Mr David Allan, last week ‚Äì a man who gave so much to PLRFC.‚ÄúThank you all for joining our minute of applause at Saturday‚Äôs st XV fixture at the Pennypit. Our sincere condolences to the Allan family.‚ÄùCurrent Preston Lodge headteacher Gavin Clark thanked Mr Allan for all his contributions to the school.Mr Clark said: ‚ÄúDavid Allan was a stalwart of the Prestonpans community and a PLer through and through. He will be hugely missed.‚ÄúAs Preston Lodge‚Äôs headteacher, he shaped and developed a school culture which everyone still benefits from.‚ÄúDavid was a man of clear views and high standards, but was also a man of great personality and humanity. His care for the staff, students and families he worked with made PL what it is today.‚ÄùMr Clark went on to explain that, beyond his time at Preston Lodge, Mr Allan stayed connected to the school, adding: ‚ÄúI was lucky to be able to learn from his insight and wisdom about our community and about PL‚Äôs proud past. His legacy lives on at PL, for sure, and our thoughts are with his family at this dficult time.‚ÄúThank you, David, for everything that you did for Preston Lodge and everyone connected to our school.‚ÄùTributes flooded on to social media, with former Preston Lodge student Audrey Mackay saying: ‚ÄúHe was a truly respected man.‚ÄúAn excellent chemistry teacher and he gained my huge respect as a headteacher by showing fair strictness and understanding which was needed at that time.‚ÄúSorry to hear of his death. He taught me a lot which I didn‚Äôt realise at the time. Thoughts with his family.‚ÄùChris Horton added: ‚ÄúA lovely level-headed man. Our sons liked him too.‚ÄúRIP Davey Allen: you really were a lovely man and a great headmaster.‚ÄúEveryone had respect for you.‚ÄùAnother former student, Mary Johnston, said: ‚ÄúRIP Mr Allan: you got me a job when I left school at , I was there for  years. Condolences to all the family.‚ÄùMr Allan passed away on March .

title: county-man-shortlisted-fisherman-year
story: Fishing is very much in the blood for -year-old Rowan Davies, with a long line of fishing and leboat heritage coming from both sides of his family.The Dunbar resident started in the family business as a -year-old, helping out with landing the catch.By the age of , he was giving up his summer holidays to go out fishing.He officially joined the family vessel Spitfire seven years ago.Now, he has been shortlisted for the Fishing News Young Fisherman of the Year Award.Rowan was nominated for his ‚Äúoutstanding commitment to the job and the boat, giving up his free time to learn and better himself every day‚Äù.On hearing of his nomination, he said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs absolutely fantastic.‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe it. I‚Äôm over the moon.‚ÄùWith awards in  categories this year, the Fishing News Awards  recognise outstanding achievement across all areas of the UK and Irish commercial fishing industry in .The Young Fisherman of the Year Award, sponsored by Seafish, recognises a fisherman under  years of age on December , , and based in the UK or Ireland, who has demonstrated outstanding skill, commitment and determination to succeed in the industry.Voting is open until midnight on Monday.The winners of this year‚Äôs Fishing News Awards will be announced at a gala presentation ceremony in Aberdeen on May .Visit fishingnews awards for more information or to vote.

title: north-berwick-too-good-leave-out-named-one-best-places-live-scotland
story: The town proved ‚Äúto be too good to leave out‚Äù, as it was named among the seven best towns across Scotland, despite losing its  crown as the very best in Scotland to the Isle of Bute.:¬†North Berwick named the best place to live in Scotland by The Sunday TimesIn the guide, North Berwick is described as the ‚Äújewel of the East Lothian coast‚Äù, with its High Street filled with independent shops, quality schools and seaside culture all commended, alongside its transport links to Edinburgh.The Sunday Times Best Places to Live Guide is an annual list that analyses towns, cities and areas across the UK in a wide range of criteria to find the most sought-after places to live.The list is compiled by experts, taking into account traditional factors such as schools, transport, house prices and greenspace, as well as the local culture, community spirit and even the quality of the broadband.Judy Lockhart-Hunter, chairperson of North Berwick Community Council , said: "NBCC is slightly disappointed that we have lost out on the top spot, having won so many of these polls recently!"In all seriousness, though, it is fantastic that our town is getting so much national recognition and we were thrilled to hear that the Sunday Times poll rated us so highly."We are very lucky to live in such a wonderful place with lots of opportunities, stunning views and a community spirit like no other."Helen Davies, The Times and Sunday Times property editor, said: ‚ÄúThe Sunday Times Best Places to Live list is necessarily subjective.‚ÄúLeave it just to statistics and you will never capture the spirit of a place.‚ÄúFor that, you need to visit to take into account that ‚Äòyou have to be here‚Äô feeling.‚ÄúIs the pub dog-friendly, for example  Can you live car-free  What are the schools and houses like  Is it multicultural and multigenerational, and can it offer a good way of le to lots of dferent sorts of people ‚ÄúTen years ago, when we launched the inaugural list, London‚Äôs gravitational pull was strong, the WFHrevolution had not yet reached our doorstep and high streets were stacked with chains.‚ÄúHow times have changed ‚Äì and how welcome that change is.‚ÄúThis year, we have discovered new best places to live, from resurgent city centres in the North, rejuvenated suburbs across the country, hidden villages in the Southwest, and a commutable Scottish island.‚ÄùThe overall UK winner was Ilkley in West Yorkshire.The full list of Scottish winners, in alphabetical order is as follows:

title: three-course-meal-served-raise-money-charity
story: Our Community Kitchen has been working for about four years to try to tackle social isolation in Haddington and the surrounding area.The group meets in the town‚Äôs bowling club and is serving up to try to raise funds.Carrot and lentil soup will be followed by either prime roast beef, Yorkshire pudding, roast potatoes and buttered vegetables with a beef and red wine gravy, or vegetarian lasagne with roast potatoes and garlic bread.Sticky toffee pudding with ice cream will be followed by tea and coffee.The meal, which costs ¬£ per person, is served next Sundayfrom .pm.For more information, call  .

title: paul-mclennan-msp-column-keeping-promise
story: This is all about tackling the challenges facing care-experienced young people.The Scottish Government remains committed to Keeping the Promise and creating a care system that places love and relationships at the centre for every child and family who needs support.Last week, I attended a Parliamentary reception for STAF , hosted by Paul O‚ÄôKane MSP.It was a fantastic event and we heard from people in the sector, caregivers, those with lived experience and the Deputy First Minister. The passion was clear from all about getting this right.The Scottish Government has shown that supporting care-experienced young people is a top priority.One example is care-experienced student bursaries, where a higher-rate of student support funding has been made available to care-experienced students in higher and further education.The Scottish Government has also increased the value of eight Scottish social security benefits by six per cent, including Best Start Grants and Carer‚Äôs Allowance Supplement, to keep pace with rising costs. The ambition is clear to support care-experienced young people from the start, through their most formative years and beyond.Family support is one of the five main priority areas for the Promise.I was delighted to hear of the introduction of new Whole Family Wellbeing Funding of at least ¬£m over the course of this Parliament, which will enable the building of universal, holistic support services, available to children across Scotland.These services need to be designed locally, with clear input from carers, and prevent,we can, young people entering into care. I am already engaging with the council in this regard.

title: easter-activities-near-national-trust-events-including-easter-egg-hunts-east-lothian
story: Trying to keep your little ones entertained can be eggs-haustingat the best of times which is why we‚Äôre sharing a little inspiration to help keep them occupied over the break.Here are some of the spring activities that you and the family can get up to including everything from Easter egg hunts to fun family-friendly crafts."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "UK Bank Holidays ","description": "All the bank holiday dates in the UK in ","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media yJjFhj poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests yJjFhj.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.eastlothiancourier video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "East Lothian Courier","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.eastlothiancourier sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Here‚Äôs a selection of the National Trust for Scotlands Easter activities that the whole family can try in East Lothian.Newhailes House and Gardens in Musselburgh are open across Easter for lots of family fun.The stunning Palladian mansion is hosting an Easter egg trail across the weekend from April -- with ious times available.Tickets for the Easter Egg Hunt start at ¬£ and can be purchased through the National Trust for Scotland website.:¬†Travelodge unveils Easter holiday deal with rooms for ¬£ - How to book:¬†Easter : Luxury Easter Eggs from Hotel Chocolat, Thorntons, Fortnum and Mason and moreTake a Spring stroll through the Inveresk Lodge Garden, located just south of Musselburgh.¬†Theres a¬†discovery trail for children where they can spot all of the flora and fauna andyou come prepared with your own net, you can go pond dipping too.¬†Alternatively, once youve finished exploring Newhailes House, the th-century designed woodland landscape is ideal for working up an appetite for the delights of the¬†Stables Caf√©.Colourful Easter eggs in Easter crafts set. title: wordle-293-april-8-wordle-word-hints-todays-answer
story: The aim of the game is to find a  letter word in only six attempts.The game uses the same rules as Scrabble, where only real words are allowed both in guesses and the result.If you get a letter in the right spot and form the correct word, the square turns green.Butthe guessed letter is in the word but not in the right spot, the square turns yellow.Letters that are wrong turn grey to help the process of elimination for the six tries.If you‚Äôre still trying to save your streak, then don‚Äôt scroll down yet, maybe some hints will send you on your way.Today‚Äôs word starts with the letter S¬†and ends with the letter E.It has two vowels.It is another word for frighten.What is today‚Äôs Wordle answer, Friday, April  If you have given up on today‚Äôs game, then we can save you the misery. But those still trying to crack the -letter code, look away now.¬†¬†¬†The Wordle for April  is SCARE.¬†¬†The game was created by software engineer, Josh Wardle, who recently announced he had sold the popular word game to the New York Times.In a statement on Twitter he wrote: ‚ÄúSince launching Wordle, I have been in awe of the response of everyone that has played.‚ÄúThe game has gotten bigger than I ever imagined .‚ÄúIt has been incredible to watch the game bring so much joy to so many and I feel so grateful for the personal stories some of you have shared with me ‚Äì from Wordle uniting distant family members, to provoking friendly rivalries, to supporting medical recoveries.‚ÄúOn the flip side, I‚Äôd be lyingI said this hasn‚Äôt been overwhelming.
