title: new coxswain for lerwick lifeboat
story: A new full-time coxswain has been appointed to the Lerwick leboat.Twenty-nine-year-old Stephen Manson starts in the role today , replacing Darren Harcus who has taken up another coxswain#s role within RNLI.Mr Manson originally trained as a vehicle mechanic and has been recently employed on workboats in the salmon industry.He has been part of the volunteer crew on the Lerwick leboat since October , and will now take up a full-time role at the station.After undertaking training in the coming months he will take command of the leboat during future launches.Mr Harcus, who has been Lerwick coxswain since , has been appointed full-time resilience coxswain for the north of Scotland # providing relief coxswain work wherever he is needed.Lerwick leboat operations manager Malcolm Craigie said: #I‚Äôm delighted that Stephen and Darren have both been appointed to these full-time roles # they‚Äôre both experienced and capable members of our leboat crew.#We rely on full-time crew members to train and support our volunteer crews and to keep the leboat ready for launch  .#..Volunteer lesavers put their navigational skills to festive use by mapping out a Christmas tree design.Tributes have been paid to the brave lesaver Billy Deacon on the th anniversary of his tragic death. Lerwick RNLI issued a post of remembrance#Aith Leboat volunteers spent  hours at sea yesterdayhelping to recover a whitefish trawler which had lost power and was taking on water#Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: tobar an dualchais what can proverbs tell us about
story: An T√¨r, An C√†nan, ‚ÄòS na DaoineIn recent years, interest in this concept has been growing exponentially, with a iety of groups recognising its importance as a sense of place and belonging or identying it as the rootedness us modern people are understandably desperate for. which Edward Dwelly noted in his dictionary.The Place of one#s birth.Heredity, native or hereditary temper, spirit or blood.Visage, countenance.Hereditary right. could be one of the cornerstones of a reconstructed Gaelic worldview. The identity of a person could undoubtedly be forged by the place of their birth and the community of that place, particularly at a time in the past when populations were less mobile.The traits of a person‚Äôs parents manest in their physical appearance their spirit, likes and dislikes, and sometimes even interests or inclinations might appear hereditary ‚Äì not just from mother and father but perhaps from an ancestor remembered only by name and special characteristic, like poesy or craft skill..The failure by clan chiefs and other landed gentry to recognise this customary right held by the people since time immemorial underpins the Clearances, while demands for its recognition echo through much of the collective action undertaken against this violence, trauma, and dispossession. as far back in history as I can.The world and society these people lived in was so dferent to ours today, making context crucial to understanding the words being used and the philosophy from which they derive.Aside from the multitude which are in still in use today, there are published proverb collections as well as countless sound recordings, many digitized and made easily accessible by Tobar an Dualchais.By their nature proverbs cut across boundaries of class and gender, their survival relying upon oral transmission, on being commonly known in a community and thus reflecting its values. They are that memorable phrase we hear our elders say once they have explained its meaning to us, we are unlikely to forget it.Theyto us often and roll off the tongue.One of the most important collections of Gaelic proverbs was published in  by Alexander Nicolson .However, Nicolson was merely re-printing a collection made by Donald Macintosh, a Perthshire-born clergyman, first printed in Edinburgh in . Nicolson called the collection ‚Äúa genuine product of the past‚Äù with Macintosh merely acting as collator and translator. of Islay, perhaps coined in the times when the MacLeans, MacDonalds, and later Campbells feuded over the island the second one is a rhyme about the MacAlpines, their former seat in Dunstaffnage, and their ancient claim to the throne of Scotland:When the natives forsake Islay, farewell the peace of Scotland!Children of the native kings, Who reigned down at Dunstaffnage, Who first the crown of Alba owned, And still have native claim to it..It also tells us that there are always grave, far-reaching political consequences whenever an indigenous population is forced to abandon its home.as a hereditary right can last for centuries. The strength of attachment to people and place shines through both.Blood is stronger than breeding., ‚Äòblood is thicker than water‚Äô, and perhaps it should come as no surprise to us that a society which places strong emphasis on ancestry and blood ties should have so many proverbs reinforcing such beliefs..Sad is the inheritance of a bad disease.This proverb is the perfect reminder that not everything we inherit from our ancestors is good. Psychologically and spiritually, we inherit their trauma physically, as the proverb reminds us, we may inherit their medical conditions.By accepting the full extent of our inheritance ‚Äì strength and weakness, the beautul and the ugly ‚Äì we grow closer to our ancestors and empower ourselves to heal from what they could not.has always been characterised by plurality and complexity, reflecting the complex G√†idhealtachd to which it belonged.For centuries, fostering children has been an important feature of Gaelic society, and for all the influence that DNA can have on us, the nurture we receive during our formative years has just as much ‚Äìnot more ‚Äì influence on who we become within our community.In a changing world, it is inspiring to see people across the G√†idhealtachd connecting with the cultural ‚Äòmycelium‚Äô of their place and rooting themselves in it, whether it is their ancestral homeland or adoptive home.can be a wellspring of transformative energy for place-based revitalisation.Sometimes it seems to burst like lightning, explosively cleaving through adversity. But it is also the stream ‚Äì the carrying stream ‚Äì slowly weathering stone, flowing ever on from generation to generation.

title: editorial budhmor decision must be
story: An T√¨r, An C√†nan, ‚ÄòS na DaoineJust  weeks‚Äô notice has been given to families to make new arrangements for their loved ones, and while staff have apparently been offered alternative positions, there is considerable anger and upset among workers who have served the home and those who have lived in it with diligence and compassion over many years. adds our voice in support, and in doing so raises further questions about the provision of care for the region‚Äôs elderly.Not so very long ago there were residential care homes in just about every district of Skye and Lochalsh # in Staffin, Struan, Dunvegan, Uig, Broadford and Dornie.But changing regulations on facilities and staff were not sufficiently accompanied by support for the owners to make the transition the new rules demanded of them. It is now surely a matter of huge regret for our communities that so many small-scale care providers # despite their good reputation and obvious appeal in rural parts of the country ‚Äì have been allowed to wither on the vine and disappear. on standards which followed the Covid outbreak in April and May .Budhmor‚Äôs owners are not a shadowy offshore conglomerate trying to put profit before care ‚Äì but CrossReach, the social arm of the Church of Scotland. Despite their benevolent roots, the modern pressures facing the sector, they say, simply make it too dficult to keep their Portree home open.The building needs too much work and they don‚Äôt have the money to pay for it.The only option, families were told, is closure ‚Äì with the suggestion that the  residents could all be accommodated nearby in a refurbished and expanded Home Farm.It is not dficult to understand why families are so aggrieved at this proposal.Things may well have improved at Home Farm since the horrors of Covid, but have all the lessons been learned The blanket national policy of shting patients from hospitals to care homes in the frantic weeks of early  was a huge factor in the devastating Covid death toll that followed.Yet now, with the pandemic still not behind us, families in Skye are being told they should accept the transfer en masse of their elderly relatives to the very home so ravaged by coronavirus when it was proven to be over capacity and understaffed.At Budhmor, they managed to keep the home safe from the worst of Covid-. Relatives of residents will tell you that was no fluke ‚Äì but down to good standards, diligent management and conscientious staff.There will be some truth in the financial and staffing pressures that CrossReach cite in their reasons for closure. But two years on from the outset of Covid, should the sector not be doing all it can to preserve and build on the success of an institution which proved such a good example during the pandemic, rather than bowing to the bottom line and accepting its loss.There is also the matter of an options appraisal on health and care needs in the north of Skye, currently being prepared by NHS Highland.Closure must at the very least be halted until this review is complete ‚Äì andthis requires support for CrossReach, our Government should find it.In the longer term what we really need are alternative models to those that are currently governed by economies of scale than on inidual or community needs. An agenda of rationalisation and centralisation has taken hold of far too many of our public services and is ultimately driving decisions like the closure of small care facilities offering a homely, personalised environment in favour of a vast, but possibly distant one many miles from an inidual‚Äôs home community.No-where has this been more obvious, or dangerous, than in the west Highland health and care sector.We should start the fightback by backing Budhmor care home, and keeping it open.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220407newsthe people you are visiting may be particularly vulnerable
story: The public has been urged to keep wearing face coverings when visiting hospitals, care homes and other health and care settings. The appeal from the Chief Medical Officer comes with reports of a decline in wearing of face coverings by visitors. Professor Sir Michael McBride said: ‚ÄúThe COVID- Omicron iant is extremely infectious and, despite best efforts, can spread quickly in health and social care settings. ‚ÄúPlease remember to wear a face covering when you are visiting. The people you are coming to see may be particularly vulnerable to the virus - as may other patients or residents. ‚ÄúAlso, do not visityou have symptoms of respiratory infection.‚Äù The Chief Medical Officer added: ‚ÄúWearing a face covering remains an important way to protect others, as well as yourself. Public health advice continues to encourage their use in everyday le. That also includes on public transport and in any indoor busy setting - especiallythey are not well ventilated.‚Äù

title: education minister visits ballymena primary school
story: EDUCATION Minister Michelle McIlveen paid a recent visit to Ballymena Primary School.During the visit on March  the Minister spoke to members of the student bodies active within the school which included the School Council, Eco-Council and Digital Leaders. She witnessed children engaging in ICTlessons, in play sessions both indoor and outdoor and spoke extensively to staff on the Special Needs team. The pastoral and Mental Health programmes within the school were of interest to Minister McIlveen as well as how children had found theto face-to-face learning after Lockdowns. The Minister also enjoyed seeing a class making toast around the fire pit as part of their Forest School activities and was shown the continual development in children‚Äôs outdoor learning in the school which the staff were finding to have had a positive impact upon their well-being and academic achievement.The Minister was initially due to visit Ballymena Primary School as part of their ceremony to celebrate an outdoor play award called TOPS back in October . Due to ious Assembly commitments the Minister had been unable to visit until now and was keen to honour a promise made to visit what was the first primary school of the town established back in . Minister McIlveen was pleasantly surprised by the extensive, bright and modern interior of the school which was not immediately evident from outside and complimented the children on their behaviour, enthusiasm and sense of responsibility. The children of the school were happy to welcome Minister McIlveen and staff were delighted to be able to share some of the developments and progress made within the school due to the hard work and dedication of the staff.Principal, Mrs Ritchie said: ‚ÄúWe were so pleased to welcome the Education Minister to Ballymena Primary School on Wednesday as a way of celebrating all of the continued hard work and advances within the school. ‚ÄúThe Minister was happy to engage with the children and staff and asked interested questions around child development and we were keen to display as many aspects of our educational provision as time would allow.‚Äù

title: daria through to miss ni final
story: A former pupil of Patricks College in Ballymena has made it through to the final of the Miss Northern Ireland competition.Daria Gapska, a -year-old childrens nursing student, recently ed to the college for a presentation to Year  on her chosen charity Braveheartsni.Daria was one of two finalists to be crowned at the first live Miss World Northern Ireland Heat of  in Nu Delhi, Belfast in front of an an astute judging  which included Managing Director of ACA models and Event organiser Victoria Withers. The event saw girls from across Northern Ireland compete for their place at the Miss World Northern Ireland final.Daria was crowned as Miss Nu Delhi and Poppy Smith a  year old Biomedical Science student from Portadown was crowned as Miss Belfast. St Patricks College congratulated their former pupil on her success in the competition.The school said: ‚ÄúDaria has chosen Braveheartsni as her charity. It is a charity very close to our hearts as founder, Shealyn Caulfield is also a past pupil. ‚ÄúDaria did an excellent presentation on the charity to our Year  pupils and will present this to other Year Groups next week.‚ÄúWe wish her all the best with her preparations for the Miss Northern Ireland final.‚ÄùBraveheartsni is Northern Ireland‚Äôs only charity supporting the needs of teenagers and young adults with Adult Congenital Heart Disease.The charity has grown from the strong volunteer ethos of HeartbeatNI who are also a local volunteer charity who support families with children with congenital heart disease.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220410newscurry s fun park opens in portrush
story: AFTER months of waiting, Currys Fun Park in Portrush is finally open! The eagerly anticipated successor to the popular Barrys Amusements opened its doors for the first time on Saturday amid great excitement. Hundreds of people young and old filed through the doors all afternoon as the magic ed to Portmagic - and just in time for Easter. The good news is that Currys is now up and running, boasting all the old Barrys favourites and adding some new ones too. And for those with old Barrys tokens - no, you cant use them, but you can help the RNLI by dropping them into collection boxes dotted around the complex. The fun park has chosen the charity as its partner - a thoughtful gesture given the important work volunteers do in the waters off the north coast. But for now, after two years of zero craic because of the pandemic, all roads lead to the Port and what promises to be a fun-filled holiday period. Happy days.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220410newsfamiliar faces on this week s rare breed
story: UTV‚Äôs hit farming series, ‚ÄòRare Breed - A Farming Year‚Äô, s on Tuesday th April at pm. The families are bringing in their ious harvests and making preparations for next year. It‚Äôs October, and on the shores of Strangford Lough the Elliott family rear turkeys. The family have years of experience looking after the birds and yet Mark and Olive are still fascinated by their behaviour. Olive comments that they are ‚Äòextremely inquisitive‚Äô. While Mark is making sure the turkeys are well fed, his mum Olive can‚Äôt help giving them an extra treat. She comments too, ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt do without my family, I have to be so nice to them at the minute!‚Äù Mark points out that they have been receiving orders for Christmas since August, which is ‚Äòabsolutely nuts.‚Äô Near Kilcoo in the Mourne Mountains, Aine Devlin is preparing her flock for the most critical part of her farming year- breeding season. Aine is keeping an eye on her rams to make sure they‚Äôre doing their job. She coats their chests with paint to see which ewes they have been with. Aine laughs, ‚ÄúThis is his cologne for the girls!‚Äù For her AI is not the way to go as the ewes would then all lamb on the same day on the mountain. She loves this time of year and is proud of the part she plays in the economy. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs better than buying produce from down the road from your neighbours and local communities ‚Äù she says. Outside Crossgar, Richard Orr is thinking ahead to next year‚Äôs wheat crop. It‚Äôs all about the planning and attention to detail to make sure the groundwork is done right. He‚Äôs conscious of the environment, saying, ‚ÄúThe major thing in the world is carbon footprint. Chemicals have made farming easy, and modern machinery has damaged the structure of the soil - we need to rebuild that.‚Äù Meanwhile, just outside Portadown it‚Äôs all hands on deck for apple harvest at the McKeever family farm. There isn‚Äôt a high yield this year but sometimes things not going to plan can be a blessing. Pat talks about the seven to eight weeks of hell and this year pickers have been hard to get. Peter comments, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs half the battle when you have good people around.‚Äù On the Donegal   Londonderry border, potato farmer Jamie Rankin and his team are coming towards the end of their harvest. He enjoys the early starts and says, ‚ÄúWhat you do before dinner time‚Äôs your day‚Äôs work.‚Äù While it‚Äôs a job Jamie enjoys, it also comes with challenges as winter months close in. The bad weather has led to reduced yields and a late harvest, but he‚Äôs very proud to have produced a good crop. UTV‚Äôs Mark McFadden narrates the series. Sponsored by Moy Park, ‚ÄòRare Breed ‚Äì A Farming Year‚Äô continues on Tuesday th April at pm on UTV.

title: new belfast transport hub to be named belfast grand central station
story: Artist impression of the new Belfast Transport Hub which will be situated on Translink property near the current Europa Buscentre and Great Victoria Street Stations. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueArtist impression of the new Belfast Transport Hub which will be situated on Translink property near the current Europa Buscentre and Great Victoria Street Stations.Niamh CampbellTwitterEmailApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailBelfast‚Äôs new transport hub will be officially named Belfast Grand Central Station, Translink has confirmed.Work on the south Belfast station began in February and is expected to open by .¬†The major infrastructural scheme led by Northern Ireland‚Äôs public transport provider stretches across , sqft, replacing the existing Europa and Great Victoria Street bus and rail stations.¬†When completed, it will become¬†the largest integrated transport hub on the island of Ireland.The hub will provide  bus stands, eight¬†railway s and an enhanced walking and cycling connectivity across the city.When the ¬£m project was announced in , Translink said the project would create  new jobs.Infrastructure Minister Nichola Mallon, who visited the project‚Äôs building site earlier this year, described it¬†as ‚Äúexciting‚Äù and said it will be a ‚Äúgame changer‚Äù for Northern Ireland.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up ‚ÄúI have been clear that we need to see an increase in the use of public transport and encourage more people to consider active travel options so that we can tackle the climate crisis,‚Äù she said.‚ÄúTo achieve that we need to have the right infrastructure in place.‚ÄùAnother project running alongside the Transport Hub at Weavers Cross close to Sandy Row will also regenerate the .m square foot brownfield site in the area.Ms Mallon added: ‚ÄúWith an expected annual footfall of over  million, this important NI Executive flagship project will bring a host of benefits to support the economy.‚ÄúIt will improve connectivity for everyone in Northern Ireland and beyond, and will be a key driver of social, economic and environmental wellbeing for the local and wider community.On Thursday, Translink tweeted that the new Grand Central¬†is being ‚Äúcelebrated with community engagement, through an innovative ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs Grand‚Äô Story Board at Europa Bus Centre‚Äù.¬†The new station is also only a stone‚Äôs throw away from the Hastings-owned Grand Central Hotel, which opened on Bedford Street in .The name itself is full of history, as the city‚Äôs first Grand Central Hotel¬†was opened on Royal Avenue in June  by Downpatrick man John Robb.He had originally planned to develop a huge central railway terminus on the site ‚Äì¬†based on New York#s famous Grand Central Station ‚Äì¬†but failed to get support¬†from local politicians at the time.It closed its doors in  when the Troubles broke out and¬†was later taken over by the Army in  for use as a base, eventually being¬†demolished in the late s. The site is now home to the Castle Court shopping centre.The train station formerly known as Belfast Central, which is located on Bridge Street in the Laganside area of the city, was renamed Lanyon Place four years ago.¬†Most ReadVideo: Feral teenagers‚Äô attack on police in Co Down village caught on cameraCharity fight event in Belfast marred by violence outside hotelBelfast paedophile brothers Gary and Gregory Rea shocked to be shunned by neighboursMan arrested after street brawl on Belfast‚Äôs Dublin RoadDecoratordenies that he ripped off almost  pensionersTop VideosPlayFootage of an attack on police in Killough Co DownPlayPolice attend fatal road collison on Toome BypassPlayThe Derry Girlsjourneyand what next for the showLatest Northern IrelandAntrim manager Elaine Dowds praises players after battling defeat by WexfordWoman in s dies in Newry while waiting for an ambulance from BelfastViewpointOpinionWheel of fortune turns full circle for Portrush‚ÄòA dream come true‚Äô ‚Ä¶ artist Jacqueline Rooney on her Jay Blades dealLosing weight  It‚Äôs a cinch!.. Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium NI Civil Service chief apologises to senior whistleblower vet hounded out of jobExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseDr Tamara Bronckaers FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDr Tamara BronckaersSam McBrideTwitterEmailApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe head of the Northern Ireland Civil Service has issued an ‚Äúunreserved apology‚Äù to a civil servant hounded out of her job because she blew the whistle on potential fraud and animal suffering and attempted to enforce the law.On Thursday, the Belfastrevealed that the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairshas abandoned its attempt to overturn a devastating industrial tribunal judgment that a senior vet in his department, Tamara Bronckaers, was effectively sacked ‚Äî and was treated appallingly by one of Stormont‚Äôs most senior officials who remains in post.Seven months ago, an industrial tribunal unanimously found that Tamara Bronckaers, a senior vet at DAERA with an ‚Äúexemplary performance and record‚Äù, had been effectively sacked because she blew the whistle on potential fraud and animal suffering.However, rather than accept a verdict which was devastating for the credibility of Northern Ireland‚Äôs chief vet, Robert Huey, and the department, DAERA instead appealed the verdict to the Court of Appeal ‚Äî a highly unusual decision, which would only succeedthe judge who heard the case had made major errors.Read MoreStormont department apologises and drops its legal challenge over whistleblowerBut last week the department suddenly U-turned to abandon its protracted and expensive fight which taxpayers have funded and is likely to cost well over ¬£ million. DAERA instead struck a deal with Dr Bronckaers which will involve the department admitting that the original judgment was right, and paying her a huge sum in compensation.That judgment repeatedly criticised the whistleblower‚Äôs treatment by two of her senior colleagues: line manager Julian Henderson and chief vet Robert Huey. DAERA has taken no action against either man.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up At the heart of the case was Dr Bronckaers‚Äô desire to enforce the law against Ballymena Livestock Market over alleged suffering caused to animals, as well as livestock movements being electronically deleted from DAERA‚Äôs much-vaunted computer system meant to track all inter-farm moves to ensure traceability of meat.Dr Huey told Dr Bronckaers that he knew the manager of Ballymena Livestock Market personally and that he also knew its chairman. Both he and Dr Henderson discouraged her from pursuing enforcement of the law, with Dr Bronckaers left in tears after an encounter with Dr Huey.In a statement on Thursday, DAERA said it ‚Äúunreservedly apologises‚Äù to Dr Bronckaers and said it had set up an ‚Äúinternal review‚Äù into the issue. The department also denied that Minister Edwin Poots had ever had any involvement in the case, despite being in charge of the department and despite the case having been extensively reported by this newspaper and other media outlets for months.Last month the Belfastasked the Head of the Civil Service, Jayne Brady,it was acceptable on her watch for a Stormont department to attempt to overturn a judicial finding that a civil servant was driven from her job after she blew the whistle on potential fraud and animal suffering, and whether she had any message for whistleblowers. At the time, Dr Brady said it was ‚Äúnot appropriate to comment on an ongoing legal issue which is a matter for DAERA‚Äù.However, now that DAERA has abandoned its appeal, Dr Brady has issued her first substantive comment on the case. In a brief statement to this newspaper, a spokesman for Dr Brady said: ‚ÄúAs Head of the Civil Service, I unreservedly apologise to Dr Bronckaers.‚ÄúThis case highlights a number of signicant concerns and I welcome the internal audit being undertaken by DAERA into this matter. Work is underway on actions to improve our processes for dealing with concerns raised both internally and externally and I have asked that this is taken forward at pace and consistently across all departments.‚ÄúThis underlines the need to drive forward the important work we have committed to do as an employer.‚ÄùRelated topicsDepartment of Agriculture, Environment  Rural Affairs - Edwin PootsMore On " class"-as:"Department of Agriculture, Environment  Rural Affairs - Environmentalists take Stormont department to High Court over ‚Äòhighly damaging‚Äô gas storage projectStormont criticised for ‚Äòinadequate response‚Äô after , wildfires in two years PremiumDepartment refuses to release information after Tamara Bronckaers tribunal caseStormont department criticised for building Derry park-and-ride which breaches planning rulesPlanning system is chronic failure, says Stormont watchdogMost ReadVideo: Feral teenagers‚Äô attack on police in Co Down village caught on cameraCharity fight event in Belfast marred by violence outside hotelBelfast paedophile brothers Gary and Gregory Rea shocked to be shunned by neighboursMan arrested after street brawl on Belfast‚Äôs Dublin RoadDecoratordenies that he ripped off almost  pensionersTop VideosPlayFootage of an attack on police in Killough Co DownPlayPolice attend fatal road collison on Toome BypassPlayThe Derry Girlsjourneyand what next for the showLatest Northern IrelandAntrim manager Elaine Dowds praises players after battling defeat by WexfordWoman in s dies in Newry while waiting for an ambulance from BelfastViewpointOpinionWheel of fortune turns full circle for Portrush‚ÄòA dream come true‚Äô ‚Ä¶ artist Jacqueline Rooney on her Jay Blades dealLosing weight  It‚Äôs a cinch!.. Credit: Phil Noble FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueStudents are graduating from university with huge debts. Credit: Phil NobleAndrew MaddenTwitterEmailApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailSome Northern Ireland students are leaving university with close to six-figure debts, it can be revealed today.One person from here has a student debt balance that tops ¬£,, while more than , students have debts of between ¬£, and ¬£,.The figures were obtained by the Belfastfrom the Student Loans Company .It provides loans for students to help pay tuition fees and some living expenses. Once a graduate begins earning a certain amount, they start repaying these loans.Figures obtained via a Freedom of Information request show the extent of some graduates‚Äô debts.The top five highest student loan balances of students from Northern Ireland are ¬£, ¬£, ¬£, ¬£, and ¬£,.Figures also show that there are , graduates who have outstanding student loan balances of between ¬£, and ¬£,.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Ellen Fearon, president of student body NUS-USI, said the figures show the ‚Äúhorric scale of debt our students are burdened by under the current education system‚Äù.In its FOI response, the SLC said the average loan balance for Northern Ireland borrowers is ¬£,.‚ÄúThe student finance system is designed to provide funding for ious levels of study from further education, through to higher and then postgraduate, and doctoral study. The system also includes safeguards for students as it enables them to access extra years‚Äô funding for resits,  starts and Compelling Personal Reasons where appropriate,‚Äù the company said.‚ÄúTherefore these higher loan balances are not reflective of the average level of student loan debt for a student on the standard three year higher education course journey.‚ÄúCustomers with balances higher than the average level of student loan debt may be in receipt of several student loan products, for example loans for an undergraduate course then a postgraduate course.‚ÄúOther factors which are relevant include customers who have received funding for multiple courses, customers who have received funding under multiple plan types, customers who have received additional years‚Äô funding due to Compelling Personal Reasons, or customers who are on courses of   years in .‚ÄúThe iniduals concerned have received student finance in line with the statutory framework applicable to them at the time funding was awarded and paid.Ms Fearon called for an end to fees.‚ÄùHigher education benefits everyone whether or not they attend university ‚Äî it trains our doctors, teachers, engineers, architects, artists. Our society simply wouldn‚Äôtwithout it,‚Äù she said.‚ÄúJust a few decades ago people attending university got their education paid for by government, and received a grant to support them while they were there. Now there are people in this country taking on debts of over ¬£, to receive the same education. This is unjust. Students deserve better than the failed experiment of the loan system. Abolish tuition fees.‚ÄùSDLP economy spokesperson Matthew O‚ÄôToole said his party has¬†been campaigning for the abolition of tuition fees for years.‚ÄúThe scale of some of these numbers are truly astonishing. It‚Äôs frightening to think more than , people here have debts of between ¬£, and ¬£, simply for pursuing an education,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúThose figures are on the scale of a mortgage rather than any reasonable amount of educational debt.‚ÄúThese highlight the grim reality facing many of our young graduates here. Instead of incentivising young people to stay in education, tuition fees penalise them.‚ÄúThe SDLP have been consistent in advocating for the abolition of tuition fees. Education should be treated as a right, not a source of revenue.‚ÄùIn a further statement, the SLC said: ‚ÄúStudent loans are income contingent, this means that¬†repayments are based on how much they earn, not on their loan balance. title: p and o ferries set to restart larne to cairnryan route following inspection
story: PO at Larne port . FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePO at Larne port .Garrett HarganTwitterEmailApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailFerry company PO has announced that services between Larne and Cairnryan in Scotland will restart on Sunday morning.Its vessels were grounded last month after PO sacked around  seafaring workers over a Zoom call and replaced them with low-paid agency staff.The company faced widespread criticism from workers and trade unions over the dismissals.A spokesperson for PO Ferries said: ‚ÄúOn Friday, the Maritime and Coastguard Agencycompleted its most recent inspection of the European Causeway, and have confirmed it is safe to sail.‚ÄúWe are delighted that we will be able to restart full services between Larne and Cairnryan from am, Sunday th April.‚ÄúPO is pleased to play its part in supporting customers to move vital goods between the Northern Ireland and Scotland.‚ÄùOn Thursday the Maritime and Coastguard Agencysaid it was carrying out a reinspection of the European Causeway at PO Ferries‚Äô request.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up An MCA spokesman said: ‚ÄúAll inspections have to satisfy the Maritime and Coastguard Agency that the ferries fulfil the requirement of the Port State Control regime and are safe to put to sea.‚ÄúThere are no further inspections of PO Ferries at the moment but we will reinspect at the appropriate time.‚ÄùEarlier this week PO said the Larne route and others would resume this weekend.Rival ferry company Stena Line has been absorbing some of the business from would-be PO customers, on its Belfast to Cairnryan route.One worker said staff at the business were ‚Äúworking their socks off‚Äù to cope with the big jump in demand.The business was thought to be meeting between  and % of the demand from PO customers.It had erted one ship, the Nordica, from the Holyhead to Dublin route to service the demand.As well as members of the public, PO also provides services to commercial customers such as Asda and Marks  Spencer.Most title: unionists snub group which aims to improve cross community relations
story: Councillor Kim Ashton. Credit: Stephen Davison FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueCouncillor Kim Ashton. Credit: Stephen DavisonAdam MortonApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailNo unionists attended the second and final meeting of a council working group that aims to promote cross-community relations.According to minutes, five Sinn Fein and one SDLP councillor attended Mid Ulster District Council‚Äôs good relations working group on March .In December, the committee¬†chairman, Ulster Unionist¬†Derek McKinney said he would not be attending future meetings as he believes ‚Äúthere are no good relations on the council‚Äù.Previously, DUP councillors, Kim Ashton, Paul McLean and Kyle Black had sent apologies for not attending.However, the minutes note that no apologies were received for absences from the recent meeting.Unionist councillors in Mid Ulster have been critical of moves to¬†spend ¬£, of ratepayers‚Äô money on the establishment of a working group to promote discussions about Irish unity, a move that has been taken forward by the good relations working group.This group has been backed by  nationalists and independents, and opposed by¬†unionists.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up At a meeting of the good relations working group in March, those present were told that a specication for workshops had been developed and sent out for quotations, with the expectation being that five online events and a close event will take place in June.Commenting on the minutes, DUP councillor Kim Ashton noted the make-up of the good relations working group is ‚Äúreally now the nationalist relations working group as there is no unionist attending that‚Äù.‚ÄúOur parties have concerns about the money¬†that is being spent through this channel looking at a United Ireland,‚Äù she said.Sinn Fein councillor Sean McPeake took the opportunity to ‚Äúinvite unionists‚Äù tonoting ‚Äúthey have essentially boycotted the group since its inception‚Äù.‚ÄúThe group would be much stronger and richer¬† they were on it but we can only but appeal for them to come onboard,‚Äù he said.Related topicsSinn F√©inDemocratic Unionist PartyUlster title: dup wont run females just to tick a box says candidate
story: There was criticism about the number of women who will be represented in electionsExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseDUP candidate Diane Forsythe. Credit: Press Eye FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDUP candidate Diane Forsythe. Credit: Press EyeLisa SmythTwitterApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThe DUP has defended the low number of female candidates it is running in next month‚Äôs Assembly elections.With just a quarter of women making its list of candidates, the DUP has the lowest number of females in the running for election out of Northern Ireland‚Äôs five main political parties.By contrast, % of Sinn Fein candidates are women, followed by the Alliance Party, where half of its runners are female. The SDLP is next, with % of candidates women, while a third of the UUP‚Äôs runners are female.The DUP‚Äôs South Down candidate has rejected accusations of gender bias and said the party does not run females as a tick box exercise.Diane Forsythe, who has replaced Jim Wells as the DUP‚Äôs candidate after  years at Stormont, said: ‚ÄúI am an accountant and mother of three young children.‚ÄúI am the only DUP candidate in this constituency.‚ÄúA lot of parties field female candidates in seats where they have little chance of winning or they field women as a second candidate but then ide the area in way which makes it very dficult for the female candidate to win. This shouldn‚Äôt be about tokenism. The DUP run female candidates in seats where we can win.‚ÄùDaily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Ms Forsythe also pointed out the fact that the DUP was the first major party to have a female leader and female First Minister.‚ÄúWe want to see more females in politics but it should be on merit rather not than tokenism,‚Äù she added.Meanwhile, UUP leader Doug Beattie said ensuring more women represent the party at Stormont remains¬†a priority and that efforts will continue to increase the number of female UUP MLAs.‚ÄúWhen I took over as leader of the UUP in May last year, I made it one of my absolute priorities to encourage more female candidates to come forward,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúWe have not yet reached where I want us to be ‚Äî¬†% of our Assembly candidates are female, but I desperately want this to increase at the next Assembly elections.‚ÄúThey may have been selected, but the most important thing now is getting them elected alongside their male colleagues, so that we have a base to build on for the future.‚ÄúWe are on a journey and I want to bring about further change as we head towards next year`s council elections and every election after that.‚ÄùMr Beattie said he wants the make-up of his¬†party to¬†‚Äúreflect society‚Äù.He continued: ‚ÄúDiversity and inclusion can only increase the strength of any organisation. We need more role models and I hope that the exceptional candidates we are standing at this election will be future leaders in our party and society.‚ÄúWe are not yet there yet, but I am absolutely committed to taking us in the right direction.‚ÄùConnie Egan, who is running for the Alliance Party in North Down, welcomed the gender make-up of her party‚Äôs candidates which she said had happened without a quota being set.¬†However, she said more needs to be done to tackle sexism faced by female candidates: ‚ÄúWe each have a role to play in ensuring we continue to encourage more women to participate.‚ÄùRelated topicsDemocratic Unionist PartySDLPAlliance PartyNorthern Ireland AssemblyJim WellsDoug BeattieMore On Democratic Unionist PartyUnionists snub group which aims to improve
